title: A SINCERE FAITH
message:
January 7, 2018

A SINCERE FAITH

Devotional Reading: Psalm 56

Background Scripture: Daniel 1

Lesson Scripture: Daniel 1:8-21

Golden Text

But Daniel resolved not to defile himself with the royal food and wine, Daniel 1:8a

Objectives :

By the end of the lesson, class members should be able to:

  • Explain why Daniel refused to take the royal food and wine.
  • Suggest how Christians can stay true to their faith in the face of challenging situations.
  • Write down their commitment to obey God always rather than humankind, regardless of the consequences.

INTRODUCTION

he quest for money, power and position has made many Christians compromise their faith with the excuse that God understands. Due to challenges, many have put aside godly principles, doing whatever it takes to get what they want. Our disposition during challenging moments as believers testifies to our level of faith in God. This statement reminds us of the story of Prince Omodaro Andrew who was born into a Christian home. He had the opportunity to attend one of the most popular and expensive private primary and secondary schools in town. His parents succeeded in bringing him up in the way and fear of God, so, he became dedicated to the things of God early in life. Consequently, they were careful about his choice of friends and activities from time to time. After his secondary education, he had the opportunity to travel outside the country for further studies. Unfortunately, he soon forgot both his moral and spiritual training and was negatively influenced by the culture of the people simply because he was no longer under the tutelage of his parents. Eventually, he abandoned his studies and got involved in internet scam and other evil vices that finally led him to jail.

The topic of today focuses on Daniel and how he refused to compromise his faith in God when he was taken captive to Babylon, the year King Nebuchadnezzar conquered Jerusalem. Daniel and his friends were found to be qualified for recruitment into the service of the King of Babylon. Daniel found himself in a foreign land, but he refused to be influenced by the evil practices of the people. Instead, he maintained his spiritual maturity and demonstrated unreserved loyalty to God by refusing to defile himself with the royal food, even though it was his right. The topic shall be discussed in three sub-headings.

THE LESSON EXPLAINED

  1. Daniel's Resolution Daniel 1:8-14

    In the year King Nebuchadnezzar conquered Jerusalem, he ordered that some of the Israelites from the royal family be brought to Babylon to serve in the king\'s palace. Daniel and his friends were among the captives. They were to be fed with the king\'s food and wine and trained for three years before they could qualify to enter the king\'s service (vv. 1-5). According to verse 8, Daniel was faced with the dilemma of whether or not to comply with the royal order, especially when he knew that the Babylonian food must have been prepared and dedicated to their gods and, therefore, was not good for an Israelite like him (Deuteronomy 14:3-21) because it could cause defilement. Daniel resolved to stick to the commands of God rather than defile himself with the royal food and wine (v. 8). Therefore, he wisely negotiated with the chief official for permission to be exempted from the king\'s food but to have a ten-day trial of vegetarian diet. Nevertheless, the Lord granted Daniel favour and the official agreed to test Daniel and three other Hebrew young men for ten days only on vegetable meals.

    However, we should know that Daniel was not a rebel who just wanted to defy the order of a constituted authority for his personal gains. Of course, he knew that his compromise would result to defilement as an Israelite, so, he was resolute. He humbly persuaded the guard to test them for ten days only on vegetable meals. His persistence in pursuing what is pleasing to God is commendable and worthy of emulation. Of course, Daniel knew the consequences of his resolution and he was ready to face it instead of compromising his faith. Likewise, believers today should strive to hold on to their faith and not give up when they are faced with some life-threatening situations, knowing that God will provide a way of escape like He did for Daniel, who was promoted in a foreign land.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. Why did Daniel refuse to take the royal food and wine?
    2. What are the things that can be likened to royal delicacies in our contemporary time that Christians should avoid?
    3. Discuss Daniel's source of boldness.
  2. Daniel's Convincing Result Daniel 1:15-16

    The fact has been established that God made Daniel and his friends to find favour in the sight of Ashpenaz who allowed them to live on vegetable meals instead of the king\'s delicacies. Subsequently, after ten days, there was a convincing result. When Daniel and his friends were assessed and compared with those who took the royal delicacies, they were found healthier and better nourished than the others who lived on the royal diet. Without doubt, the guard was convinced that Daniel and his friends had done well with their vegetarian diet. Therefore, he completely withdrew the royal food and wine from them.

    One can imagine how Daniel and the other Israelite young men felt after they realised that the ten-day diet trial made a difference after all. The great lesson is that Daniel dared to be different when it was actually difficult to do so, especially in a foreign land. It is not uncommon that some believers suffer great loss because of their faith in the Lord, like Stephen, who was stoned to death and other apostles. No wonder Paul said, "I consider that our present sufferings are not worth comparing with the glory that will be revealed in us" (Romans 8:18). In other words, whatever we lose as a result of our faith is temporary because, like He did for Daniel, the Lord will reward us accordingly.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. As a Christian public servant, what would you do if you are constantly denied promotion because you refused to compromise the standard of the Bible?
    2. How can Christian artisans demonstrate sincere faith in their dealings with their clients in their bid to make profit?
    3. What is your counsel for a Christian student who has consistently failed an examination and finally had a free offer of supply of answers to examination questions (\'expo\')?
  3. Daniel's Amazing Reward Daniel 1:17-21

    One of the attributes of God is that He rewards faithfulness like the case of Daniel and his friends who sought to please Him above pleasure, personal gratification and royal esteem. According to the passage, God had blessed these young men with "knowledge and understanding of all kinds of literature and learning” (Daniel 1:17). They quickly mastered the Babylonian language and became experts. Specifically, Daniel was gifted in the understanding and interpretation of all kinds of dreams and visions by divine revelation. When they were presented to the king for appraisal, he found that no one was equal to Daniel, Hananiah, Mishael, and Azariah, so they were qualified and entered into the king\'s service. Furthermore, the king found the young men ten times better in matters of wisdom and understanding than the magicians and the enchanters in the whole kingdom (v. 20). Daniel lived long and remained in office until the first year of King Cyrus. His faithfulness was rewarded as he worked with Nebuchadnezzar, Belshazzar, Darius and Cyrus (Daniel 1:21; 6:28).

    Daniel and his friends were exemplary in their relationship with God. Although they were in a foreign land, they knew their God and remained faithful to Him. Therefore, the challenge is that believers should be ready to obey God rather than people, even when the situation is criticallike the case of Daniel and his friends. We should always seek to obey God not minding the consequences. Worthy of note in the passage also is the fact that the three years of waiting, serving and perseverance by these youths who chose to obey God despite the danger they found themselves was rewarded with promotion and prominence.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. Does God\'s laws have direct effect on our day-to-day living? Consider Daniel\'s choice of food in compliance with God\'s law and the possible effect on his lifespan.
    2. Discuss the various ways God rewards faithfulness.
    3. Let some members share their testimonies of God\'s reward for their faithfulness recently.

Prayer Points

  • Thank God for whatever situation you have found yourself, whether pleasant or unpleasant.
  • Pray for more of God\'s grace and wisdom to handle instances of conflicting sources of authority that you are confronted with without compromise.
  • Ask God to remember you for good and promote you in every area where you have suffered retardation in the process of keeping the faith.

Fellowship and Ministry Building Activities

  • Make a list of Christians in politics in your church and our Convention, send a message to each of them encouraging them to be a Daniel in their different places of assignments.
  • Class members should memorise Daniel 1:8a and make it their watchword.

Take Home

  • There will always be situations that contend with our commitment and obedience to God.
  • Believers should be law-abiding.
  • When other laws conflict with that of God, our priority should be obedience to God.
  • Christians should be polite in our bid to defend the faith.

title: A BOLD FAITH
message:
January 14, 2018

A BOLD FAITH

Devotional Reading: Romans 12:9-21

Background Scripture: Daniel 3

Lesson Scripture: Daniel 3:19-23, 26-28

Golden Text

Then Nebuchadnezzar said, "Praise be the God of Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego, who has sent his angel and rescued his servant. They trusted in him and defied the king\'s command and were willing to give up their lives rather than serve or worship any god except their own God." Daniel 3:28

Objectives :

By the end of the lesson, class members should be able to:

  • Identify the source of the three Hebrew young men\'s boldness.
  • Analyse why the three Hebrews chose to suffer the consequence rather than worship the golden image.
  • Discuss how their bold faith can draw others to God.

INTRODUCTION

Mr Effiong Michael was a senior supervisor in one of the fastest growing communication companies in Nigeria. He is known for his piety and dedication at home, office and in church. He has been praying and believing God for promotion to the post of a sales manager in one of the new branches in the North East. Having been interviewed, he emerged the best qualified and experienced candidate for the position. The only problem was that he was given an option of joining a cult before the promotion will be effected. Although some friends and even his wife persuaded him to accept the option because of the benefits attached to it, Mr Effiong vowed never to compromise his faith for the sake of money or position. How will you describe Mr Effiong?

The story above pictures the nature of our journey of faith in God. It is sometimes full of all kinds of temptations that can easily lead believers into sin, especially those who are not bold enough to demonstrate their faith in God. Nevertheless, God has empowered us to resist all forms of temptations with the boldness that we have in Christ, like the Hebrew young men in today\'s passage. Instead of fear and intimidation, the three young men expressed bold faith in God even in the face of challenges.

THE LESSON EXPLAINED

  1. A Death Sentence Daniel 3:19-23

    King Nebuchadnezzar was a powerful king who demanded total loyalty to his commands throughout his domain. He made a gold statue and set it up in the province of Babylon with the command that everyone must worship it. The penalty for __ disobedience was death sentence that individual will immediately be thrown into a blazing furnace (vv. 1-6). The king issued a decree to authenticate the order but Shadrach, Meshach and Abednego who have been true to their faith in God publicly declared their unwillingness to compromise their faith and bow to a graven image (vv. 16-18). Of course, the three Hebrew young men who refused to bow to the golden image of the king put their lives on the line. In rage, the king ordered that the intensity of the fire be increased seven times over. These men were bound and thrown into the furnace with their robes on, by some soldiers. However, these men stayed with their convictions and never compromised.

    The faith and lifestyle of the three Hebrew men in a foreign land is worthy of emulation. Even though they knew the consequences of their resolution, they were not ready to worship the golden image of King Nebuchadnezzar. They were bold __ because they knew their God they knew that it is more rewarding to obey God rather than human beings, even when threatened with death penalty. It is obvious that if they had bowed to the golden image because they did not want to die in the blazing furnace, they would have still died perhaps a more horrible death without becoming heroes. Christians are, therefore, encouraged to be bold in exercising their faith, no matter the conspiracy from the kingdom of darkness. The assurance we have is that God will always provide a way of escape for His children.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. Why does God sometimes let His people experience suffering or hardship?
    2. Discuss the reasons why the three Hebrews preferred to be thrown into the furnace to bowing down and worshipping the golden image.
    3. What can make believers compromise their faith today? Can those reasons be tenable before God?
  2. Divine Protection and Promotion Daniel 3:26-28

    The three young men were actually thrown into the fire without pity according to the command of the king but the testimony is that they remained unhurt. According to verses 24 and 25, the king was troubled when he saw a fourth image (like a son of the gods) and that they were unhurt. In amazement, he went to the door of the blazing fire and called out Shadrach, Meshach and Abednego addressing them as "servants of the Most High God" (v. 26). Apparently, their miraculous deliverance from the fire attracted the attention of all the princes, governors, lieutenant-governors and other officials of the king; they all saw and confirmed their miraculous escape. Interestingly, not even their hair or clothes were burnt and there was no smell of smoke on them (v. 27). In his response in verse 28, the king sang to the praise of the God of Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego who sent His angel to rescue the three young men from the blazing fire. Eventually, the king testified to their unreserved loyalty to their God and how they risked their lives rather than bowing down and worshipping the image.

    Whenever Christians hold to their faith without compromise, God always provides a way of escape like He did for the three Hebrew men who demonstrated boldness and faith in Him for deliverance. The experience of the young men ultimately translated to an opportunity for the king to acknowledge the powerful nature of the God of Shadrach, Meshach and Abednego before the \'honourables\' of the Babylonian empire. In fact, King Nebuchadnezzar himself became their \'interpreter\' who translated their action to words. The king praised the God of the three Hebrew men and declared that God\'s angels rescued them. He also affirmed that their faith was worth dying for (Daniel 3:28). The implication, therefore, is that our disposition to life’s challenges, especially as Christians, matters to God greatly and more importantly, it can be a means of spreading the Gospel to unbelievers.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. Discuss how being bold about your faith can draw others to God.
    2. Why do some believers easily give up in the face of persecution? How can the story of the three young men encourage them to be more faithful to God?
    3. Write out your commitment to demonstrate bold faith as you continue in life.

Prayer Points

  • Pray that God will increase your faith to be a better witness for Him, especially in the face of temptations and threats.
  • Pray against the spirit of compromise, no matter how challenging the situation may be.
  • Ask God to restore those who have fallen from the faith and begin to live as better Christians.

Fellowship and Ministry Building Activities

  • Share your current challenges among yourselves and encourage one another to boldly face the issues by faith.
  • Pray about each of the issues you have shared.

Take Home

  • Temptations and challenges are inevitable in the journey of faith.
  • Learn to keep records of God\'s past deeds in your life and praise Him.
  • Christians should be careful how they react when they are faced with difficulties.
  • God does not abandon His people in their time of distress.

title: A CRY FOR HELP
message:
January 21, 2018

A CRY FOR HELP

Devotional Reading: Psalm 130

Background Scripture: Daniel 9:1-19

Lesson Scripture: Daniel 9:4-8, 15-19

Golden Text

O Lord, listen! O Lord forgive! O Lord, hear and act! For your sake O my God, do not delay, because your city and your people bear your Name. Daniel 9:19

Objectives :

By the end of the lesson, class members should be able to:

  • Recall the wonderful deeds of God in their lives, families, church or nation.
  • Analyse the prayer of Daniel and relate it with their specific situations.
  • Pray in a way that indicates their dependence on God, not on self- righteousness.

INTRODUCTION

A story was once told of a Christian community whose inhabitants were known to be pious and faithful in all their dealings. Their devotion was so noticeable that other communities worked hard to emulate them. Suddenly, they began to experience strange things that bothered the minds of the people, especially the elderly who had witnessed God\'s faithfulness in time past. As they continued to pray for deliverance, it was revealed that they needed to pray and intercede on behalf of the community. Without delay, they set aside some days for prayer, fasting and confession of their known and unknown sins; asking for God\'s forgiveness. It was said that God answered their prayers and the people began to live their normal lives.

Today\'s topic centres on Daniel’s prayer based on the word of God given to Jeremiah. Before this time, Daniel had an understanding from the Scriptures that the desolation of Jerusalem would last for seventy years. Therefore, he turned to the Lord God and offered a prayer of help to Him on behalf of his people, Israel. The prayer was characterised by praise, confession and petition to God. His prayer was with humility, precision, as he acknowledged God\'s past deeds among them.

THE LESSON EXPLAINED

  1. A Sincere Confession of Sins Daniel 9:4-8

    In the first year of the reign of Darius, son of Xerxes, Daniel understood from the Scriptures, according to the word of the Lord given to Prophet Jeremiah, that the captivity which was then drawing near would last seventy years. Upon the discovery, Daniel prayed earnestly to the Lord God; he fasted, wore sackcloth and sat on ashes as signs of mourning (vv. 2-3) and confessed the sins his people. The content of his prayer beginning from verse 4 can be analysed as:

    • He acknowledged God as great and awesome - One who keeps His covenant of love with all who love and obey Him commands.
    • He acknowledged the sins and wickedness of the people without exonerating himself.
    • He acknowledged that the people did not listen to the prophets who spoke to their kings and fathers.
    • He confessed that all the men in Judah and the people of Jerusalem are covered with shame because of their unfaithfulness to God

    It should be noted that Daniel did not exonerate himself from the sins of his people. He acknowledged their short-comings, identified with his people and their sins using the collective pronoun \'we\'. It is obvious that Daniel was sincere in his assessment of their status in the light of God\'s righteousness. He did not accuse God or his people. Rather, he admitted that their predicament was as a result of their own unfaithfulness and rebellion to God. According to the New International Version Commentary, Daniel\'s prayer can be classified into worship, confession and petition. The lesson, therefore, is that Christians should not always apportion blame to people, especially in times of difficulty. Instead, they should be ready to identify with them and their sins and, therefore, play the role of an intercessor like Daniel.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. Should a Christian who is in right standing with God bother about generational sins?
    2. What is your understanding of the doctrine of inherited guilt, based on Exodus 20:5-6; 34:6-7?
  2. An Appeal to God\'s Faithfulness Daniel 9:15-16

    Daniel was a great intercessor. Having acknowledged their sins with a contrite heart, he pleaded for God\'s intervention. He, thereafter, referred to God\'s righteous acts when He brought His people out of Egypt and, therefore, made for Himself a name that endures forever. In verse 15b he stated categorically, "... we have sinned, we have done wrong." In recognition of their sinful acts, he appealed to God to turn away His wrath and anger from Jerusalem (v. 16). His appeal centred on the fact that the sins and iniquities of their fathers have made Jerusalem and God\'s people an object of ridicule to other nations, thereby bringing dishonour to His holy Name. Obviously, Daniel understood that God punishes sinners up to the fourth generation; however, He also forgives wickedness, rebellion and sins (Exodus 34:7). He, therefore, appealed to God to turn away His anger so that Jerusalem will no longer be an object of ridicule.

    Daniel\'s ability to recall the faithful deeds of God among His people in the past reinforced his faith in God\'s ability to show Himself faithful again. In his appeal, Daniel described Jerusalem as God\'s city and holy hill, though the people continuously rebelled against God and His commands and, therefore, deserved to be punished. However, Daniel\'s concern was that God\'s well-revered name should not be profaned among the Gentile nations, thereby bringing shame and reproach to His holy Name.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. Why did Daniel not recount his personal deeds of righteousness in this prayer? What does it teach about leaders?
    2. What can we do when we have discovered generational issues that may hinder our progress? Should we just resign to fate and continue to struggle
  3. A Precise Call for Divine Intervention Daniel 9:17-19

    This passage is truly a cry for God\'s intervention as expressed by Daniel. Having identified their problem as a nation, he then made his request for mercy known to God. He said, "Now, our God, hear the prayers and petitions of your servant. For your sake O Lord, look with favour on your desolate sanctuary." (v. 17) In fact, verse 19 is a summary of his prayer of petition as he asked the Lord to listen, forgive, hear and act. He, however, acknowledged the fact that his request was based on the integrity of God and not the righteousness of the people. Furthermore, His city and people bear His Name (v. 19b), which must be carefully protected among the heathen nations.

    Daniel demonstrated one of the qualities of a good leader who had the interest of his people at heart. His prayer was specific and concise that: God will hear his prayers and petitions and restore the desolation of Jerusalem because of His mercy (v. 18). Daniel\'s cry for divine intervention is worthy of emulation. As a godly leader, he was able to identify the wrongdoing of his people and proffer the best solution (God\'s intervention). This implies that whenever we acknowledge and understand God\'s Word as believers, we can be led to sincere repentance that will pave way for answered prayers whenever we sin against God, either as a nation, family or individuals.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. Analyse the prayer of Daniel, identifying the major features and how that can inform your own prayer according to your individual situations.
    2. How would you describe leaders who often apportion blames instead of interceding on behalf of their people?

Prayer Points

  • Pray that God should help you to understand His Word and cause you to discover the hidden truth therein.
  • Pray that God should help you to understand His Word and cause you to discover the hidden truth therein.
  • Pray for the restoration of our nation for the glory of God.

Fellowship and Ministry Building Activities

  • Recall the wonderful deeds of God in your lives, families, church or nation and compose a song of thanksgiving.
  • Identify collective sins in your community/family. Confess them to God and pray for grace not to indulge in such acts again. (Write down your commitment to aid your memory).

Take Home

  • The understanding of God\'s Word leads to liberation.
  • Our prayers may not be acceptable to God when we fail to confess our sins.
  • Be specific and straight to the point in your prayers.
  • Despite the sinful nature of humankind, God is still faithful.

title: A STRONG FAITH
message:
January 28, 2018

A STRONG FAITH

Devotional Reading: Revelation 1:9-18

Background Scripture: Daniel 10; 11

Lesson Scripture: Daniel 10:10-19

Golden Text

"Do not be afraid, O man highly esteemed," he said, "Peace! Be strong now; be strong. When he spoke to me, I was strengthened and said, 'Speak, my lord, since you have given me strengthen." Daniel 10:19

Objectives :

By the end of the lesson, class members should be able to:

  • Discuss Christians' attitude in the face of delayed answers to prayer.
  • Explain the role of angels in believers' walk with God.
  • Identify the qualities that make God interested in people, like Daniel.

INTRODUCTION

A pregnant woman who had a prolonged labour had to endure the travails and pains of the delivery process. However, rather than having a progressive process, her dilation was static for unknown reasons. As the woman relaxed at intervals, the nurses urged and pleaded with her not to give up because that may be dangerous for her and her unborn baby. Unfortunately, the more she tried to make progress, the more she encountered difficulty. Immediately the medical team concluded that she could not have the baby on her own, thus, they made an alternative arrangement for her in order to save her life and her baby.

In our text today, the experience of Daniel can be likened to the story of the woman, as narrated above. As a prayer warrior, Daniel had fasted and mourned for three weeks over the sins of his people. He had travailed in prayer for God's intervention on behalf of His people but it seemed no answer was forthcoming. Ultimately, his physical strength failed and he became weak just like the woman in the story. He was in this state when he saw the vision of a man who touched and strengthened him. In other words, Daniel was encouraged to have strong faith in God and be courageous. The man revealed to him his plans to fight against the prince of Persia so that the prince of Greece will come (v. 20). Nevertheless, those who were with him did not see anyone but they were overwhelmed with terror and so, they hid themselves. Delay in receiving answers to our prayers is not only common to people of old. Even today, believers still experience delay in receiving answers to their prayers that may have been hindered by evil forces. But one thing is sure, God is always ready to fight our battles and give us victory, especially those who have strong faith in Him.

THE LESSON EXPLAINED

  1. A Message for Daniel Daniel 10:10-14

    In the third year of Cyrus, king of Persia, Daniel had a revelation concerning a great war. Consequently, his response was quick and astonishing. He decided to mourn for a period of three weeks without food or wine (vv. 1-2). During this period, he saw a man that looked like an angel who said to him, "Do not be afraid, Daniel. Since the first day that you set your mind to gain understanding and to humble yourself before your God, your words were heard and I have come in response to them. But the prince of the Persian kingdom resisted me twenty-one days ..." (vv. 12-13). The testimony of Daniel\'s experience was that God intervened as one of the chief princes (Michael) came to rescue him. The message to him was clear and concise and that it was for an appointed time (v. 14). The angel's message to Daniel was an assurance and a confirmation that:

    • He was greatly loved by God despite the delay in receiving answers to his prayers.
    • His prayers have been heard since the first day he began to seek the face of God.
    • The prince of Persia was the reason for the seeming delay in receiving answers to his prayer before the intervention of Michael, one of the chief princes.
    • The vision was for the future.

    Notable in the passage is that although Daniel was greatly loved of God, he experienced delay in receiving answers to his prayers. Nevertheless Daniel did not give up in the place of prayer and fasting, a show of strong faith in God. In contrast, some believers today give up or are in the habit of blaming God for not responding to their prayers despite their commitment to His work. As Daniel persisted, God intervened, and his prayers were answered. Note that answers to our prayers may be hindered but we must “pray continually” (1 Thessalonians 5:17) and ask until our joy is full (John 16:24). The reason is that our prayer is both a communion with God and a spiritual warfare (Ephesians 6:10-12, 18), which should be offered in righteousness and with strong faith in God.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. What are the indications that Daniel was greatly loved by God?
    2. Should the prayer of believers be hindered by any force whatsoever?
    3. How can we sustain our faith today when we are faced with the challenges of seeming unanswered prayer or delayed answers to prayer?
  2. Divine Strength for Daniel Daniel 10:15-19

    Daniel's response to the vision is remarkable. At the appearance of the angel, he bowed and remained speechless as a sign of reverence to God. Suddenly, the angel touched him and he started to speak. He said to the angel. "I am overcome with anguish because of the vision, my lord, and I am helpless" (v. 16b). Thereafter, he confessed his unworthiness to speak with him (the angel) and his loss of physical strength. According to verse 18, Daniel was touched again by the angel and that brought restoration and renewed strength he needed for that moment. The angel said to him, "Do not be afraid, O man highly esteemed ... Peace! Be strong now; be strong." (v. 19) and immediately, he was strengthened. In the same vein, the Lord stretched out His hand and touched the lips of Jeremiah and put His words in his mouth, when he complained of his inadequacies upon receiving the call of God as a prophet to minister to His people (Jeremiah 1:9).

    It is natural for people to consider their limitations, especially when they are called to serve thus they give different excuses, unlike Daniel who was open to divine touch through the angelic ministration. Even though we are weak as humans, we often forget that God who has called us is capable of empowering us for the ministry, no matter the challenges. It should be noted that Daniel's walk with God, and not his esteemed position in Babylon was responsible for the angel's statement: “... you are highly esteemed” (vv. 11, 19). No doubt that he remained an ideal man of God who demonstrated his unbending faith, even in the face of persecution. He was strengthened after the touch of the angel before he declared the purpose of his visit which was to reveal what is written in the Book of Truth (v. 20). Christians should recognise the role/ministry of angels in our daily living, but we must be careful not to worship them. Afterward, his reference to the angel as 'lord' was not an act of worship, which is due to the Lord only (Deuteronomy 6:4), but as God's messenger.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. What/who is the source of believers' strength today?
    2. What was responsible for Daniel's bowing down and speechlessness? Was there any basis for praying to or with the name of an angel in the passage? vv. 8, 15-18. What can believers do when they are in helpless situations and with no strength?

Prayer Points

  • Pray that God will grant you a resilient faith and courage not to give up in prayer until you receive answers.
  • Pray that the Holy Spirit will open your eyes and mind of understanding so that you can pray rightly in seemingly hopeless and difficult situations.
  • Pray for God's intervention on those issues of delayed and prolonged breakthrough.

Fellowship and Ministry Building Activities

  • Share practical ways of seeking God's face effectively through fasting and prayer – both in person and as a group.

Take Home

  • Believers should pray ceaselessly.
  • God will not leave us helpless in times of trouble.
  • Angels are ministering spirits; therefore, believers must not worship them.
  • God still reveals secret things to those who walk with Him in purity.

title: FAITH WITHOUT WORKS IS DEAD
message:
February 4, 2018

FAITH WITHOUT WORKS IS DEAD

Devotional Reading: Psalm 143

Background Scripture/Lesson Scripture: James 2:14-26

Golden Text

In the same way, faith by itself, if it is not accompanied by action, is dead. James 2:17

Objectives :

By the end of the lesson, class members should be able to:

  • Differentiate between a dead and living faith.
  • List some practical ways to prove their faith.
  • Agree as a group on individuals to minister to in the new week.

INTRODUCTION

Sister Grace Elumena is a member of a Baptist church. She is known to be pious, responsible and has vowed to keep her virginity until her wedding night. She had prayed and waited fervently for a life partner without result. While observing her quiet time one morning, she received a message from God to fix her wedding date even though she was not yet engaged. After due consultation with her church pastor, she obeyed and acted accordingly.

Some months later, a brother who had prayed and was convinced of God's leading to marry sister Grace started to develop interest in her. However, he lacked the courage to make his intention known to her until there was an intermediary. When they both visited their pastor and told him their intention to maintain the wedding date, their pastor concluded that the brother had faith based on his conviction but lacked action. Nevertheless, the wedding took place as scheduled and God's name was glorified. Little wonder some people have defined faith as the proof of what we have not seen but we believe will be because God is involved. Apart from the fact that faith in God is an important aspect of Christianity, such faith can be described as dead if not translated into action. The author of the book of James wrote to those who had accepted the doctrine of justification by faith, yet were not living right. He made it clear to them that faith can only be proven and developed when we act on it; else, it is a dead faith. The focal point of today's lesson is the importance of proving our faith with corresponding actions of obedience or deeds and not mere words.

THE LESSON EXPLAINED

  1. Faith and Actions Examined James 2:14-17

    James was aware of the discrimination that existed in the church between the rich and the poor and responded accordingly. He carefully examined the difference between faith and action. He opened chapter 2 with a warning against prejudice or favouritism, whereby the rich are given preferential treatment at the expense of the poor. He made it clear that it is pointless for Christians to say they have faith if their actions do not prove it (v. 14) because such faith cannot save them. According to verses 15 and 16, if anyone has the ability to meet the physical needs of another person and fails to do so, his/her faith is useless. Such faith, according to the author, is dead because it is not accompanied by action or deed (v. 17). In contrast, whenever we give food to the hungry, water to the thirsty, and clothes to the naked, we are demonstrating living faith through our action.

    As believers, we have the obligation to care and meet the needs of people around us, no matter who they are. This is what is known as practical or living faith (Galatians 6:10). We have those who are blessed with material resources in our churches, yet are indifferent to the plight of the underprivileged. The understanding of James is that such people have dead faith, no matter what they profess or the level of their spiritual maturity. This implies that one of the ways we can prove our faith is by meeting the needs of people around us (action). We can give out food items, clothes in good condition, textbooks and other possessions. We can also prove our faith by showing concern for the sick and lonely around us. It is sad to note, however, that some rich people find it difficult to identify with the needy while a few others prefer to be begged before they render help. It is our responsibility to identify with the needy, whether they request or not.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. Why do some rich people find it difficult to help their fellow believers who are in need?
    2. Discuss some of the ways the church can be practically involved in helping the needy?
    3. How will the needy feel if neglected when there are people around them who can render help?
  2. Faith without Works Is Dead James 2:18-24

    The author of the book of James pointed out that faith without deeds is dead. Precisely in verse 18b he states, "Show me your faith without deeds, and I will show you my faith by what I do." The evidence of one's faith is the manifestation of good deeds done. He illustrated the difference between a dead and living faith with the example of Abraham who was considered righteous because he was ready to obey God's command and offer his son, Isaac, on the altar of sacrifice (v. 21). Consequently, his faith and action worked together because his faith was made perfect through his action. Therefore, '... the scripture was fulfilled that says, "Abraham believed God, and it was credited to him as righteousness," and he was called God's friend.' (v. 23) The author concluded that one can only be justified by what he does and not necessarily by faith alone; otherwise such faith will be regarded as dead because it does not produce anything. A living faith is usually accompanied by a corresponding action of obedience to the Word of God like the example of Abraham. It is an active faith that produces results by obedience to God or response to the needs of others. Therefore, our profession and corresponding actions show that we have faith; anything contrary is lack of faith __ otherwise called dead faith.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. Why do some Christians struggle to put their faith into action?
    2. Why is dead faith worthless and of no value?
  3. An Example of a Living Faith James 2:25-26

    Apart from the example of Abraham who had a living faith, as shown in his complete obedience to God's command, James also made reference to the faith of Rahab, the prostitute, who welcomed the Israelite spies and helped them to escape from their __ enemies (Joshua 4 8). Eventually, she was put right with God through her actions. Because Abraham and Rahab demonstrated living faith by obedience to God and the spies respectively, they have become part of the heroes/heroine of faith (Hebrews 11:11, 31). Over and again, the author made a comparison between living and dead faith. According to verse 26 he wrote, "As the body without the spirit is dead, so faith without deeds is dead." Invariably, faith and works are inseparable just as our faith cannot be a living faith when we are not willing to obey God's Word.

    God expects us to walk by faith because without faith it is impossible to please Him (Hebrews 11:6). It is important to exhibit corresponding actions so that we can really be the men and women of faith God expects us to be. Although James did not mean that a person is saved by good works; an individual can be declared righteous before God by his/her doing and confession. According to Apostle Paul in his letter to the Galatians, "The only thing that counts is faith expressing itself through love." (Galatians 5:6b) Christians should note this and be ready to express genuine love toward one another, as we relate with people of all races.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. In what ways can we put our faith into action?
    2. What are the things that can hinder us from exercising our faith?
    3. What is the place of prayer in activating our faith?

Prayer Points

  • Pray and thank God for the power of His Word that is living and active.
  • Pray against every form of fear, doubt and unbelief that can hinder you from exercising your faith in God.
  • Ask God to give you the grace that will enable you to believe His Word and act obediently all the time.

Fellowship and Ministry Building Activities

  • Identify a needy person in your church, family or community and minister to their physical needs this week.
  • List five examples each of men/women from both the Old and New Testaments who demonstrated living faith.
  • Pray together as class members for God to increase your faith.

Take Home

  • Faith without works is dead. Our good works can serve as evidence of our faith in God.
  • God expects us to be men and women of faith.
  • Living faith obeys God and proves itself through good deeds.
  • Believers should be sensitive to the needs of others as a markof their faith.

title: A DISCIPLINED FAITH
message:
February 11, 2018

A DISCIPLINED FAITH

Devotional Reading: Psalm 34:1-14

Background Scripture/Lesson Scripture: James 3:1-12

Golden Text

but no man can tame the tongue. It is a restless evil, full of deadly poison. James 3:8

Objectives :

By the end of the lesson, class members should be able to:

  • Discuss the good and bad uses of the tongue.
  • State ways Christians can put their tongues under control.
  • Identify practical ways to use their tongues to minister grace to others.

INTRODUCTION

Mrs Abigail Amadake is one of the respected Christian women in her community. Meanwhile in reality, she is known to be rude, arrogant and often uses abusive words on her husband and children whenever there is misunderstanding at home. One day, she was beaten by her husband to the point that she was admitted to a hospital for several days. After being discharged, she resolved to seek the help of a herbalist to kill her husband. Having narrated her ordeal, the herbalist simply folded an empty sheet of paper and gave it to her saying, "Whenever there is a quarrel between you and your husband, put this paper in your mouth and press it with your teeth so that it will not fall to the ground." The woman strictly adhered to the instruction never to talk back at her husband the next time there was a misunderstanding. While her husband was surprised and became curious about the sudden change in his wife, the woman was eagerly waiting to see her husband dead. However, after much investigation, it was discovered that the herbalist did not do anything special, he only taught the woman indirectly the importance of controlling her tongue whenever there was a quarrel.

Today's lesson focuses on a disciplined faith, especially in the use of our tongues. From experience, some people have found themselves in unnecessary trouble because they could not control their tongues. Besides, mere words have wrecked communal living, marriages and family relationships, and so many people are in despair due to some people\'s inability to tame their tongues. As people who have professed faith in Christ Jesus, God expects us to demonstrate a high level of discipline regarding what we say and teach. James said those who consider themselves religious and yet do not keep a tight rein on their tongue deceive themselves and their religion is worthless (James 1:26). Although the tongue is about the smallest part of the body, we must understand how destructive it can be if not tamed.

THE LESSON EXPLAINED

  1. Warning against Hasty Desires James 3:1-2

    The opening of this chapter suggests that there were some people in the days of James who were eager to become teachers. This was so probably because in the Jewish setting a teacher occupied an important position of authority and influence, just like the scribes and rabbis. However, James made them know that not all of them should become teachers (v. 1) because those who teach will be judged more strictly. In like manner, regarding the religious leaders who took advantage of people, Jesus said that their punishment will be severe (Mark 12:40). According to James, we all make mistakes but those who never make any mistake in the use of their tongue can be regarded as perfect and they possess the ability to control their whole body. Nevertheless, we should not misunderstand James' counsel about becoming teachers of the Word of God. James wanted the would-be teachers to understand their responsibilities, especially regarding the use of their tongues and words in their teaching ministry. Therefore, those who desire to be teachers, according to James, should be able to control their tongues so that they can influence their class members positively.

    Teaching is so important that James did not exonerate himself. In verse 2 he said, "We all stumble in many ways. If anyone is never at fault in what he says, he is a perfect man, able to keep his whole body in check." James wanted his audience to know the power of the tongue as it has the ability to build and destroy. Therefore, as teachers of the Word of God, our lives should not be contrary to what we teach so that we will not be guilty like the scribes, according to Jesus' evaluation in Matthew 23:1-7. Teachers of the Word who have discovered their giftedness in the area of teaching should not be discouraged because of James\' warning in this passage. Instead, they should work hard so that what they teach will influence people positively and not contradict their lifestyles. Therefore, if you are gifted in teaching adults, youths, teenagers or children, simply make your interest known to your pastor and ask the Holy Spirit to help you to be an exemplary teacher with a disciplined faith.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. Why did James caution against being hasty to become a teacher?
    2. What are the things that can help teachers not to be guilty of what they teach, according to the lesson?
  2. The Power of the Tongue James 3:3-6

    As he continued his instruction about the importance of taming the tongue, especially as teachers of the Word, James gave a comprehensive description of the power of the tongue. He likened the tongue to small objects that are used to control big objects such as bits to control horses to make them obey and rudder to control ships to wherever the pilots want them to go. (vv. 3-4) In like manner, the tongue, though small, can boast about great things just as a large forest can be set on fire by a small spark. According to verse 6, the damage the tongue can cause is described in these terms:

    • It is a fire this means that it has the capability to consume and destroy lives.
    • A world of evil. It can corrupt the whole person. The Scripture says that the tongue has the power of life and death (Proverbs 18:21).
    • It can set the whole course of life on fire.
    • It is itself set on fire by hell.

    The tongue has the power to destroy just like a small spark of fire can set a large forest ablaze. Experience has shown that many churches have been divided because of some people who lack the power to control their tongues. Little wonder James said that the tongue with which we praise our Lord and Father is the same tongue with which we curse men, who have been made in God's likeness ... (vv 9-10). This of course is an indication that we are expected to use our tongues to praise, bless, encourage, edify, comfort, soothe and not to curse or destroy people. According to Apostle Paul in his letter to the church in Colossae, our words should be full of grace, and seasoned with salt (Colossians 4:6). He further said, "Do not let any unwholesome talk [word] come out of your mouths, but only what is helpful for building others up according to their needs, that it may benefit those who listen" (Ephesians 4:29). Believers should be careful about what they say. Before you speak, be conscious that words are like fire; you can neither control nor reverse the damage they have done, once spoken. The tongue has the ability to either build or tear down.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. Mention the sins people commit that do not involve the use of the tongue.
    2. "... and with it we curse men, who have been made in God's likeness." verse 39b. Discuss.
    3. Discuss some steps believers can take to control the way they use their tongues.
  3. Taming the Tongue James 3:7-12

    The ability of a man to tame his tongue is definitely a sign of a disciplined faith. James emphasised that all kinds of animals are being tamed and have been tamed by humankind but sadly, no one can tame the tongue. He, therefore, referred to it as a restless evil and full of deadly poison that can cause great damage to the entire body (vv. 7-8). He said that from the same mouth comes praise and curse, an attitude contrary to the will of God. He further compared an untamed tongue with a fig tree that cannot bear olives or a grapevine that cannot bear figs, even a salt spring that cannot produce fresh water (v. 12); they are different in nature.

    By our human nature, we lack the power to control our tongues but the good news, however, is that God through the Holy Spirit can help us to control what we say. The need to maintain a disciplined faith has placed a demand on believers to put their whole body in check so that we will not be seen as hypocrites who do not do what we say or teach. However, James sums it up when he said, “If anyone considers himself religious and yet does not keep a tight rein on his tongue, he deceives himself and his religion is worthless” (James 1:26).

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. Which one is easier for man to control, anger or the tongue?
    2. Let a class member share how he/she felt recently after he/she used his/her tongue in a bad way, and the lessons he/she learnt from that experience.

Prayer Points

  • Pray and ask God to help you to be self-controlled always.
  • Pray for all Sunday School teachers that God will give them the grace to be able to model what they teach.
  • Ask God to help you to use your tongue to build lives rather than destroy lives.

Fellowship and Ministry Building Activities

  • Role-play a scenario in which someone is tempted to use the tongue in a harmful way. Then let participants brainstorm positive alternatives such a person might use. Resume the role-play, showing how the tempted person can speak appropriately in this difficult situation.

Take Home

  • The tongue can cause ruin if it is wrongly used
  • Christians are expected to tame their tongues even when provoked.
  • Teachers of God's Word should know that their measure of judgment will be stricter.
  • God expects us to maintain a disciplined faith.

title: FAITHFUL DISCIPLES
message:
February 18, 2018

FAITHFUL DISCIPLES

Devotional Reading: 1 Peter 1:3-9; 4:7-11

Background Scripture / Lesson Scripture: Acts 9:36-43

Golden Text

Peter sent them all out of the room; then he got down on his knees and prayed. Turning toward the dead woman, he said, "Tabitha, get up." She opened her eyes, and seeing Peter she sat up. Acts 9:40

Objectives :

By the end of the lesson, class members should be able to:

  • Discuss the source of genuine miracles.
  • Explain the importance of miracles to the spread of the Gospel.
  • Express their resolve to develop strong faith in God.

INTRODUCTION

"Baba miracle" (alias "automatic answer"), as he was fondly called by his admirers, was a popular evangelist of his time. His ministry was identified with signs and wonders. At every crusade, many people would come from far and near not only to listen to his polished messages but to receive their own miracles. At intervals, some people would come out to testify of their healing miracles and by this, Baba miracle gained more popularity with many faithful disciples who were dedicated to his ministry. One day, it was discovered that those who gave testimonies of healing were actually paid to do so in order for Baba miracle to gain popularity and make more money. Within a very short while, the ministry ceased to exist because people discovered that it was fake.

However, the story in today's passage is quite different from the fake healing miracles associated with Baba miracle's ministry. The lesson centres on the faithful disciples at Joppa. After the death of Tabitha, also known as Dorcas, these elders had faith in God and believed that He could restore her back to life. Their faith was demonstrated when Peter, who was invited as an apostle of God, prayed and she was restored to life. The miracle of the restoration of life became known all over Joppa and many came to believe in God. In fact, the faith of these elders should challenge us today to believe in the God of all genuine miracles.

THE LESSON EXPLAINED

  1. A Generous and Faithful Disciple Act 9:36-38

    As a missionary, Peter travelled to various places to visit God\'s people including Lydda, where he miraculously healed a paralysed man that made many in the city turn to the Lord (vv. 32-35). While he was at Lydda, there was a woman in Joppa named Tabitha, (which when translated in Greek is Dorcas, meaning "a deer"). According to the passage, she was a disciple, woman of faith and a faithful follower of Christ who was always doing good and helping the poor. At that time, she became ill and died, and her body was washed according to the Jewish custom of purification of the dead and laid in an upstairs room. Interestingly, the disciples demonstrated their faith in __ God when they heard that Peter was in Lydda, they sent two men to him saying, "Please come at once!" (v. 38).

    There is no doubt that Tabitha was a generous woman, a good steward of God\'s resources. From the phrase 'always doing good', we can deduce that she used every opportunity she had to bless lives. She truly loved the Lord and other brethren not only in words but also in deed (1 John 3:17-18). Therefore, we can say that this woman of faith (Tabitha) fulfilled God's expectations for which she was created according to Ephesians 2:10. “For we are God's workmanship, created in Christ Jesus to do good works, which God prepared in advance for us to do.” Her life was an embodiment of generosity, which stresses the importance of a living faith. As Christians who know the importance of generosity, we should heed the counsel of Paul who said, "... let us do good to all people, especially to those who belong to the family of believers." (Galatians 6:10) By so doing, we shall prove that we are truly faithful disciples of Jesus.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. Is it practicable today to lend helping hands to as many people who solicit our help?
    2. How often should we help a particular needy person who seems to be lazy?
  2. The Miracle of Resurrection Acts 9:39-43

    Peter's response to the call of the faithful disciples is astonishing. According to verse 39, he went with the two men and was taken to the upstairs room where the body of Tabitha was laid. All the widows stood crying as they showed Peter proofs of her generosity __ all the shirts and coats Dorcas had made for them while she was alive. Certainly, Peter was moved with compassion thus, he prayed fervently, then turned toward her and said, "Tabitha, get up." The testimony is that God answered his prayer as Tabitha came back to life and was handed over to the believers and widows (v. 41). Interestingly, the news of this great miracle spread all over Joppa and many people believed in the Lord, which further stresses two important facts: the importance of miracles to the spread of the Gospel and the genuineness of miracles.

    As Christians, our little acts of kindness and generosity speak volume even in our times of difficulties. Rather than being selfish and hoarding your resources, share and impact the lives of others like Dorcas did. Faith is needed even in dead situations; we should have faith in our God and leaders/pastors whenever we invite them for prayers __ for with God, all things are possible. Just like the disciples who demonstrated strong faith, Christians need to pray and believe God for miracles that will make many to accept Jesus as their Saviour and Lord.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. Were the widows really crying because of the death of Tabitha or because there would be no more free clothing for them?
    2. Why did Peter send those who were crying away before he prayed?
    3. What do you think would have happened if the disciples at Joppa did not send for Peter?

Prayer Points

  • What do you think would have happened if the disciples at Joppa did not send for Peter?
  • Pray that God will bless His Church with the gift of miracles just like the early church.
  • Pray that God will help you to have an active and unwavering faith to trust Him for all things.

Fellowship and Ministry Building Activities

  • Let each class member write at least three lessons they wish to emulate from the disciples in Joppa
  • Identify someone in your church who is like Dorcas and write a letter of commendation appreciating his/her acts of benevolence.

Take Home

  • Generosity should be the hallmark of believers.
  • Christians must remember that we are blessed so that we can be blessings to others.
  • Genuine miracles are catalysts to the spread of the Gospel.
  • We serve a miracle-working God.

title: THE GOOD FIGHT OF FAITH
message:
February 25, 2018

THE GOOD FIGHT OF FAITH

Devotional Reading: 1 Thessalonians 2:17 3:10

Background Scripture / Lesson Scripture: 1 Timothy 6:11-21

Golden Text

Fight the good fight of the faith. Take hold of the eternal life to which you were called when you made your good confession in the presence of many witnesses. 1 Timothy 6:12

Objectives :

By the end of the lesson, class members should be able to:

  • Explain what it means to fight the good fight of faith.
  • State why Christians should put their trust in God.
  • State why Christians should put their trust in God.

INTRODUCTION

Sometime ago, I had the opportunity of listening to the testimony of a young man who had made success in the ministry. He graduated from one of the popular Nigerian universities with a brilliant result. After his National Youth Service Corps, he sensed God calling him into full-time ministry. Consequently, because of his passion and desire to succeed as a pastor, he sought the help of one of the most respected senior pastors in his Association to be his mentor. Having been trained as a Baptist pastor, he continued in his relationship with his mentor who was devoted to helping him succeed in the ministry, especially after he had been called by a church. From time to time, the senior pastor encouraged and admonished him when necessary and sometimes, shared practical examples of how to become successful in the ministry. He was particularly warned against the love for money, women and power. To the glory of God, after serving the church for a period of ten years, he was appreciated by his church as one of the most disciplined pastors in the Association. Interestingly, the young pastor publicly gave the credit to the senior pastor who had mentored him from the beginning.

The relationship between the young pastor and his mentor is similar to that of Timothy and Paul. Timothy was a young Christian from Asia Minor. He had a Jewish mother and a Greek father (Acts 16:1). He became a companion and an assistant to Paul, who mentored him. Paul did not leave young Timothy to struggle on his own in the ministry; he mentored him and constantly gave him instructions about church administration and worship with a description of the kind of character that church leaders should possess. Today's lesson focuses on Paul's final instruction to young Timothy, his son in the Lord, to fight the good fight of faith as a good servant of Jesus Christ. However, Paul's instructions to Timothy are also relevant to believers today, especially as we continue to fight the good fight of faith.

THE LESSON EXPLAINED

  1. The Command to Fight the Good Fight 1 Timothy 6:11-16

    Paul's labour over his spiritual son, Timothy, was all-inclusive. Previously, Paul had warned and instructed Timothy to run away from false doctrines, quarrels, controversies, the love of money, envy and malicious talks for fear of wandering away from the faith (vv. 3-10). Thereafter, he admonished him to pursue godly virtues like righteousness, godliness, faith, love, endurance and gentleness (v. 11). In fact, the charge to pursue means to put in his best to possess these qualities. Furthermore, he was instructed to do his best in the race of faith and attain the eternal life to which he was called when he first confessed Jesus in the presence of many witnesses. Without doubt, Paul's desire was that Timothy should hold fast to his faith and keep the commands faithfully until the day our Lord Jesus will appear (v. 14).

    As Christians, we are called and charged to defend the truth of the Gospel and fight against those things that contend with our faith. As we fight the good fight of faith, we must keep the faith by knowing Christ personally and making Him known, obeying Him and doing what we know is right, keeping His commandment until the baton of faith is passed on to the next generation, and living day by day without spot or blemish until Christ appears.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. In view of the present reality, how easy is it for Christians to pursue righteousness, whether as students, government officials, business men/women, artisans, etc.?
    2. Discuss “Prosperity Gospel” in the light of Paul's warning to Timothy.
  2. Command to the Rich 1 Timothy 6:17-21

    As a young man in the ministry, Paul did not relent in his effort to instruct Timothy in the way he should go. Having commanded him to fight the good fight of faith, he also gave him additional instructions about the rich. Specifically, he was commanded to guide the rich so that they will not:

    • Be arrogant. In other words, they should not be conceited because of the abundant resources at their disposal, as it is the habit of some believers today who are proud and arrogant.
    • Put their hope in their riches but in God who richly provides everything for their comfort (v. 17). But they should:
    • Do good and be rich in good deeds.
    • Be generous and willing to share their resources with others

    According to verse 19, this is the only way they can store up treasures for __ themselves, a sign of solid foundation for their future. More importantly, Timothy was to guard what has been entrusted to his care, which some have interpreted to be Christian truth (2 Timothy 2:2). Finally, Paul admonished Timothy to turn away from godless chatter and opposing ideas, falsely called knowledge. The admonition became necessary because of those who had wandered from the faith. Experience has shown that arrogance is a common tendency among the rich, but those who have truly accepted Jesus as their Saviour and Lord and whose hearts have been circumcised should use their riches for good deeds so that they can store up eternal treasures for themselves (v. 19). We must be generous by sharing our resources with those who are in need. The rich must not put their hope and trust in their money but in the living God. No matter how poor we are, we must have something to share with someone.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. Why do you think these instructions were necessary for Timothy?
    2. Mention some of the false teachings that are prevalent in our time and how to overcome them.
    3. What does it mean to be rich in the sight of God?

Prayer Points

  • Lord, help me to finish strong in this journey of faith.
  • Ask the Lord to give you grace so that you will not be consumed by the love of money in this end time.
  • Pray against every spirit of arrogance and pride because it destroys.

Fellowship and Ministry Building Activities

  • Let class members brainstorm on some of the reasons why some rich people are arrogant and how a believer can be free from this tendency

Take Home

  • Be always ready to contend for your faith.
  • Do not place too much value on earthly riches.
  • Christians should strive to live godly lives at all times.
  • Do not put your trust in your riches.

title: A TEST OF TRUTH
message:
March 4, 2018

A TEST OF TRUTH

Devotional Reading: Psalm 20

Background Scripture: Genesis 22

Lesson Scripture: Genesis 22:1-2, 6-14

Golden Text

Abraham answered, "God himself will provide the lamb for the burnt offering, my son." And the two of them went on together. Genesis 22:8

Objectives :

By the end of the lesson, class members should be able to:

  • Discuss why God tested Abraham by asking him to sacrifice his son, Isaac.
  • Identify the source of Abraham\'s motivation to really sacrifice his son.
  • Discuss the importance of total obedience to God and His command in respect of today's lesson.

INTRODUCTION

A story was once told of a pastor who was privileged to pastor one of the biggest churches in his Conference. He was very comfortable and well loved by his members. But all of a sudden he resigned and decided to relocate to a lepers’ colony in one of the towns in the South West, as a pastor. Despite all efforts by his wife, children, friends, family and church members to dissuade him from making such a risky decision, he remained adamant, even though he knew the consequences of his decision. When some concerned members of the church asked him the reason for his decision, he simply said, "God has spoken, his servant must obey." His slogan was, "If Christ loves sinners, we should also love others irrespective of their status." Ultimately, people testified to his faithful and sincere service to the lepers in the colony for some years. Invariably, we can say that the pastor passed the test of truth even though he died as a leper.

Sometimes, God tests His people to ascertain their commitment and level of obedience to Him, like the case of Abraham. Our lesson today is about how God tested the faith of Abraham by asking him to sacrifice his beloved son in order to determine his level of obedience to Him. Abraham, on his part, passed the test. He did __ not mind the bond between him and his son, Isaac the promised seed. Little wonder he became the father of faith.

THE LESSON EXPLAINED

  1. Abraham's Supreme Test Genesis 22:1-2

    The relationship between God and Abraham had been cordial since he was called to leave his father's land for the land He (God) would show him. The command was with a promise to make him into a great nation, to bless and give him the Promised Land (Genesis 12:1-7). The promise was eventually fulfilled in chapter 21 when Isaac was born to Abraham in his old age. However, God later tested his loyalty to Him. He said, "Take your son, your only son, Isaac, whom you love, and go to the region of Moriah. Sacrifice him there as a burnt offering on one of the mountains I will tell you about." (v. 2) The expression "... your only son, Isaac, whom you love, ..." connotes a sense of the uniqueness of the child, Isaac, who was born out of promise.

    God's instruction to Abraham was clear and distinct. The object of the sacrifice was Isaac, not Ishmael or any of his servants. Truly, Abraham's experience was a serious test because God had promised that his descendants would come through Isaac (Genesis 21:12b). Interestingly, his response was amazing as he was ready to carry out the task without hesitation (vv. 3-8). Abraham did not question God, or suggest an alternative, which reveals the depth of his faith and total loyalty to God. Immediately he received the message, he set out to do just what God instructed him to do. We can, therefore, say that God still tests His people to determine the extent of their love and faith in Him. Those who faithfully undergo such tests are greatly rewarded and will serve as examples to other believers, like Abraham.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. Discuss some of the ways God tests His people today and how to pass such tests.
    2. What are the likely consequences of disobeying God's commands? Give some biblical examples.
  2. A Journey of Faith Genesis 22:6-12

    Earlier in chapter 15, God appeared to Abraham in a vision and promised to make his offspring as numerous as the stars. According to verse 6, he believed God and it was credited to him as righteousness. His assignment of sacrificing his only beloved son, Isaac, was a difficult one but as a man of faith, he embarked on the journey without hesitation. While he made Isaac to carry the wood, he himself carried the other elements for the burnt offering. As they walked towards the mountain, Isaac became curious and asked his father “... where is the lamb for the burnt offering? (v. 7b) Abraham's mature response revealed the depth of his trust and faith in God. He said, 'God himself will provide the lamb for the burnt offering ....' The climax of the experience was that having built an altar, Abraham bound Isaac, laid him on it and reached out for a knife and wanted to kill him but God spoke through an angel who halted the action saying to him, "Do not lay a hand on the boy,"... "Do not do anything to him ..." (v. 12). Of course, God was pleased and testified of Abraham's unreserved loyalty to Him.

    Certainly, the journey of Abraham and his son, Isaac, was faith-based. According to his confession in verse 8, God truly provided an alternative (a lamb) for the burnt offering instead of Isaac. At last, Abraham obtained an attestation from heaven of the genuineness of his faith with a revelation of God's ability to always meet our needs. Therefore, his faith was made complete by what he did __ he obeyed God without hesitating. James cited the action of Abraham to prove that faith is shown by means of appropriate actions (James 2:21). Consequently, God can always meet our needs in ways that are quite unusual when we trust and obey His instructions. Therefore, believers should be willing to demonstrate their faith in God, no matter how difficult it may seem.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. What do you think would be the attitude of Isaac to his father after the whole episode?
    2. Discuss some of the ways Christians can demonstrate their total obedience to God without counting the cost.
  3. God's Divine Provision Genesis 22:13-14

    Our God specialises in making provisions for His people beyond their comprehension. Having been instructed by God not to harm Isaac, because of the demonstration of his faith, God provided a substitute. When Abraham looked up, he saw a ram caught by its horns, which eventually served as an object for the burnt offering instead of his son, Isaac. Certainly, Abraham was astonished by the divine provision thus he called the place 'The LORD Will Provide' and to this day, people still say, "On the mountain of the Lord, it will be provided." So, the ram was sacrificed in place of Isaac just like Jesus Christ who gave His life as a ransom for the remission of the sins of humankind (Mark 10:45). Our God does not undermine our sacrificial services to Him. Whenever we attempt great things for Him without reservation, we can be sure that we will be greatly rewarded.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. Throughout the passage, nothing is said about Sarah. What would you have done if you were Sarah, after the whole episode?
    2. Let at least two class members share how their needs were met recently and how they responded to God.

Prayer Points

  • Pray and ask God for the grace to remain faithful to Him, no matter how difficult it may seem.
  • Pray that you will not disappoint God by failing His test.
  • Pray for believers who are struggling with life's challenges that they will not also disappoint God.

Fellowship and Ministry Building Activities

  • Divide the class into two groups. Let group A discuss the benefits of observing God's command and group B the consequences of disobeying His command. They should pray for one another for grace to obey God's command always.

Take Home

  • It pays to obey God, no matter the task.
  • God still rewards faithful services.
  • Christians should be ready to give their best to God.
  • We should have faith in God like Abraham.

title: PROMISES KEPT
message:
March 11, 2018

PROMISES KEPT

Devotional Reading: Psalm 132

Background Scripture: 2 Chronicles 6:1-21

Lesson Scripture: 2 Chronicles 6:12-21

Golden Text

You have kept your promise to your servant David my father; with your mouth you have promised and with your hand you have fulfilled it __ as it is today. 2 Chronicles 6:15

Objectives :

By the end of the lesson, class members should be able to:

  • Differentiate between human and divine promises.
  • State some attributes of God as far as making promises is concerned.
  • Explain what it means to celebrate spiritual landmarks, especially when God has fulfilled His promise.

INTRODUCTION

The society we live in is characterised by deceit; people no longer keep their promises. Politicians are known to be good in making promises, especially during their electoral campaign. It is common to hear some of them promise free education at all levels while others promise to provide good roads and other social amenities for the comfort of the electorate. Sometime ago, a particular gubernatorial candidate promised to give employment to all the youths in the community if only he is voted into office. But immediately he assumed office, he forgot all his promises and became inaccessible __ without giving a thought to any of his promises to the people. There are also cases of some Christian spouses who failed to keep their marital vows to their partners.

However, the promises of God are always sure, dependable, eternal and from generation to generation. Our lesson today centres on the fulfilment of God's promises to David and Israel, by extension, as witnessed by Solomon. After the building and furnishing of the temple was completed and the ark of the Lord was brought in, Solomon dedicated the temple to the Lord. He prayed and appreciated God for keeping the promise He made to his father, David.

THE LESSON EXPLAINED

  1. Solomon Worshipped God for Promises Fulfilled 2 Chronicles 6:12-15

    Solomon began to build the temple of the Lord in Jerusalem on Mount Moriah, where the Lord had appeared to his father David. He also furnished it greatly (chapters 3, 4). From verse 1 of the chapter, he expressed gratitude to God for fulfilling His promises. He prayed and praised God before the whole assembly for keeping His covenant of love with His servants who continued whole-heartedly in His ways. He also praised God for keeping and fulfilling His promise to David, his father (v. 15). In an atmosphere of worship, Solomon did the following:

    • He stood on a brazen scaffold, which was made for that purpose, so that everyone could see and hear him.
    • He knelt down before God on the platform in total submission and humble adoration, in the presence of the congregation.
    • He knelt down before God on the platform in total submission and humble adoration, in the presence of the congregation.
    • He described God as One without equal who keeps His covenant with those who walk blamelessly before Him.

    One attribute that distinguishes God from humankind is that He is always faithful to His promises (2 Peter 3:3). David\'s initial plan to build a magnificent temple for the Lord was against the will of God; rather, his offspring would build the temple (2 Samuel 7:13). The completion of the temple necessitated the praise and prayer before the whole assembly for the fulfilment of God's promise to David. This implies that the promises of God are often connected with the faithfulness of His people. The most important lesson from this passage is that God is always faithful to His promises. Therefore, whenever God fulfils His promises concerning us, we should learn to show appreciation to Him in songs, prayers and meditation. 

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. How can we relay the testimonies of God's blessings and the fulfilment of His promises to our children so that the culture of gratitude can be transferred?
    2. Discuss some consequences of not fulfilling one's promises.
  2. Solomon's Sincere Petition 2 Chronicles 6:16-21

    Solomon continued in his prayer with petitions as he appealed to God to keep the promise He made to his father, David. His request was that God should continually raise offspring to succeed David and to establish his kingdom forever (2 Samuel 7:12; 2 Chronicles 6:16-17). He also affirmed that God does not live on earth among men neither does the heaven and the highest heavens contain Him much less the temple, which he has built (v. 18). In his letter to King Hiram of Tyre, Solomon also expressed this same praise to God (2 Chronicles 2:6). He passionately appealed to God to:

    • Give attention to his prayer and appeal for the sake of His mercy
    • Make His eyes (presence) to be on the temple day and night where He had promised to put His Name.
    • Answer the prayers of His people, which they pray toward the temple.
    • Hear the prayer of His people, Israel, from heaven and forgive their sins.

    Solomon was sincere in his prayer with the assurance that God will answer the requests and supplications of His people, which they make in the temple. It is important to note that the first request made by Solomon is the preservation of the throne, the prosperity of his people and that of the royal lineage. This is important because the royal palace plays an important role in the religious life of the people. More so, He requested for God's continual presence and attendance to the people's supplications. It is worth mentioning that Solomon's style of prayer is quite remarkable unlike some believers' style today whose prayers are self-centred and self-seeking. Solomon demonstrated humility and passionately pleaded with God to hear their prayers based on His mercy. Solomon repeatedly reminded God of His promise to his father, David, to establish his throne forever.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. What was the significance of the temple to the people of Israel?
    2. Analyse the prayer of Solomon and discuss where it differs from the type of prayer some believers pray today.

Prayer Points

  • Help me, O Lord, to always keep my promise of walking in Your will and ways.
  • Give me a grateful heart to recognise and celebrate Your fulfilled promise.
  • May Your promises for me and my family come to pass, in Jesus' Name.

Fellowship and Ministry Building Activities

  • Let class members mention some attributes of Solomon they wish to emulate.

Take Home

  • God is ever faithful to His promises
  • Christians should learn to keep their promises, whether to God or humankind.
  • Whenever we pray from a sincere heart, He hears us.
  • God does not dwell in houses made by humankind.
