title: THE PEOPLE GAVE THANKS TO GOD
message:
March 18, 2018

THE PEOPLE GAVE THANKS TO GOD

Devotional Reading: Psalm 138

Background Scripture: 2 Chronicles 7:1-11

Lesson Scripture: 2 Chronicles 7:1-9

Golden Text

When all the Israelites saw the fire coming down and the glory of the LORD above the temple, they knelt on the pavement with their faces to the ground, and they worshipped and gave thanks to the LORD, saying, "He is good; his love endures forever." 2 Chronicles 7:3

Objectives :

By the end of the lesson, class members should be able to:

  • Identify various ways God reveals Himself to His people.
  • Discuss how Christians can show gratitude to God for the manifestation of His power.
  • Recognise divine landmarks and celebrate God's faithfulness.

INTRODUCTION

Recently, God's Grace Baptist Church, Uguma, made history. It was a week of commemoration for the members having successfully completed the reconstruction of the church auditorium, which was burnt down when members of the Boko Haram sect attacked the community. The week was marked by different activities like Bible study, quiz and games, marriage seminar, testimonies, stewardship lectures, etc. The climax of the celebration was the appreciation service for the pasor for his resilience and hard work over the years. The entire members of the church and other invited guests were excited as they sang praises to God, danced, prayed and finally gave thanks to God for His provision and faithfulness.

Usually, people rejoice and are filled with gratitude to God when a promise is fulfilled, especially when they have directly benefitted from such a promise. Such was the case of Solomon and the people of Israel who gathered together to dedicate the temple built in honour of God; and offered sacrifices to Him. It was seven days of festivity; on the eight day, there was a solemn meeting before they all dispersed. The ceremony was a spiritual landmark in the history of the people of Israel. Particularly, God agreed to honour all of Solomon's request but with the condition that the people must demonstrate complete obedience in their relationship with Him.

THE LESSON EXPLAINED

  1. God's Glorious Manifestation 2 Chronicles 7:1-3

    Solomon's prayer was a long one (6:14-42). Precisely in verse 42, he made an appeal to God to remember the love He promised His servant David. The aftermath of his prayer was the glorious manifestation of God's presence when fire came down from heaven and consumed the burnt offerings and the sacrifices. Consequently, the temple was filled with the glory of the Lord and the priests were prevented from entering into the temple. Of course, it was evidence that Solomon's prayers had been answered. Ultimately, the people of Israel were amazed as they witnessed the coming down of fire and the glory of God above the temple. Their response was awesome. They fell down on the pavement and worshipped God saying, "He is good; his love endures forever" (v. 3). In like manner, fire came out from the presence of God and consumed Aaron's sacrifices at the Tent of Meeting and all the people shouted for joy and bowed down in worship (Leviticus 9:23-24).

    God responds to His people in different ways. For instance, He revealed Himself to Moses through the burning bush (Genesis 3:3-6) and to Saul through a light from heaven (Acts 9:3-5). But in this passage, the manifestation of God's glory in the temple reveals that:

    • God is glorious; for He is a consuming fire.
    • God is gracious to Israel.
    • Their prayers had been answered.

    The people also responded accordingly to the manifestation of God's presence as they worshipped and praised Him with sincere hearts (v. 3). They bowed their faces to the groun,d acknowledged God's mercy and worshipped with cheerful submission to the divine authority. This attitude should remind us of the need to constantly remember that God is good; therefore, we should always offer Him thanksgiving, especially when He chooses to manifest His power and glory in our midst.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. Let class members discuss various ways they have experienced the manifestation of God's power in the last three months and how it has affected their relationship with Him
    2. Discuss some other ways Christians can show gratitude to God for the manifestation of His power on daily basis.
    3. Discuss ways class members can be thankful to God
  2. The Temple Dedication 2 Chronicles 7:4-9

    The response of the people to the glorious manifestation of God was so overwhelming that Solomon offered sacrifices of twenty-two thousand head of cattle and a hundred and twenty thousand sheep and goats to the Lord. The temple was dedicated. The priests and Levites played active parts in the dedication service with the Lord's musical instruments, which David had made. They blew their trumpets, praised the Lord and gave thanks saying, "His love endures forever" (v. 6). Having consecrated the middle part of the temple, Solomon offered sacrifices of fellowship offerings. The festival which attracted a great number of people from Lebo Hamath to the Wadi of Egypt lasted seven days.

    To dedicate something is the same as to devote or set it aside for the purpose of God. Therefore, it is clear from the passage that Solomon and the people of Israel understood the concept and duly demonstrated complete obedience to God in the construction and dedication of the temple. Little wonder God's presence and power was made manifest and the people responded in praise and thanksgiving to God. Christians often dedicate their possessions like cars, houses, children and other material possessions to God without actually releasing such things for the use of God. Based on today's lesson, Christians should cultivate the habit of dedicating their possessions for God's use considering the fact that He is the owner of everything while we are the caretakers.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. Discuss the significance of the seven days which the festival lasted.
    2. What was the reason for the consecration of the temple by Solomon?

Prayer Points

  • O Lord our God, give me a thankful heart that I may recognise and appreciate You appropriately for Your uncountable blessings.
  • Lord, reveal Your glory to Your people again
  • Teach me, Lord, to always sing songs of thanksgiving, no matter the challenges of life

Fellowship and Ministry Building Activities

  • Compare and contrast the worship in this passage with the worship in churches today.
  • List the different ways we can learn to worship God with our whole hearts and continue to pray for grace to improve

Take Home

  • Christians should recognise the fact that God deserves our praise and worship
  • Believers should set aside time for regular communal worship like the people of Israel.
  • Following God's instructions can be rewarding.
  • We should cultivate the habit of dedicating our possessions and lives to God.

title: KEEP MY STATUTES AND ORDINANCES
message:
March 25, 2018

KEEP MY STATUTES AND ORDINANCES

Devotional Reading: Isaiah 58:6-12

Background Scripture / Lesson Scripture: 2 Chronicles 7:12-22

Golden Text

If my people, who are called by my name, will humble themselves and pray and seek my face and turn from their wicked ways, then will I hear from heaven and will forgive their sin and will heal their land. 2 Chronicles 7:14

Objectives :

By the end of the lesson, class members should be able to:

  • Discuss how disobedience to God can result in divine punishment.
  • State some reasons why people find it difficult to abide by rules established by those in positions of authority.
  • Discuss the benefits of total obedience to God in relation to the lesson.

INTRODUCTION

Mr Akpan John graduated from one of the universities in Nigeria with a first class. After his National Youth Service Corps, he was immediately recruited to be trained for a period of two years at the Nigerian Defence Academy, as it has always been his desire. Interestingly, while some of the students were disqualified during training as a result of misconducts, Mr John displayed an exemplary character.

Eventually, he graduated as the best student with several awards from the institution. When interviewed about the secret of his success, he linked it to determination, hard work, disciplined lifestyle and most importantly, complete obedience to constituted authority.

The importance of abiding by the rules and regulations established by those in positions of authority cannot be overemphasised. The fact has been established that God fulfilled His promise to Solomon and helped him to build the temple, which was dedicated amidst celebration, thanksgiving and burnt offerings. Furthermore, it was an opportunity for the people to celebrate the Festival of Shelters for seven days in remembrance of God's blessings. The lesson of today is a reminder that God's blessing upon His people Israel was with a condition their willingness to keep His statues and ordinances and to serve Him faithfully.

THE LESSON EXPLAINED

  1. God Appears to Solomon 2 Chronicles 7:12-16

    After Solomon had finished the construction of the Lord's Temple, the palace and all he had planned to do, the Lord appeared to him at night. This is the second time God appeared to Solomon. The first was when he prayed for wisdom (2 Chronicles 1:1-13). God said to him, "I have heard your prayer and have chosen this place for myself as a temple for sacrifice." (v. 12) God told Solomon that even though He shuts the heaven so that there is no rain, or commands the locusts to devour or sends a pestilence to the land, there is hope for His people. However, it was with a condition that the people must humble themselves before Him, pray, seek His face and turn from their wicked ways (v. 14). In addition, God promised to watch over the Temple and answer their prayers. The reason is that the Temple had been specially chosen and consecrated as a designated place for His worship. Therefore, He will protect it forever (v. 16). God's answer in these verses matches the characteristics of Solomon's earlier prayer of dedication that God would consecrate the Temple, receive the people's worship, and preserve Israel from calamity.

    By implication, just as disobedience to God brings about punishment; so total obedience leads to prosperity, deliverance and various blessings. God's repeated appearance to Solomon suggests that believers need fresh manifestations of God. It should also be noted that the willingness of the people to confess their wickedness and forsake them was a condition for receiving God's forgiveness. This further portrays the fact that the prayer of a sinner is an abomination to God but when we walk humbly with Him, He hears and blesses us.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. Does God forgive sins without confession?
    2. Discuss what would have become of the people of Israel and their leaders if they had not confessed their sins.
  2. A Call to Total Obedience 2 Chronicles 7:17-22

    God does not change His standard, no matter who is involved. As He conversed with Solomon, He categorically stated in verse 17 that if Solomon will serve Him faithfully, do everything He has commanded and observe all the decrees and laws as He has covenanted with his father David, He will establish his royal throne forever. Nevertheless, if he, disobeys and forsakes the decrees, laws and commands and worships other gods, then He will uproot Israel from the land which He has given to them and reject the temple which He had consecrated for His holy Name. The implication of God's statement is that other nations will make mockery of them and ask, "Why has the Lord done such a thing to this land and to this temple?" (v. 21). The response would be that they disobeyed God who had brought them out of Egypt, and served other gods.

    It is obvious from the passage that God is a jealous God. He has constantly called His people to demonstrate complete obedience to Him and His laws. Unfortunately, people find it difficult to obey the rules and regulations of God and constituted authorities without minding the consequences. While some people feel they are above the law probably because they are highly placed, others may be ignorant of the consequence of such an act. Israel’s relationship with God was not steady in spite of God’s warnings against disloyalty and idolatry. They remained defiant thus they were captured and taken to exile in Babylon for a period of seventy years.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. What does idolatry mean in our contemporary time
    2. If God is to address the sins of our country Nigeria, what do you think He will focus on

Prayer Points

  • O Lord, my God, give me a new heart to obey Your laws and ordinances
  • Bring to pass all Your promises for me and my generation.
  • Pray that God's blessings for you will not elude you.

Fellowship and Ministry Building Activities

  • From verses 14, list the things God\'s people are called to do and the things God promised to do in return.
  • Let class members pray for one another for the forgiveness of sins.

Take Home

  • Disobedience to God can result to punishment in any form.
  • God is always ready to forgive those who forsake their sinful ways and turn to Him.
  • God does not tolerate sin, no matter how small it may be.
  • God demands our faithful service to Him.

title: HE HAS RISEN
message:
April 1, 2018

HE HAS RISEN

Devotional Reading: Luke 24:36-49

Background Scripture: Luke 24:1-35

Lesson Scripture: Luke 24:1-12, 30-35

Golden Text

And saying, "It is true! The Lord has risen and has appeared to Simon.” Luke 24:34

Objectives :

By the end of the lesson, class members should be able to:

  • List pieces of evidence of the resurrection of Jesus Christ.
  • State at least three benefits of Jesus' resurrection.
  • Mention two ways they will witness to someone about the resurrected Lord, this week.

INTRODUCTION

It was another Baptist Student Fellowship (BSF) Week and, as it was their practice, all the students went out on a one-to-one evangelism within the community. In his attempt to present the gospel message to a group of students, Brother Michael explained the death and resurrection of Jesus Christ to them. One of the boys, a Muslim fanatic, bombarded him with many questions about the possibility of the resurrection of Jesus Christ. Although Brother Michael made frantic efforts to convince him based on the Scriptures, the young Muslim disagreed, with the excuse that no one in the history of the world has ever died and resurrected as professed by Christians. For Brother Michael to successfully convince the young Muslim, with the help of the Holy Spirit, he needed to clearly give the proofs of Christ's resurrection from the Bible. This is part of what today's lesson will help us to understand.

The latter part of Luke chapter 23 records the events of Jesus' crucifixion, death and burial. But the climax of the account in chapter 24 deals with the resurrection of Jesus Christ and His appearances to His disciples on their way to Emmaus and when they were at the table. The centrality of the Gospel is the fact that God raised His Son, Jesus Christ, from the dead. It is indeed the highest earthly manifestation of the glory of God because the disciples themselves did not seem to understand how the resurrection will occur despite the fact that Jesus had repeatedly told them He would rise again on the third day (Matthew 16:21). Today's lesson focuses on the reality that Jesus Christ resurrected on the third day and lives forever. We may have heard of people who died and were brought back to life, but the difference is that they died again. Therefore, the resurrection of Christ Jesus is the foundation and essence of the Christian faith.

THE LESSON EXPLAINED

  1. The Declaration of Jesus' Resurrection Luke 24:1-8

    The resurrection of Jesus Christ, as declared by an angel, is one of the mysteries in human history. According to the account of Matthew, after the burial of Jesus, Pilate made sure the tomb was secured, put a seal on the stone and assigned some guards to keep watch over it (Matthew 27:65-66). That notwithstanding, on the first day of the week, very early in the morning after the Jewish Sabbath, some women set out with spices they had prepared purposely to anoint Jesus' body as it was their tradition (Luke 24:1). When they got to the tomb, the stone had been rolled away and when they entered, they did not find the body of Jesus. To their amazement, while they were still standing and looking, probably thinking of what to do, two men in shinning clothes appeared and stood beside them. Apparently, the women recognised them as supernatural beings, thus, they bowed down in reverence with their faces downward. The men declared Jesus' resurrection saying, "Why do you look for the living among the dead? He is not here; he has risen!" The angelic beings reminded them of Jesus' words while in Galilee that, "The Son of Man must be delivered into the hands of sinful men, be crucified and on the third day be raised again" (v. 7). Then the women remembered what Jesus had told them about His resurrection. The women's commitment was part of what led them to discover the different proofs of Christ's resurrection, which include the stone that had been rolled away; the absence of Christ's body in the tomb; and the angels who appeared to them. This gave them the opportunity to hear from the angels exactly what had happened and were reminded of Christ's word.

    The commitment of the women is commendable and worthy of emulation. Of course, they were aware of the security put in place by Pilate (the seal at the entrance of the tomb and the security guards who were placed there to watch over the body), yet they prepared spices and courageously went to Jesus' tomb to anoint His body. They were determined to fulfil their mission and show love to Jesus even after His death. Although no one saw Jesus physically as He arose from the dead, the discovery of the empty tomb and His appearances to His disciples at different times are proofs of His resurrection. Therefore, because Jesus resurrected from the dead, believers have reasons to believe in Him as well as have the hope of resurrection. Consequently, we do not have to depend on some supposed myths to ascertain whether or not Christ rose from the dead. Rather, we should ask ourselves the following questions: How committed am I to my Saviour? What mysteries about my faith in Christ have my commitment enabled me to solve? It is through our commitments as Christians that we can discover hidden truths that we could use to convince our neighbours that truly Christ died and resurrected and grant salvation and life after death to those who believe in Him.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. What motivated the women to go to the tomb of Jesus Christ very early in the morning without minding the dangers in doing so?
    2. Discuss the two ways the resurrection of Jesus Christ is significant to Christians. 1 Corinthians 15:12-20
    3. What are the proofs of Christ's resurrection found in today's Scripture?
  2. The Apostles' Disbelief Luke 24:9-12

    The fact has been established that Jesus had predicted His death and resurrection (Luke 18:31-33), even though it seemed His disciples did not fully understand what He meant. When the women (Mary Magdalene, Joanna and Mary, the mother of James and the others with them) returned from the tomb without finding Jesus' body, they reported everything to the apostles. Unfortunately, the apostles doubted the story; they counted it as mere idle tales, because they had forgotten Jesus' words about His death and resurrection, like the women. However, out of curiosity, Peter ran to the tomb to see for himself. On arrival, he saw the strips of linen lying by themselves and went away pondering on what would have happened to the body of Jesus (v. 12).

    The story of the death and resurrection of Jesus is still a mystery to many, especially unbelievers because such has never happened in the history of the world. Therefore, unbelievers often ask questions about the possibility. Even Jesus' disciples who were with their Master for some time and heard His predictions about the event doubted the possibility and Peter, out of curiosity, ran to the tomb to confirm it. He was surprised that Jesus was no longer in the grave __ He had risen. Eventually, they all remembered what the Scripture and Jesus had said: He would die and rise again. The reality of the death and resurrection of Jesus is enough proof that He is faithful to His words, therefore, believers should not doubt His promises.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. Why did the disciples doubt the testimony of Jesus' resurrection as told by the women?
    2. Some Christians easily believe in people rather than God. Why do you think this is so?
  3. Jesus' First Appearance Luke 24:30-35

    One evidence of Jesus' resurrection is that He appeared to His disciples at different occasions. First, He appeared to two of His disciples (Cleopas and another) on their way to Emmaus and later to others (vv. 13-16, 36). Because it was getting dark, Jesus agreed to stay with the two disciples and He sat down to eat with them. He took bread, gave thanks, broke it and gave it to them. Immediately, their eyes were opened and they recognised Him as Jesus but He disappeared from their sight. According to verse 32, they wondered and said to each other, "Were not our hearts burning within us while he talked with us on the road and opened the Scriptures to us?" Perhaps out of bewilderment, they returned immediately to Jerusalem and found the disciples and other people with them saying, "It is true! The Lord had risen and has appeared to Simon." The conviction and confession made by the eleven disciples about the risen Lord prompted the two to share what had happened on their way and how they had recognised Jesus when He broke bread (v. 35).

    It should be noted that Jesus' appearances to His disciples has two significant implications: it acknowledged the fact that they serve the risen Lord that works according to His promises. Secondly, it alleviated their fears, worries and doubts about Jesus. Consequently, the disciples were no longer overwhelmed by fear, impossibilities, dangers, enemies, or death, the moment they were assured of the fulfilment of God's promise(s). Like the two disciples on the way to Emmaus, are we should be interested in strengthening other believers. Such a testimony goes a long way to encourage and empower others.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. Why did the disciples not recognise Jesus immediately?
    2. Mention two ways you can convince an unbeliever that Jesus actually arose and He is alive?
    3. What would have been the fate of believers if Jesus did not resurrect?

Prayer Points

  • Thank God for the resurrection of Jesus Christ.
  • Pray that the power of resurrection will rest upon you, in Jesus\' Name.
  • Ask God to give you grace to preach 'the risen Lord'.

Fellowship and Ministry Building Activities

  • Work with the evangelism committee of your church and plan a crusade this Easter season so that more people can have faith in the resurrected Christ.

Take Home

  • The resurrection of Jesus Christ is real.
  • The resurrection of Jesus forms the basis of Christian hope of salvation.
  • Death has been conquered as a result of the resurrection of Jesus.
  • Tell others about the resurrection of Jesus.

title: THE RISEN LORD APPEARS
message:
April 8, 2018

THE RISEN LORD APPEARS

Devotional Reading: Psalm 19:7-10; 119:105-112

Background Scripture / Lesson Scripture: John 21:1-14

Golden Text

Jesus said to them, "Come and have breakfast." None of the disciples dared ask him, "Who are you?" They knew it was the Lord. John 21:12

Objectives :

By the end of the lesson, class members should be able to:

  • State some reasons the disciples went back to their fishing profession.
  • Discuss the importance of Jesus' appearances to His disciples.

INTRODUCTION

Lucky has always worn dreadlocks since I knew him. One day, while on mid-semester break, I saw that he has had his hair cut. When school resumed, I was asking one of my roommates if anyone had seen Lucky. To my amazement, the person I was talking to was Lucky himself. I could not easily recognise him because I least expected him to cut his hair. He looked strange, even though he was not a stranger. His new haircut brought out his facial features in a way I have never noticed before. I was taken aback. I just kept starring at him. Possibly the disciples' experience was similar to this when they saw Jesus.

THE LESSON EXPLAINED

  1. An Unexpected Appearance/Visit John 21:1-8

    After the resurrection of Jesus, the disciples returned to Galilee, as Jesus had instructed them to do (Matthew 28:7; Mark 16:7). Obviously, Jesus manifested Himself at different locations. He appeared to His disciples again at Sea of Tiberias. While the disciples were together, Simon Peter decided to go back to his old business of fishing. He said to the others, "I'm going out to fish," and they responded saying, "We'll go with you." That night they did not catch anything even though night is usually the most favourable time to catch fish. Without doubt, Jesus would have seen their fruitless effort throughout the night, thus, He chose to help them. According to verses 4 and 6, He stood on the seashore and said to them, "Friends haven't you any fish?" "No" they answered, and He said, "Throw your net on the right side of the boat and you will find some." Despite the fact that the disciples did not recognise Him (v. 4), they obeyed His instruction and they caught a large number of fish. Immediately, one of the disciples whom Jesus loved recognised. Jesus said to Peter, "It is the Lord". The declaration prompted Peter to throw his garment around himself and jump into the water while the other disciples pulled the net full of fish.

    The Bible did not state categorically the reasons Peter and the other disciples went back to their fishing profession. Nonetheless, it is obvious they were unsure of their future and in the interim, they chose not to be idle. However, there experiment ended in fruitlessness until the risen Lord appeared to them. Today, Christians need to ask themselves how faithful they are to the assignment committed to their hands by God or the assignment delegated to them by their pastor. Jesus appearance to the disciples reminds and gives us hope that Christ will one day appear again to judge the world. What will be our lot? Also, the disciples' inability to catch fish might be an indication of doing the wrong business. People with God's calling upon their lives can as well have such an experience if they abandon the ministry work God has called them to do. Perhaps the present turbulence in your business is due to such? Repent like Peter did. Some people have argued that the miracle of the great catch was a symbol of the great success of the redemptive movement among humankind (the Great Commission), which Jesus initiated. Believers should learn to obey Jesus\' command, no matter how difficult it may seem because it will be rewarding just as it was with the disciples.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. Why did the disciples not immediately recognise Jesus?
    2. Discuss Peter's action in verse 7b and its implication for believers. How many of us believe that Jesus can restore us from our hopeless situation as He did to the disciples?
  2. Jesus' Invitation for Conviction John 21:9-14

    Jesus' invitation to His disciples to eat in the passage is of paramount importance. His appearances to His disciples further prove of His resurrection. Indeed, He knew their emotional state after His death and burial and was ready to deal with it. Therefore, He asked for some fish, then invited them to eat breakfast to prove to them that He was Jesus. In addition, Jesus' invitation to His disciples to eat was purposely to allay their fears and worries and probably to prove to them that He is truly the Lord. Are you in doubt of Christ's resurrection? By eating with His disciples, Jesus confirmed that He was not a ghost but a living being. If you have been discouraged concerning the assignment the Lord has given you and contemplated quitting, would you respond to Christ's effort to restore you? Would you obey His command as His disciples did? It is in obedience that true restoration can occur. One of the striking lessons in the passage is that the disciples could not catch any fish in spite of their hard labour. Without the help of Jesus, we are helpless. Therefore, we should depend on Him and respond to His invitation to save.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. Compare and contrast the experience of the death of a loved one with those of the disciples who thought they would never see Jesus again
    2. Discuss the implication of Jesus' invitation in verse 12.
    3. What is the significance of the fish and bread Jesus gave to His disciples?

Prayer Points

  • Pray and thank God for the risen Lord through whom we have hope.
  • Uphold me with Your grace, O God, that I will not doubt You and what You can do.
  • Lord, I surrender myself to You today, receive me into Your loving hands.

Fellowship and Ministry Building Activities

  • Ask class members to discuss experiences in which they feel Christ directed them and/or empowered them and made them succeed at something they had previously failed at.

Take Home

  • We can do nothing on our own except God helps us.
  • Our struggles and hope can be restored with the help of the risen Lord
  • Jesus is the Bread of Life who provides for all our needs.
  • It is rewarding to obey Jesus' command.

title: FOLLOW ME
message:
April 15, 2018

FOLLOW ME

Devotional Reading: Matthew 10:5-15

Background Scripture / Lesson Scripture: Matthew 10:5-15

Golden Text

When they had finished eating, Jesus said to Simon Peter, “Simon son of John, do you truly love me more than these?” “Yes, Lord,” he said, “you know that I love you.” Jesus said, “Feed my lambs.” John 21:15

Objectives :

By the end of the lesson, class members should be able to:

  • Explain the various ways we can show our sincere love to God and humankind.
  • Discuss the reasons for Jesus' repeated question to Peter.
  • Express their decision to follow Jesus Christ in totality with a prayer of commitment.

INTRODUCTION

Mr George Asabaor is a renowned politician. He had occupied some important political positions in time past with good records of performance. Consequently, people, especially the youths, loved him and wanted him to continue in office. Some years later, he made his interest known to run for the gubernatorial position in his state. Almost immediately, his supporters started to move from one place to another canvassing for the votes of the electorate. In his attempt to convince the electorate of what he is capable of doing, he would remove his cap, point to his grey hair and say, "This is experience, so vote for me and follow me because I know the way". In fact, the people were thrilled by his promises and resolved to vote for him. No sooner had he assumed office than he was alleged of fraud and all kinds of political misconduct. He was nicknamed "Baba follow me" when actually he does not know the road. Eventually, he was disgraced out of office. This story is useful for today's lesson as we see Peter who seemed to be a good leader before Christ's death but somehow failed after Christ's death.

Today's lesson focuses on Jesus' command to Peter three times to feed His flock. After Peter's denial of Jesus (John 18:17, 25-27), Jesus restored him to his former position as a leader, and gave him the task of caring for His people whom He called "sheep". The call to leadership became necessary, especially as Jesus was about to ascend. As believers, Jesus is our perfect example. As He called Peter into a leadership position so He is calling all believers to follow Him today because He is the Way, the Truth and the Life.

THE LESSON EXPLAINED

  1. The Command to Follow John 21:15-19

    As Jesus' time with His disciples after His resurrection was coming to an end, He decided to reinstate Peter immediately after their meal. Jesus three times asked Peter if he loved Him and Peter's affirmative answers was followed with a command to feed Jesus' lambs and take care of His sheep (vv. 15-17). In the Greek text, Peter's answers to Jesus for the first and second times indicated that the Greek word translated 'love' used by Peter was a kind of brotherly love, while Jesus meant agape love. It seems Peter came to this understanding the third time. After the third question, which made him sad, Jesus told him again, "Feed my sheep." In other words, Jesus wants Peter to assume leadership position after His ascension and be responsible to all. The instructions, 'feed my lamb' and 'take care of my sheep' indicate Peter's leadership role among the disciples. Moreover, in verses 18-19, Jesus spoke to Peter about his death which will bring glory to God. He also commanded him to follow Him, by implication, to walk in His ways.

    The dialogue between Jesus and Peter was very interesting. Jesus' questions to him were, in effect, asking if he really understood the task of his new position to nourish and care for His people. So, while Peter seemed to have become exasperated, he later came to a fuller realisation of what exactly Jesus was asking him to do. Apparently, Peter affirmed his love for Jesus. This lesson, therefore, is a call for Christians to renew their love and commitment to follow God. This can be done through our sincere services, love to humankind and God.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. Discuss the possible reasons why Jesus repeated the command to feed His lamb to Peter.
    2. What might be required of someone wishing to restore a relationship with others after a relational breach? Compare your opinions with what Jesus asked of Peter
    3. What are the various ways by which we can show love to God and humankind?
  2. Jesus and the Other Disciple John 21:20-25

    After Jesus' command to Peter to follow Him, Peter saw the other disciple whom Jesus loved. Although the name of the disciple was not disclosed throughout the Scripture he was described in this passage as the one who had leaned close to Jesus at the table. Ancient tradition identified him as Apostle John, the son of Zebedee. It is obvious that Peter was surprised to see this same disciple following them; thus, he said to Jesus, "Lord, what about him?" Perhaps he wanted clarification whether he is included in the command to follow Him. Nevertheless, Jesus simply said, "If I want him to remain alive until I return, what is that to you? You must follow me" (v. 22). Consequently, there was a misconception and rumour about Jesus' statement among the brethren. They thought Jesus meant that the disciple would live and not die until He returns, whereas Jesus only meant that He has the authority to let him live until He returns (His second coming).

    Jesus response to Peter's question seems to tell us that He has revealed to us what we need to know. The call of each disciples is determined by God rather than by conforming to human reasoning and expectations (vv. 20-23). How many of us are ready to be totally committed to God? Can you just say a few words of prayer to God about this?

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. Mention three ways we can be restored, having gone astray.
    2. What could have been on the mind of Peter when he asked Jesus if the unnamed disciple should follow them?
    3. Who are the sheep and lamb Jesus commanded Peter to feed?

Prayer Points

  • Help me Lord, to follow Your ways, no matter how difficult it may seem.
  • Let my life bear witness to You at all times

Fellowship and Ministry Building Activities

  • Let class members identify the sheep and lamb in today's lesson. Who are they and what are our responsibilities to them?

Take Home

  • Our love for Christ can only be expressed through our love for others.
  • Following Jesus is rewarding.
  • Our lives should bear witness to Jesus Christ, our perfect example.
  • Christians must be ready to follow Jesus without fear.

title: THE LORD GOD, THE ALMIGHTY
message:
April 22, 2018

THE LORD GOD, THE ALMIGHTY

Devotional Reading: Revelation 19:1-8

Background Scripture: Revelation 4

Lesson Scripture: Revelation 4:1-11

Golden Text

“You are worthy, our Lord and God, to receive glory and honour and power, for you created all things, and by your will they were created and have their being.” Revelation 4:11

Objectives :

By the end of the lesson, class members should be able to:

  • Explain the significance of the symbolic words in the passage.
  • State some elements of quality worship.
  • Identify various ways God speaks to His people.

INTRODUCTION

The book of Revelation is unique in its writing because of the figurative language therein. Symbols are representations or signs that are used to communicate spiritual messages in human languages. Symbols may have more than one meaning and often evoke powerful responses. They can help us to see beyond the surface meaning of things to their deeper meanings. They also serve as doorways to understanding the sacred things of God. We shall see some of these as we learn today about God's glory.

Apostle John is the writer of the book of Revelation. The focus of today's lesson is the privilege of a full revelation of heavenly worship, which John had through visions at different times. In order for him to understand the heavenly events, which are related to the future of all the redeemed, God communicated with him using various symbols. The symbols are not just ordinary narratives, allegories, fiction or fable but real events that happened around the throne of God in heaven. Little wonder reading the book of Revelation is like taking a journey to a distant country with strange customs and unknown language. It is, of course, obvious that God wanted John to have an understanding of the message. Even today, God still speaks to His people through different signs and symbols. What matters is the willingness to study and understand God's Word and apply it appropriately.

THE LESSON EXPLAINED

  1. The Vision of an Open Heaven Revelation 4:1-3

    John's vision was in sequence. Apart from the previous revelations of the seven churches and the different messages for each, he had another vision. This vision was about the heavenly worship experience around the throne of God. It was a vision of an open door in heaven with the sound of a trumpet and an invitation to him saying, "Come up here, and I will show you what must take place after this." (v. 1b) The phrase "I will show you" means visions concerning the future and the command “come up here” refers specifically to the change in the scene in which John was to receive revelation about future events. Immediately, he was in the Spirit and was able to see the throne in heaven with someone sitting on it whose appearance looked like jasper and carnelian (a red stone with glittering features). The expression means that the Holy Spirit gave him a vision, showing him situations and events he could not have seen with his physical eyes. He also saw a rainbow that resembled an emerald (rock crystal which acts as a prism, breaking up light into the colours of the rainbow (Ezekiel 1:28). It encircled the throne.

    Without doubt, the voice that sounded like a trumpet was the voice of Jesus Christ that unfolded the events around the throne of God so that it will be recorded. John's vision of Christ under the influence of the Holy Spirit was a landmark in his ministry. He was given the opportunity to see beyond the physical __ an open heaven and God sitting on His throne. It is also worth mentioning that the description of the use of trumpet is partly influenced by the Old Testament tradition of God calling His people to witness great events that are yet to come. According to some Bible scholars, the symbols in the passage describe the radiance of God's throne while the door, here, signifies entrance by way of revelation into heaven.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. Discuss the significance of John's vision
    2. In what ways can we recognise the presence of God Almighty in our midst today?
    3. Why do some people use diabolical means to see vision today and how can we overcome such practices?
  2. God Communicates His Message Revelation 4:4-8

    The fact has been established that John had his vision in stages. From verse 4, God revealed to him the nature of the throne and the different symbols. In particular, John took note of the twenty-four elders who were clothed in white robes and crowns of gold; sitting on twenty-four thrones around the throne of God. In front of the throne were different elements of flashes of lightning, rumblings and peals of thunder, seven lit torches. Usually, lightning and thunder are connected with significant events in heaven and in the Old Testament, such imagery were used to reflect God's power and majesty (Psalm 77:18). The elements symbolise the seven spirits of God or the Holy Spirit in the work of illumination and revelation of God's Word to humankind. Other creatures like lion, bull, human face, and eagle with six wings also surrounded the throne. Interestingly, these creatures recognise the mightiness of God; therefore, they continually praise Him saying, "Holy, holy, holy is the Lord God Almighty, who was, who is, and is to come." These living creatures were united in their constant praise of God for His eternal holiness. Though not exactly like the cherubim seen by Prophet Ezekiel (Ezekiel 10:1-10), they appeared to serve similar functions.

    God still communicates His messages through humankind using various familiar symbols like the case of John in his vision. Because He is God and always desires that His people will understand His plan and purpose for them, He sometimes speaks to us using different familiar symbols. Whenever He does that, it shows His willingness to be understood. Therefore, we should recognise that every representation in this passage is meaningful, symbolic and it speaks of God's power and glory, day and night.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. Discuss various types of worship symbols you use in your church and explain their importance.
    2. The revelation of God's holiness stimulates us to worship and praise Him. Discuss.
  3. Worshipping God in Heaven Revelation 4:9-11

    Part of John's vision was the picture of a combined choir of four living creatures. They continually sing songs of glory and honour and thanksgiving to Him who sits on the throne. The phrase "him who sits on the throne" was a direct way the Jews and early Christians expressed reverence to God. Also, it was an attempt to describe the act of ceaseless worship in heaven. Particularly, the activities of the four creatures are described in verse 8, "Day and night they never stop saying: "Holy, holy, holy is the Lord God Almighty." As it is seen in the passage, the song often prompts the twenty- four elders to fall down before Him who sits on the throne and worship Him because He lives forever and ever. As part of showing reverence to God, they lay their crowns before the throne and say: "You are worthy, our Lord and God, to receive glory and honour and power, for you created all things, and by your will they were created and have their being” (v. 11). Their style of worship is worthy of emulation, especially the removal of their crowns and bowing down; these are all symbols of emptying oneself and humility. It also shows respect for God who lives forever and ever.

    The passage is a reminder that God is worthy of our praises and honour because He created and sustains all things. Apostle John's description of the activities in heaven reminds us that we serve a God of order and harmony who deserves praise and honour. The entire vision shows a portrait of God, His awesomeness and dignity. It, therefore, confirms that praise and worship to God are constantly on-going in heaven. As a result, Christians should continuously praise and worship God because He is the Creator and Sustainer of all things. We should worship Him with songs of praise, dancing, our time and other resources at our disposal. This should be done in humility just like the twenty-four elders remove their crowns, as a sign of humility.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. Identify some things Christians are expected to forsake in order to worship God in sincerity.
    2. Suggest some ways of improving praise worship in your church.

Prayer Points

  • Pray and ask God to open your eyes and give you understanding of how to praise Him better.
  • Ask the Lord to count you worthy to praise Him with the saints at the end of age.
  • Pray that your life will be characterised with praise and sincere worship.

Fellowship and Ministry Building Activities

  • Let each class member write at least ten things that make God worthy of honour and praise.
  • Sing together BH 1: Holy, Holy, Holy and pray for grace to always praise and honour God.

Take Home

  • Christians should learn to praise God all the time because He is worthy of our praise.
  • God alone should be our object of worship.
  • God can choose to speak to His people through any means.
  • One of the attributes of God is holiness.

title: BLESSING, GLORY, HONOUR FOREVER
message:
April 29, 2018

BLESSING, GLORY, HONOUR FOREVER

Devotional Reading: Philippians 2:1-11

Background Scripture: Revelation 5:6-14

Lesson Scripture: Revelation 5:1-14

Golden Text

In a loud voice they sang: "Worthy is the Lamb, who was slain, to receive power and wealth and wisdom and strength and honour and glory and praise!" Revelation 5:12

Objectives :

By the end of the lesson, class members should be able to:

  • Mention at least four characteristics of the Lamb.
  • State clearly what was revealed about the Lamb (Jesus) and what He has accomplished through His death.
  • Write down what they will do in order to give God worthy worship.

INTRODUCTION

It was another Sunday morning and as usual, the children were engaged in different activities according to their age groups. One of the boys in younger children's class was engrossed with drawing and colouring a highly complicated picture. Having watched him with keen interest, the teacher walked up to him and said, "What are you drawing, my dear?" The boy responded without lifting his head, "I am drawing the picture of God." "That is very good, but do you know that no one knows exactly what God looks like", said the teacher. "They will now know with my picture", was the boy's response. The effort of John in the book of Revelation can be likened to what the little boy did in his attempt to draw the picture of God.

Today's lesson is a continuation of the vision in chapter 4, that is, the ceaseless worship in heaven. In John's vision, he carefully described the scroll and the Lamb (the One seated on the throne). As the plan of his vision unfolded, what was unspoken became open. In fact, the fifth chapter of the book of Revelation is a key chapter that introduces us to some scenes and characters in heaven. Mainly, it contains the worship of Christ, the Son, by the heavenly hosts.

THE LESSON EXPLAINED

  1. Vision of the Scroll Revelation 5:1-5

    The scene that began in chapter 4, when John was invited to behold some future events continued in chapter 5. In this vision, John's attention was drawn primarily to the scroll and the Lamb. He saw the scroll in the right hand of Him who sits on the throne covered with writing on both sides and a mighty angel who proclaimed in a loud voice, "Who is worthy to break the seals and open the scroll?" (v. 2) Unfortunately, it seemed no one met the criteria to open the scroll in heaven or on earth. This made John weep profusely until he was consoled by one of the elders that the Lion of the tribe of Judah, the great descendant of David has triumphed. Therefore, He is qualified to break the seven seals and open the scroll. The two phrases describe Christ, the Slain and Risen Lamb who alone is confirmed to be worthy to open the scroll. Of course, this presupposes the fact that Jesus, the Lamb of God has the right to open the scroll not only by virtue of His power (as the Lion of the tribe of Judah) but also through His sacrificial death (as the Slain Lamb), which has brought salvation to humankind. The two phrases are very significant in John's vision because they both describe Jesus as the Slain and Risen Lamb who is worthy to open the scroll.

    It is evident that Jesus, the Lamb of God who alone has the authority to reveal God\'s secrets, was qualified to open the scroll. According to some Bible commentators, the scrolls at that time usually contain writings on both sides and sealed with seven seals. The writings on both sides often emphasise their ability to accomplish the purposes of God and the number seven represents the absolute sacredness of the scroll. It was this same scroll that no one was capable of opening except Jesus, the Lamb, who is our Deliverer, Saviour and Mediator.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. List the attributes of the Lamb as described in the passage.
    2. Why is it that no one was qualified to open the scroll except Jesus Christ who has won the victory?
  2. Vision of the Lamb Revelation 5:6-10

    John's vision was successive and explicit. Having been invited to behold some future events in the first few verses of the passage, John suddenly saw a Lamb standing at the centre of the throne as though already slain (Isaiah 53:7). He was surrounded by four living creatures and the elders. He had seven horns and seven eyes representing seven spirits of God that have been sent throughout the whole earth (v. 6). According to verse 7, the Lamb took the scroll from Him who sits on the throne. The event prompted the four living creatures and the twenty-four elders to bow down before the Lamb in worship. Each had a harp and golden bowl, which John identified as the prayers of God\'s own people who have been set apart for God. They worshipped and sang a new song: "You are worthy to take the scroll and to open its seals, because you were slain, and with your blood you purchased men for God from every tribe and language and people and nation." Ultimately, this song of praise explains why the Lamb is worthy to open the scroll: by His sacrificial death, we have been reconciled to God. Consequently, it has made the people a kingdom and priests to serve God, because they will reign on earth (v. 10).

    Remarkably, the scroll refers to the prophecy of this book; a revelation of the complete redemptive plan of God through human history to eternity. Interestingly, the redemptive plan of God was fulfilled in Revelation 21:6 when God said, "It is done ...." Furthermore, it is apparent that praise and worship of the four creatures and twenty-four elders form the content of the song, which of course is the summary of the victory of the Lamb. Therefore, Christians proclaim Jesus' worthiness on the basis of His redemptive power with which He has made them a kingdom of priests to serve God through His sacrificial death (Revelation 1:5-6; 1 Peter 2:9), and they shall rule on earth.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. According to the lesson, state two benefits of Jesus' death.
    2. Identify the differences between the heavenly worship as seen in today's passage and the way we worship today.
  3. Praise to the Lamb Revelation 5:11-14

    It was confirmed in the previous lesson that the death of Jesus Christ has a universal effect, therefore, the redeemed have the right to serve God as kingdom priests. The scene that followed the song of praise to the Lamb was the voice of innumerable company of angels that surrounded the throne. Suddenly, John heard them saying with a loud voice, "Worthy is the Lamb, who was slain, to receive power and wealth and wisdom and strength and honour and glory and praise!" (v. 12) He also heard the voice of every creature in heaven, on earth, under the earth and in the sea singing praises in honour of Him who sits on the throne and the Lamb. The four living creatures responded by saying, "Amen" while the elders fell down and worshipped.

    No doubt, this vision is similar to Daniel's vision when he saw countless multitude before the Ancient of Days and the books were opened (Daniel 7:9-10). This passage is a reminder that all creation should acknowledge that Jesus is Lord. This confirms that whether one likes it or not, every creation wherever found; religion and race notwithstanding, will at last worship the Lord Jesus as the only living God (v. 13). This is essentially important because He has completed the work given to Him by His Father and has restored humankind from their fallen state, thus He is worthy of our praise. Therefore, we can praise God corporately or individually for the way He works in the lives of His people like the elders and the four creatures in the passage.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. In line with today's passage, discuss the common saying that, 'the only work in heaven is praising God.'
    2. Mention some things believers can emulate from verses 11-13 as we worship God.

Prayer Points

  • Praise God for His plan of salvation through the blood of His Son, Jesus Christ.
  • Lord, teach me to worship you in an acceptable way.
  • Lord, count me worthy to be among the saints who will praise and worship You in heaven ceaselessly.

Fellowship and Ministry Building Activities

  • Compare and contrast the heavenly worship, as described in today's passage with the style of worship in your church. Discuss the areas you think there should be improvement and submit it to the pastor.
  • Write down what you will do so as to give God quality worship.

Take Home

  • God alone is worthy of our praise and worship.
  • Christians are encouraged to celebrate God's faithfulness through sincere praise and worship.

title: GIVING FROM A GENEROUS HEART
message:
May 6, 2018

GIVING FROM A GENEROUS HEART

Devotional Reading: Psalm 112

Background Scripture: Exodus 25:1-7; 35:4-29;Leviticus 27:30-33; 2 Corinthians 9:6-8

Lesson Scripture: Exodus 35:20-29; 2 Corinthians 9:6-8

Golden Text

Remember this: Whoever sows sparingly will also reap sparingly, and whoever sows generously will also reap generously. 2 Corinthians 9:6

Objectives :

By the end of the lesson, class members should be able to:

  • Explain what it means to give sacrificially as it is seen in today's passage.
  • Identify and discuss the blessings that result from giving generously.
  • Write their commitments to give towards meeting specific needs of the church and people.

INTRODUCTION

When Pastor Peter Odogu assumed the pastorate of All Believers Baptist Church, Ekedola, he had passion for evangelism and missions and was willing to cooperate with members of the church as regards church projects. Few weeks after his assumption of office, he saw the need for the construction of a new church building and purchase of modern equipment. Having prayed and was convinced of God's approval, he made his plan known to the members of the church. Interestingly, they were willing to support him with their resources and prayers. The members met and encouraged one another on the need to support the pastor's vision and almost immediately the construction work began. Some of the people offered free services while others donated money and other material gifts for the completion of the project. Before the stipulated time, the work was completed and dedicated for use. The attitude of the people can be likened to the people of Israel who responded to the call of Moses to give generously when the Tabernacle of the Lord was to be constructed.

The book of Exodus records the movement of the Israelites from Egypt, as well as the various instructions God gave them in the course of their journey to the Promised Land. One of such instructions was the construction of the Tabernacle (Exodus 25-27). They were expected to provide the materials to be used for the construction of the tabernacle. The instruction was carried out to the letter. They all responded by providing the materials for the construction and furnishing of the Tabernacle. By this singular act, God taught the Israelites the principle of giving. This same concept of generous giving was emphasised by Paul in his letter to the Corinthian church (2 Corinthians 9:6). According to Paul, he was aware of their hardship, yet he encouraged them to give to support their fellow brothers and sisters in Jerusalem just like the Macedonians had done despite their troubles.

THE LESSON EXPLAINED

  1. A Willing Heart Exodus 35:20-22

    The Israelites heard the commands of the Lord through Moses with reference the building of the tabernacle. Among the commands was generous giving for the construction of the tabernacle of the Lord. The people responded positively to Moses' appeal. According to verse 21, those who were willing and whose hearts moved them to give came with their offerings for the construction work. They brought their gold jewelry of various kinds, brooches, earrings, rings and beautiful ornaments and presented them as wave offerings to the Lord. Certainly, the people understood the fact that God is capable of providing the needed material without involving them, but He has only chosen to involve them in the work of the tent of meeting.

    Having listened to Moses' narration, the people allowed the Lord to speak to them about what to bring instead of being coerced (v. 20). This of course is an indication of a willing heart, which is God's standard for His people. In addition, their response is an indication that they believed in Moses as God's messenger and that God owned everything in their possession. But today, there are different people in the church of God: those who are compelled to give and those who are insensitive to the things of God. In some cases, leaders place curses on people who fail to give. This attitude is ungodly and selfish. The message in the passage is that giving must come from a willing heart because God only accepts offerings that come from willing hearts. Giving is also an element of our worship to God, this was evident in the presentation of gold (valuable substance, which in our generation includes money) as wave offering to the Lord. A true worshipper gives God quality offering to meet a need in the church. It may also be necessary for us as Christians to allow God to speak to us on how to meet needs in the church for the expansion of His work. More so, God will not demand that you give what He has not already provided for you. He will not ask you to give what you do not have at your disposal.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. Discuss why some people are not willing to give to the work of God in their various churches.
    2. What are the likely dangers of compelling people to give to God?
    3. Why did the people respond to Moses' appeal for generous giving?
  2. Everyone Was Involved Exodus 35:23-29

    The importance of teamwork in achieving success in whatever facet of life cannot be overemphasised as it is seen in the passage. The instruction on generous giving which was given to Moses about the construction of the tabernacle was all-embracing as the people presented their gifts as offering unto the Lord. The passage shows that no one was excluded in the provision of the resources needed for the building of the tabernacle. Particularly, every skilled woman used her expertise and brought what she had spun (blue, purple or scarlet yarn or fine linen) to the Lord at no cost (v. 25). Furthermore, the leaders were exemplary in their giving __ they brought onyx stones and other gems to be set for the ephod and breastpiece, spices and olive oil for the light and anointing oil (vv. 27-28). In fact, the collaborative effort demonstrated by the people is worthy of emulation by contemporary Christians. All the men and women who were willing brought their freewill offerings for the completion of the tabernacle as Moses had commanded them (v. 29).

    The spirit of cooperation and enthusiasm that was demonstrated by the people of Israel is worth emulating. From verse 25, everyone involved brought their resources, no matter how little it seemed. They were passionate about the completion of the tabernacle for the worship of God. The implication, therefore, is that no one should be exempted from making provision for the progress of the work of God. Both the leaders and the led, men and women, should ensure that they play their parts in giving, as God speaks to them. It is, however, sad that some Christians find it difficult to give for the advancement of God's work. What is commonly seen today is that while some Christians complain they do not have enough, some others refuse to give willingly and adequately because they are ignorant of the blessings that come with giving. Our challenge from today's lesson is that artisans in our churches should be willing to use their technical know-how in the construction and beautification of church buildings, whenever the need arises, with little or no charges. The benefit can be rewarding because God does not forget our labour of love.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. Why do some leaders in the church not give but encourage other members to give? Discuss.
    2. Discuss possible reasons why some artisans find it difficult to render free services whenever they work for the church.
    3. How can church leaders encourage teamwork?
  3. Generous Giving Attracts Divine Blessing 2 Corinthians 9:6-8

    Apostle Paul did not relent in his effort to encourage the Gentile churches in Galatia, Macedonia and Corinth to help their fellow Jewish Christians who were experiencing financial difficulty probably as a result of persecution. As he wrote and encouraged the people on generous giving, he based his facts on two important principles:

    • Anyone who sows sparingly (scarcely) will also reap sparingly but anyone who sows generously (open-handedly) will also reap generously (v. 6). This implies that the amount they give will determine the reward they will receive.
    • Each one of them should give whatever they have proposed in their hearts. In other words, they should give willingly because God loves and will only accept the offering of those who give cheerfully.

    Generous giving is synonymous to bountiful giving because a generous giver gives the best that is available to him/her. Such givers do not need to be compelled and such giving attracts divine blessings. In verse 7, Paul emphasised the importance of making personal decisions to give willingly to God. But these days, the present economic hardship has made some Christians not to see the need to contribute willingly and meaningfully in meeting the needs of the church. They often complain of lack and inability to cater for their immediate family members. As believers, we should be encouraged by the words of Paul who based his reason for giving generously on the hope that God will be glorified (2 Corinthians 9:11-13) and He will reward those who give liberally.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. Mention some likely blessings God can make available to those who give generously.
    2. How can we encourage people to give sacrificially so as to receive God's blessings?
    3. Let some members briefly share how they have been blessed because they gave to God from their little resources.

Prayer Points

  • Ask God for forgiveness for your stingy attitude in the past.
  • Pray to God to open your eyes to the needs of the church and people around you.
  • Ask Him for the grace to be willing to meet some of these needs, as the Lord provides for you.

Fellowship and Ministry Building Activities

  • Each member of the class should decide how to meet some urgent needs of the church this week.
  • Be prepared to share with the class what you have done or started next week.

Take Home

  • Christian giving is a loving response to the self-giving of Jesus Christ.
  • Be sensitive to the needs of your church and people around you.
  • Generous giving attracts divine blessings.
  • The call to give is for all.

title: BRINGING FIRST FRUITS
message:
May 13, 2018

BRINGING FIRST FRUITS

Devotional Reading: Ephesians 4:25 __ 5:2

Background Scripture: Leviticus 2:14; 23:9-22

Lesson Scripture: Leviticus 23:9-14, 22

Golden Text

"Speak to the Israelites and say to them: 'When you enter the land I am going to give you and you reap its harvest, bring to the priest a sheaf of the first grain you harvest. Leviticus 23:10

Objectives :

By the end of the lesson, class members should be able to:

  • Explain the meaning of first fruits and how the practice relates to the poor.
  • Discuss various ways the church can care for the poor.
  • Make concrete decision on how to care for the poor around them.

INTRODUCTION

Pastor John Madoki Udoh is a young graduate from one of the Baptist theological institutions. Having prayed fervently, he was convinced of God's leading to pastor a Baptist church in a rural area. Members of that community were predominantly farmers. One Sunday morning, as he entered into the church, he was surprised to find some tubers of yam on the floor beside the pulpit. He was puzzled so, he asked an elderly man about the reason for bringing tubers of yam to the church. With a smile, the elderly man replied, "This is the first fruit from my farm. I have brought it to you as it has been our practice in this church." He explained further that it is according to God's command about first fruits. Throughout the period of his pastorate in the church, bringing first fruits to the Lord became more meaningful to the pastor. The more the members were committed to the practice, the more they experienced God's bountiful blessings.

Leviticus chapter 23 deals with three great annual feasts God commanded the children of Israel to observe during which all Israelite males would go to Jerusalem. One of such feasts was the Feast of Firstfruits. It usually falls on the sixteenth day of the first month of the Jewish calendar (Abib), with its contemporary equivalent as March/April. It signifies the dedication of harvest to the Lord as well as celebrating God, who has made them to witness another harvest. As partakers of the saving grace of God, Christians have a lot to learn, adopt and practice from these Jewish feasts and as another dimension of generous giving.

THE LESSON EXPLAINED

  1. First Fruit: A Divine Command Leviticus 23:9-13

    The relationship between God and Moses was cordial. From time to time, God communicated with him as he played the role of an intermediary between Him and the people of Israel. In the first few verses of Leviticus chapter 23, Moses was commanded to instruct the children of Israel about the observance of three important feasts which must be celebrated by them. They include the Sabbath (v. 3), the Passover and the Festival of Unleavened Bread (vv. 4-8) and the Firstfruits (vv. `9-14). Principally, the Feast of the Firstfruit was to be observed when they enter the Promised Land after harvest (v. 10). The feast was to be in two stages.

    • They shall take a sheaf of the harvest to the priest who will present it as offering unto the Lord. This practice enhances acceptability of the person presenting the sheaf before the Lord (verses 10-11). It is important to note that the waving of the sheaf must take place on the day after the Sabbath.
    • They were also to make sacrifices of a burnt offering of a lamb without blemish (v. 12), a grain offering of two tenths of an ephah and an offering of one litre of wine (v. 13). The offerings should be made by fire, and the smell pleasing to God.

    The command to celebrate the Feast of Firstfruits was from God. It was to remind the Israelites that the land upon which they farmed was a gift to them from God and the harvest was only made possible by God. In like manner, Christians are expected to celebrate the blessings of God through generous giving and with particular emphasis on the first fruit, which could be the first proceed from whatever job we do. More importantly, believers should see such a celebration as a way of showing gratitude to God, without whom our labour would have amounted to nothing. However, leaders of God\'s people should be wary of instituting 'feasts' that are not godly in order to increase the income of the church without receiving clear instructions from God.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. What are the things that could represent first fruits for various categories of workers (civil servants, traders, artisans, etc.)?
    2. Identify some church traditions that have become a burden to the people and suggest ways to avoid them.
  2. Put God First Leviticus 23:14

    God's instruction to Moses concerning the celebration of the Feast of Firstfruits was clear and straightforward. Having instructed them on the two stages of the celebration, God gave them stern warning that, "You must not eat any bread, or roasted or new grain, until the very day you bring this offering to your God" (v 14). They were not to eat from the fruits of their labour except God's due portion is given Him. This of course places emphasis on the importance of putting God first. Even when they are tempted, they must remember that the Lord forbids them from taking any portion of the harvest before giving the first fruit. It is interesting to note that God stated clearly that this is not an ordinance for a particular generation, but “... a lasting ordinance for the generations to come, wherever you live.” (v. 14b)

    It is apparent from the passage that present-day believers are not exempted from this divine principle of first fruit. God desires to be the first in our lives. Even when it is obvious that there are situations that are contending with our allegiance to Him, we must be mindful of this instruction and resolve not to compromise our faith in God. After all, God made us, owns us and everything that belongs to us (Psalm 24:1). When we violate this age-long ordinance, our progress may be hindered but when we obey and put Him first, He blesses us.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. What are the likely things that take first position in our lives apart from God?
    2. What would you do if a sick relative of yours is in dire need of money, and the only money available with you is your first fruit?
  3. God's Concern for the Poor Leviticus 23:22

    God's command to the people of Israel to bring their first fruits to the priests is closely related to caring for the poor (the deprived or disadvantaged) in their midst. According to the passage, God said to Moses, "When you reap the harvest of your land, do not reap to the very edges of your field or gather the gleanings of your harvest." In other words, they were expected to intentionally leave some crops during harvest. This will serve as provision for the poor and the aliens, especially during the time of the celebration of God's abundance and provision. The warning became necessary probably for two reasons: the tendency for the Israelites to take undue advantage of poor people with the justification that they have given God their first fruits. Secondly, they may not be concerned about the underprivileged in their midst. This is exactly a clear indication of God's concern for the poor in the land of Israel. The same order was later given to the Israelites with the inclusion of widows and the fatherless so that the work of their hands will be blessed by God (Deuteronomy 24:19). However, God warned that the poor must be catered for and be allowed to gather the gleanings, as well as take from the leftovers at the edge of the farmland (Ruth 2:2-3). This was God's design for meeting the needs of the poor in the land of Israel.

    The poor are the underprivileged people, who for some reasons cannot provide for themselves and their family members. The poor are always around the people of God (Deuteronomy 15:11). Just as God had concern for the poor and foreigners in the days of Moses, today He expects believers to care for such people, especially those of the household of faith, irrespective of where they come from (Galatians 5:6; 6:10), so that none will be in want. This can be done through empowerment programmes, whereby some of them are trained in various trades. Some influential members of the church can also use their stewardship of influence to help them whenever there are job opportunities. The church can also organise cooperative programmes from which members can borrow with little or no interest for small scale businesses. When this is done, God's mandate would have been fulfilled and there will be joy and unity in the body of Christ.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. How can we truly identify the poor and needy, especially when there are professional beggars all around?
    2. Are we not encouraging laziness if the church continues to care for people who are not physically challenged?

Prayer Points

  • Thank God for the blessings you receive regularly from your work/business.
  • Pray for grace to be sensitive to the needs of people around you.
  • Pray that God will break the yoke of poverty in your life

Fellowship and Ministry Building Activities

  • Identify poor mothers in the church and give them gifts e.g. foodstuffs, money, etc.

Take Home

  • Christians should celebrate the blessings of God.
  • Giving is the hallmark of a Christian.
  • Self-centredness can hinder us from seeing the needs of the underprivileged.
  • The rich are blessed in order to care for the poor and needy.

title: REMEMBERING WITH JOY
message:
May 20, 2018

REMEMBERING WITH JOY

Devotional Reading: Psalm 50:1-15

Background Scripture: Leviticus 25

Lesson Scripture: Leviticus 25:1-12

Golden Text

Consecrate the fiftieth year and proclaim liberty throughout the land to all its inhabitants. It shall be a jubilee for you; each one of you is to return to his family property and each to his own clan. Leviticus 25:10

Objectives :

By the end of the lesson, class members should be able to:

  • Discuss the significance of Jubilee and relate it to the ministry of Jesus Christ.
  • Explain the importance of rest to humankind and land.
  • Make (write down) a commitment to always have enough rest without being told.

INTRODUCTION

Mr Emmanuel James was a committed Christian and a business entrepreneur. Before his death, his slogan was “I cannot afford to rest when there are business opportunities to be explored.” In light of this, he was always on the move without having enough time to rest. Apart from his business philosophy, as a young man, he believed he must be hard-working, not minding the consequences. Truly, his devotion to the success of his business was amazing even though it turned out to be a problem to his employees. He rarely approved leave for his employees because he was of the opinion that only lazy people go on leave. His business grew so well as a result of his commitment but soon, his health deteriorated because of his rigorous working habit. He was later diagnosed of cardiac problem. Unfortunately, he died at the prime of his age.

Today's lesson is a reminder of some of the commandments God gave to the children of Israel, through Moses. In Leviticus chapter 25, God commanded Moses to instruct the Israelites to observe two specific feasts (the Sabbath and the year of Jubilee) when they enter the Promised Land. While the Sabbath was a time for the land to lie fallow, the Jubilee was simply a time to proclaim liberty throughout the land to all the inhabitants. Particularly, the rest was to be observed at a stipulated time (the seventh farming year), which should be remembered with joy. However, these instructions are not only meant for the nation of Israel. Contemporary Christians are expected to take time to rest without being lazy or slothful. As much as rest is good for the body, it is also good for the land because it enhances productivity.

THE LESSON EXPLAINED

  1. The Command to Observe the Sabbath Leviticus 25:1-7

    The book of Leviticus has a long list of God's commands through Moses to the Israelites, especially concerning their relationship with Him. In chapter 25, God instructed Moses on Mount Sinai to tell the Israelites to observe the Sabbath when they eventually enter the Promised Land. Apart from the people, the land must also observe the Sabbath to the Lord (v. 2). Invariably, when the children of Israel would have tilled the land for six years, it should be allowed to rest, thereby preparing it for another productive six years. In the seventh year, they are not expected to plant anything, prune their vineyards or harvest the crops and grapes that grow of itself (vv. 4-5). It was emphasised that the Sabbath is not unto the people of Israel, but “a Sabbath to the LORD” (v. 4), hence, it must be observed as a sacred year. However, whatever the land would produce during the year would be enough for the people, their slaves and animals (vv. 6-7, 21).

    There is a common saying that "rest is sweet after labour" and this rest is good for humans, animals and land as it enhances productivity. After all, God rested after the creation of the universe, thereby setting an example for us to follow (Genesis 2:2- 3; Leviticus 23:3). The command to rest is necessary for all to observe because a period of rest for the people, the animals that plough and the servants who work on the field is ultimately rewarding. Of course, God knew that His command not to cultivate the land for one year will definitely lead to fear and doubts about their means of survival. Consequently, He assured the people that the land will still yield and its produce will be enough for them, their animals and dependants (v. 6). Apparently, this affirms God's ability to care for His people since the earth and everything in it belongs to Him (Psalm 24:1; 50:10-11). This divine promise of provision (which was actually fulfilled) is also meant to awaken our trust in God's unfailing care for us both when we labour and in time of legitimate rest. Those who fail to observe their annual leave because of their quest for more money also have a lesson to learn from this lest their health suffer a breakdown.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. What does “the land is God's” (v. 23) mean to us today and how can we care for it? From professional practice, how does rest (fallowing) enhance productivity of lands?
    2. Let some class members share their experiences of adequate rest in recent time.
  2. The Command to Observe Jubilee Leviticus 25:8-12

    Jubilee was another important festival God instructed the people of Israel to celebrate. It is also known as the year of restoration. According to verse 8, they were to count seven Sabbath years, which will make a total period of forty-nine years. Then on the tenth day of the seventh month, the trumpet would sound on the Day of Atonement throughout the land. This date, which indicates the day the Israelites restored their relationship with the Lord, with their sins atoned for (Leviticus 23:28), will be succeeded by two other events: the consecration of the fiftieth year and the proclamation of liberty (the Year of Jubilee) all over the land including their inhabitants that dwell in the land. Accordingly, each of them will return to their original clan and family property. This is to ensure that poor people or slaves who have lost their properties (lands and/or houses) can have them restored to them in the year of Jubilee (vv. 23-31).
