It is also an indication that God abhors the amassing of wealth at the expense of the poor. In addition, the people were instructed not to sow or harvest whatever grows of itself in the field.

    The blowing of the trumpet in ancient Israel was remarkable. It signified a solemn but joyful occasion which informs the people of an important event. The Jubilee trumpet is to be sounded on the Day of Atonement, the tenth day in the seventh month. It suggests liberty and freedom for the people of Israel, giving them the opportunity to begin again. In fact, the feast was supposed to be celebrated and remembered with joy because of the cancellation of debts and slaves that would regain their freedom (Leviticus 25:39-41). Moreover, lands will be returned to their original owners and properties redeemed (Leviticus 23:25-28). Therefore, the Jubilee is an expression of the grace of God, extended to humanity. It signifies the freedom that humans are expected to enjoy having received atonement for their sins through the blood of Jesus Christ, thereby making our freedom total. Believers should, therefore, continue in the 'jubilee ministry' of Jesus Christ to grant freedom to the oppressed by ministering to the prisoners, people living with disabilities, the poor (physical and spiritual) and the oppressed.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. Is the celebration of Jubilee still relevant? If yes, how do you think it should be celebrated?
    2. Discuss some things the Jubilee reminds us of as believers.

Prayer Points

  • Ask God for forgiveness for the overuse of your body.
  • Pray and be ready to support the underprivileged in your little way.
  • Ask God for the grace to extend the love of Christ, expressed through the Jubilee, to people that work with/under you.

Fellowship and Ministry Building Activities

  • Discuss with your pastor the need to invite a medical personnel to talk about the importance of rest to humans.
  • Do a wide publicity so that more people will be blessed through the programme.

Take Home

  • Rest is good and ordained by God.
  • You cannot afford to handle the things in your possession carelessly.
  • Jesus' ministry brings freedom and liberty to the oppressed.
  • As believers, we are duty-bound to help those in bondage (sin) to gain freedom through Jesus Christ.

title: REJOICING IN RESTORATION
message:
May 27, 2018

REJOICING IN RESTORATION

Devotional Reading: Hebrews 7:20-28

Background Scripture: Leviticus 16; Psalm 34; Hebrews 2:5-18

Lesson Scripture: Psalm 34:1-10; Hebrews 2:17-18

Golden Text

Taste and see that the LORD is good; blessed is the man who takes refuge in him. Psalm 34:8

Objectives :

By the end of the lesson, class members should be able to:

  • Identify the reasons why some people find it difficult to trust God, especially in times of trouble.
  • Discuss the causes of fear and how to overcome it.
  • Renounce their personal fears and challenges to God in prayer.

INTRODUCTION

Mr and Mrs Peter Okoloba are good Christians. They had taught and trained their children, James and John, to trust God and give Him thanks in whatever situation. As the children grew up, they started to demonstrate spiritual maturity to a point that their friends often addressed them as pastors. One day, the children were kidnapped by some gun men on their way home from school. While they were in custody of their abductors, they were overwhelmed with fear and greatly disheartened, especially as they were being threatened with death every day. Soon, the young men began to suspect some supposed enemies with whom their parents had had misunderstanding. But after some days in captivity without hope of being rescued, they realised that only God could set them free. Therefore, they resorted to singing praises and songs of deliverance to God and after twelve days in captivity, they were miraculously released without any ransom. When interviewed by some journalists about the secret of their escape they simply said, “We trusted in the Lord, He heard our prayers and delivered us from our enemies.” In fact, their joy knew no bounds as they shared their testimonies in church about God's power to save and deliver particularly in difficult moments. They promised to continue to trust in God and show Him gratitude, no matter the condition they find themselves.

Today's lesson will focus on Psalm 34. It is a psalm of praise of God's goodness. The psalm is believed to have been written by David in commemoration of his escape from Achish, the King of Gath, before whom he pretended to be mad in order to escape death (1Samuel 21:10-15). Interestingly, God hearkened to his prayer. His experiences taught him that God has the power to rescue anyone from trouble, especially when such an individual is righteous and trusts God. In his composition of this psalm, David expressed that only the Lord can restore a man when faced with oppositions and challenges of life. Whenever this restoration takes place, it is expected of such an individual to joyfully ascribe the glory to God.

THE LESSON EXPLAINED

  1. David's Personal Testimony Psalm 34:1-7

    This psalm was composed by David when he was afraid that he might perish in Gath, by the sword of Achish. The psalm is a summary of his expression of gratitude to God for deliverance and answer to prayer (v. 4) having escaped death. As a result, he publicly declared to always thank the Lord and never to stop praising Him for what He had done (v. 1). Therefore, the afflicted and the poor who hear his testimony should glorify God with him (vv. 2-3), because he sought the Lord who answered him and delivered him from all his fears. His declaration in verses 5 and 6 is astonishing. He said:

    • When the oppressed looked up to Him, they were glad and not disappointed.
    • The helpless called Him and He answered their prayers and saved them from all their troubles. Therefore, David acknowledged the fact that the angel of the Lord always protects those who fear Him and delivers them from danger.

    David was a man of faith. In every trouble of his life, he learnt to talk to God in prayer, thanksgiving, praise and he testified to the faithfulness of God. He learnt to commit his fears and worries about defeat and, death, which are capable of putting one in bondage, unto God. Unfortunately today, some Christians are overwhelmed with fear as a result of life's challenges. The only way to overcome such fear is to trust God for deliverance and give Him thanks always like David. Whenever we commit our fears and troubles unto the Lord in prayer, we are sure of deliverance and restoration. When we do contrary, we get unnecessarily anxious to the extent that we forget about God's ability to deliver us from such unpleasant experiences. As mature believers, we should learn from David, who spoke to God about his fears and testified of His deliverance and restoration. This presupposes the fact that anyone who fears the Lord will surely overcome.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. Discuss the effective ways a Christian can overcome fear.
    2. Why do believers easily complain and apportion blame when they are faced with life's challenges?
  2. Encouragement to Seek Refuge in the Lord Psalm 34:8-10

    David's testimony was followed by encouraging his readers to seek refuge in the Lord. Furthermore, he urged them to 'taste and see' which is the same as to 'find out' or to 'discover' the goodness of the Lord, especially to those who take refuge in Him (v. 8). The admonition to fear the Lord is emphasised again in verse 9 when he said, "Fear the Lord, you his saints, for those who fear him lack nothing." The declaration was further explained when he said, even the young lions may grow weak and hungry, those who fear God will lack no good thing (v. 10).

    David's counsel to seek protection in the Lord is encouraging. Without doubt, he understood the importance of taking refuge in God based on his experiences in the wilderness when Saul sought to kill him (2 Kings 19:11-24). David was confident and expressed the fact that the fear of God attracts His attention and a person who fears Him will not lack anything good (vv. 9-10). Based on his personal experiences in his walk with God, David affirmed that the Lord redeems His servants; and no one who takes refuge in Him will be forsaken (v. 22). David's admonition was that those who seek protection outside God should turn to Him and those who take refuge in the Lord should be steadfast in Him. After all, other sources of refuge are man-made and will fail but God remains constant in His promises of safety for His people. Therefore, just as David encouraged his readers to taste and see the goodness of the Lord, believers are also encouraged to invite unbelievers around them to come out of darkness into the marvellous light of God (Colossians 1:12-13). Our personal testimony can be a strong weapon for winning them to the Lord.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. Where do people seek refuge during turbulent times? Discuss the implications based on David's counsel.
    2. Let a member share how he made the Lord his refuge during a turbulent period and the outcome.
  3. Christ, A Worthy High Priest Hebrews 2:17-18

    The author of Hebrews focuses on Jesus Christ as the One who leads us to salvation through His death (Hebrews 2:1-16). Invariably, Jesus has helped the descendants of Abraham. Christ became like His brothers and sisters that He might become their faithful and merciful High Priest in His service to God, and in making atonement for their sins. Ultimately, He is most qualified to help those who are being tempted because He has been tempted and He also suffered through His death on the cross.

    Jesus Christ is the worthy High Priest whose death has brought eternal salvation to humankind. This is why His ministry is different from the Old Testament priests whose duty was only to lead the people back to God through the processes of burnt and sin offerings, among other sacrifices. However, these high priests were not perfect in their ways; hence, the need to make an offering for their own sins first before making intercession for the people (Leviticus 16:8). Therefore, their ministry was deficient (Hebrews 7:23). But Jesus is a worthy High Priest who has been “... made like his brothers in every way ...” (v. 17). Automatically, we have become God's sons and daughters. Unlike the Old Testament high priests, Jesus did not sin when tempted and so He is able to express sympathy concerning our weaknesses (Hebrews 4:15). Instead, He overcame temptation and by this singular act, He understands and sympathises with our weaknesses, thereby making it possible for Him to make intercession for us in the presence of God (1 John 2:1-2).

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. What qualified Jesus and made Him able to help those who are being tempted? v. 18
    2. State at least three differences between the Old Testament priests and Jesus, the High Priest
    3. What benefit do believers have since Jesus is the Great High Priest?

Prayer Points

  • Lord, forgive me for my lack of trust in You, in time past.
  • Father, help me to commit my fears to You and trust You as my Refuge and Deliverer.

Fellowship and Ministry Building Activities

  • Make a list of at least five things you can thank God for in the last few months and five things to thank God for in the lives of the children around you.
  • Compose a song of thanksgiving to God for His faithfulness and teach it to others – possibly children. Pray for the children in your church as today is Children's Day.

Take Home

  • God honours and delivers those who fear Him.
  • A man who fears the Lord will not fear circumstances.
  • Jesus is our Great High Priest who intercedes on our behalf.
  • Jesus understands and sympathises with our weaknesses.

title: JUSTICE AND SABBATH LAWS
message:
June 3, 2018

JUSTICE AND SABBATH LAWS

Devotional Reading: Psalm 10

Background Scripture/Lesson Scripture: Matthew 12:1-14

Golden Text

If you had known what these words mean, “I desire mercy, not sacrifice.” ' you would not have condemned the innocent. Matthew 12:7

Objectives :

By the end of the lesson, class members should be able to:

  • Explain the purpose of observing the Sabbath
  • Mention some traditions in their church that are at variance with the will of God.
  • Discuss how their religious rituals can be adjusted to accommodate people in need.

INTRODUCTION

It was the last Saturday of the month, usually scheduled for cleaning exercise throughout the country. There is always restriction of movement for a period of time with the expectation that people will tidy up their environment. To enforce the law, security agents are always on ground to arrest and, probably, prosecute offenders. However, it has been observed that enforcing the law has brought pain and sorrow to the general public. On one occasion, a pregnant woman in labour was denied movement to the hospital for breaking the law of the State. The woman who was in serious pains was left unattended to for several hours until the intervention of a higher security officer who permitted the husband to quickly take the woman to the hospital to save her life and that of her unborn child. The law enforcement officers were only interested in enforcing the law of the State without considering the dangerous state of the pregnant woman. What is your judgment about their action? To what extent is their action justifiable?

The question about strict observance of the Sabbath was one of the disputes between Jesus and the Pharisees as recorded in Chapter 12 of the gospel of Matthew. The Old Testament had strict laws about the observance of the Sabbath for the children of Israel. In the book of Deuteronomy, God told the people that they were free to eat the grapes in someone else's vineyard but none should be taken away. Also, they are free to eat the corn that are plucked by hand and not with a sickle (Deuteronomy 23:24-25). Unfortunately, the Jewish tradition added other restrictions to these laws to the point that it eventually voided God's original purpose of commanding that the Sabbath day be kept holy (Exodus 20:10). Today's lesson focuses on the argument that ensued between Jesus and the Pharisees over the observance of the Sabbath with regards to Jesus' disciples who plucked some ears of corn from a field when they were hungry. In His response, Jesus affirmed that the Son of Man is Lord of the Sabbath.

THE LESSON EXPLAINED

  1. Jesus Accused of Breaking the Law of the Sabbath Matthew 12:1-8

    Jesus and His disciples travelled through a particular grain field on a Sabbath, in the course of proclaiming the Gospel. Most likely because of the long journey, the disciples became hungry and began to pluck some heads of grain and eat them. But the action displeased the Pharisees. They assumed that the disciples had broken the Law of Moses, which forbids reaping on the Sabbath. They said to Jesus, "Look! Your disciples are doing what is unlawful on the Sabbath." (v. 2) In His response to counter their accusation, Jesus cited two examples: firstly, He made reference to David and his companions who ate the bread offered to God which ought to be eaten only by the priests (1 Samuel 21:1-6; Leviticus 24:5-9). Secondly, the priests in the Temple who broke the Sabbath law by desecrating the day and yet were not guilty. He made them realise in verse 6 that the kingdom of heaven is far more important than the temple rituals. In other words, what He desires is kindness and not animal sacrifices. Therefore, no one should be condemned, especially those who are not guilty after all. Jesus' rhetorical questions meant that the disciples were not guilty of any offence because He knows how best the laws of the Sabbath should be kept. His quotation of Hosea 6:6 is an indirect way of reinterpreting the law of the Sabbath for the Pharisees. Their understanding that God desires mercy above sacrifice and that the Son of Man (Jesus) is Lord of the Sabbath are key elements of this reinterpretation (vv. 7, 8).

    It should be noted that the disciples of Jesus were not really accused of stealing grains even though they took them from a field that was not theirs. The reason is that the Law of Moses permitted the plucking of grains from a neighbour's field as long as it was done by hand and not with a sickle (Deuteronomy 23:25). According to the Pharisees, they were apparently guilty of reaping (harvesting the grains) on the Sabbath, thereby contravening the Law of Moses. However, since Jesus and His disciples are greater than the Temple (v. 6), He automatically has the authority to override the normal Sabbath regulations. In essence, Jesus established that biblical principles should have preference over ritual observances (Hosea 6:6). Customs and traditions, no matter how spiritual they seem should not hinder believers from doing good or meeting the needs of other people.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. Discuss some traditions in our churches today that can be regarded as rituals.
    2. Jesus said, “for the Son of Man is Lord of the Sabbath.” Discuss.
  2. Jesus Accused of Healing on a Sabbath Matthew 12:9-12

    When Jesus left the Pharisees, He went straight into the synagogue as it was His habit and there, He met a man who had a shrivelled hand. There, a group of people (probably the same group of Pharisees) asked Him, "Is it lawful to heal on the Sabbath?" It is obvious that they were looking for a reason to accuse Jesus again of breaking the Sabbath, since the Pharisees claimed it was a sin to heal on the sabbath. Jesus, however, justified his action through an illustration that if they could lift out their sheep when it falls into a pit on the Sabbath, they should know that a person's life is much more valuable than that of a sheep; therefore, it is lawful to do good and heal a sick person on the Sabbath. In the gospel of Luke, Jesus also defended the healing of a man with dropsy on the Sabbath. He, however, made it difficult for them to protest by posing a rhetorical question that left them speechless: 'If one of you has a child or an ox that falls into a well on the Sabbath day, will you not immediately pull it out?' (Luke 14:1-6).

    The Pharisees, and the teachers of the law were fond of accusing Jesus, especially in relation to the violation of the Mosaic law. However, Jesus did not plan to abolish the law, rather He gave it its full meaning. The fact is that He only condemned the hypocritical lifestyle of the Pharisees who were only concerned about strict observance without fair dealings. The implication for believers is that we should balance our understanding of observance of the law and justice. If the keeping of any law will cause us to ill-treat people, we should know that it is lawful to do good on the Sabbath. We should also ask for God's wisdom to make us do what is right.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. Is the command to observe the Sabbath still relevant to contemporary Christians?
    2. Discuss some funny questions unbelievers ask with the intention of ridiculing Jesus and His followers and how to handle such situations.
  3. Jesus' Healing Power Manifested Matthew 12:13-14

    The ministry of Jesus waxed stronger in the face of oppositions. Having declared that it is lawful to do good on the Sabbath (v. 12), Jesus commanded the man with shrivelled hand saying, "Stretch out your hand" and because the man obeyed, his hand was completely restored just like the other (v. 13). Instead of the Pharisees to rejoice over the healing miracle, they went out and plotted how they might kill Jesus. To these hard-hearted people, a common deed of kindness on the Sabbath was a crime, which deserves death. The Pharisees generally believed that acts of mercy were allowed only on the Sabbath if the life of the sick person was in danger. However, it is obvious that the life of this man was not in danger thus the healing of the man so infuriated them that they planned to kill Jesus. This incident is also mentioned in Mark 3:1-6 and Luke 6:6-11.

    Even today, there are traditions in some churches that have made it difficult for people to render help to those in need and the result is friction and division among God's people. Instead of such people to allow the Spirit of God to direct them, they simply hold on to such traditions/protocol and allow people to suffer unnecessarily. Therefore, Christians must be mindful and allow the Spirit of God to lead them as they consider situations in which they can set aside traditions for the sake of showing compassion, according to Jesus' explanation. Since Sabbath is a day of rest, believers should pay attention to every effort or act that will foster rest and deliverance from sin, sickness, unemployment, poverty and the like.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. Discuss the implication of Jesus\' healing miracle on the Sabbath in this passage and how this affects believers of today.
    2. Discuss ways Christians can handle unnecessary criticism.

Prayer Points

  • Help me, Lord, to identify some customs and rituals that have hindered me from showing compassion to the needy.
  • Teach me the best way to observe the Sabbath without ignoring its real meaning.
  • Forgive me where I have considered temple rituals more important than acts of kindness.

Fellowship and Ministry Building Activities

  • Read Romans 14:5-6 and Colossians 2:16, and discuss the implications of these verses on Christians' observance of the Sabbath.

Take Home

  • Believers should endeavour to set aside some rules in order to help those in need.
  • Christians should be ready to show compassion rather than mere compliance to rituals
  • Jesus is truly the Lord of the Sabbath.
  • Believers should be cautious of what they say and who they criticise.

title: PARABLES OF GOD\'S JUST KINGDOM
message:
June 10, 2018

PARABLES OF GOD'S JUST KINGDOM

Devotional Reading: Psalm 78:1-8

Background Scripture: Matthew 13:24-43

Lesson Scripture: Matthew 13:24-33

Golden Text

Let both grow together until the harvest. At that time I will tell the harvesters: First collect the weeds and tie them in bundles to be burned; then gather the wheat and bring it into my barn.'” Matthew 13:30

Objectives :

By the end of the lesson, class members should be able to:

  • Explain the meaning of the good seed and weeds in the parable of the weeds and how we can identify them.
  • Identify the deceptive and destructive attempts of the Devil to frustrate the expansion of God's kingdom.Compare and contrast the status/fate of saints and sinners in this contemporary world and on the Judgment Day.

INTRODUCTION

Mrs Esther Okon is a children’s pastor. She is known to be gifted in teaching. Children always love to be in her class because of her interesting illustrations and display of appropriate visuals. Because of her skilfulness, she is popularly called "Iya ewe" meaning, the mother of children. So, her car is always filled with all kinds of images (wooden, metal, paper, and plastic of various shapes and colours), toys, fruits both fresh and dried. According to her, the use of visuals as teaching aids helps children to understand the lesson better than merely teaching without any representation.

A parable is a sort of extended metaphor or story, a comparison which illustrates spiritual truths with familiar objects. Jesus Christ, the Great Teacher, taught His people different parables about the kingdom of God. He spoke in parables because of the spiritual dullness of the people (Matthew 13:10-15; Luke 8:4), and to fulfil the prophecy of Prophet Isaiah which says, "I will use parables when I speak to them; I will tell them things unknown since the creation of the world" (v. 14). Particularly, chapter 13 of the gospel of Matthew records 7 parables which teach and explain some lessons about the kingdom of God.Today's lesson focuses on the fact that we shall all reap what we have sown, whether good or bad.

THE LESSON EXPLAINED

  1. The Good Seeds and the Wheat Matthew 13:24-26

    The parable of the weeds among the wheat is the second parable Jesus told in this chapter. He likened the kingdom of heaven to a man who sowed good seed on his field. While everyone was asleep at night, the enemy came and sowed weeds among the wheat. Because time will always show the true nature of everything, the two plants sprouted, and both the weeds and the wheat become recognisable. In Jesus' explanation of the parable, the one who sowed good seed is the Son of Man, that is, Jesus Himself. The field is the world, the good seed sown are people of the kingdom, the weeds are people of the world, and the enemy who sowed the weeds is the Devil.

    The implication of this parable is that believers are kingdom people and are bound to live in this world with sinners and wicked people. However, we must live as citizens of heaven in the kingdom of this world, sprouting as good seeds with godly fruit of righteousness (1 John 2:15-17). Just as the wheat and weeds were distinct in their appearance, the world should be able to identify Christians by their fruits, which should be void of hypocrisy. We must ask for the grace to co-exist with evil in the world, especially in our immediate society and workplace while we maintain the goodness of the godly nature in us without being contaminated or corrupted in the world. Applying this grace must also be done with the understanding that our chief enemy who placed the weeds around us is the Devil. We must, therefore, resist him so that he will flee from us.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. How can we identify genuine Christians and hypocritical people or wicked ones around us?
    2. Discuss some of the ways the Devil deceives and destroys God's good plans and purposes for His people today and how to avoid such strategies.
  2. The Harvest of Weeds and the Wheat Matthew 13:27-30

    According to verse 27, the servants were shocked at the appearance of the weeds among the wheat and out of curiosity asked the master, "Sir, didn't you sow good seed in your field? Where then did the weeds come from?' The good seeds represent the righteous and the weeds are the evil or unrighteous people planted mischievously by the Devil. Obviously, the weed planted among the wheat was the handiwork of the enemy to destroy the good work of the owner of the field. The servant immediately sought permission to pull out the weeds but the master would rather allow both to grow to full maturity before separation. The reason for his decision was the fear of mistakenly uprooting the wheat alongside the weed. Then, while the weeds are tied in bundles to be burned, the wheat will be gathered for storage (v. 30).

    This parable is meant to teach that the 'children of the evil one', which symbolise the weeds are destined for damnation with no opportunity to change their destiny. The phrase “while everyone else was asleep,'' shows the determination of the enemy to frustrate the good plans and purpose of God for His people. Though the wheat and weeds would be allowed to grow together in the same field and under the same weather condition, they would not have equal fate. Ultimately while the weeds would be gathered in bundles and be burnt, the wheat would be stored safely in the barn for future use. The harvest refers to the end of age, which will be executed by angels (harvesters). The important lessons are:

    • The good seed symbolise the righteous.
    • The reaping of the unrighteous symbolises the judgment of God that will be meted out by fire, which will result in weeping.
    • At the end of time, the co-existence of believers and unbelievers will end.
    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. What does the decision of the owner tell us about God? (1 Peter 3:9)
    2. What moral lesson should we keep in mind in light of the separation of the righteous and evil?
  3. The Parable of the Mustard Seed and the Yeast Matthew 13:31-33

    Jesus did not relent in His effort to make known the nature of the kingdom of heaven to the people. As He continued in His teaching, He used different analogies to illustrate and drive home His point for the sake of clarity. As it is seen in the passage, He told them another parable. Just like the parable of the weeds, Jesus likened the kingdom of heaven to a man who planted a mustard seed in his field. The mustard seed, according to verse 32, is the smallest of all seeds but it usually turns out to be the biggest of all plants that its branches accommodate the birds of the air. Furthermore, Jesus described the kingdom of heaven and likened it to a woman who mixes some quantity of yeast until the whole dough of flour rises (v. 33). The ancient equivalent of yeast was a lump of leavened dough saved from the previous baking of bread whereby a small quantity will easily make a large quantity of flour rise. Though the word yeast in the Scripture is most times used to mean corruption or evil that pervades the whole, it here represents the secret way the kingdom of God will spread. Jesus was particularly interested in making people understand the nature of His kingdom and what it takes to enter into it.

    Some people, however, believe that these parables teach about the combination of the evil and righteousness in the church while others see it as a vivid image of the startling growth and spread of God's kingdom. However, it is certain that this parable explains the small beginning of Christ's kingdom, its gradual and unnoticeable growth in the individual and eventually the transforming power of the Gospel in individual lives and nations, which is God's purpose and plan for the church. Even though the spread of the Gospel may seem slow, it will definitely spread through the world. In addition, the reference to birds perching on the tree may indicate that people of different social, ethnic, racial, economic and religious backgrounds will find rest in it.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. What truth do these parables reveal about the kingdom of God?
    2. Discuss some hindrances to the spread of the Gospel and the roles of the Church in the spread of the Gospel.
    3. Describe the different ways Christians can influence their communities for the sake of spreading the gospel message to unbelievers.

Prayer Points

Fellowship and Ministry Building Activities

Take Home

title: JESUS TEACHES ABOUT JUSTICE
message:
June 17, 2018

JESUS TEACHES ABOUT JUSTICE

Devotional Reading: Mark 7:1-13

Background Scripture: Matthew 15:1-9; Mark 7:1-13

Lesson Scripture: Matthew 15:1-9

Golden Text

"'These people honour me with their lips, but their hearts are far from me. Matthew 15:8

Objectives :

By the end of the lesson, class members should be able to:

  • Describe some ways people break the laws of God for selfish reasons.
  • Identify some principles that should guide Christians in observing the law
  • Verbally appreciate the superiority of Christ over all.

INTRODUCTION

"Papa judge", as he was fondly called, was a prominent and retired judge. He had had the opportunity to serve in various capacities during his service years with different awards pasted on the wall of his well decorated library. It was another Christmas holiday and 'papa judge' hosted his grandchildren. Every day after breakfast, papa would go to the library with his grandson, Peter. One day, out of curiosity, Peter asked his grandfather the reason for his interest in reading when heno longer goes to court. With a smile on his face, 'papa judge' nodded his head and explained that he needed to read widely so that he could interpret the laws of the land correctly which have been violated and misinterpreted in different cases. He further explained that laws, as good as they seem, can be misinterpreted and applied wrongly.

The rulers at Jerusalem had already determined in their hearts to kill Jesus probably because of His popularity in Galilee and, therefore, sent a delegation of Pharisees to condemn whatever Jesus did and make Him and His teachings unacceptable to the people. The practice of hand washing that is referred to in this passage was purely a religious ceremony. However, Jesus made them realise that such ceremonial cleansing has no connection with defilement for real defilement is of the heart. He denounced them for violating the Word of God by some of their traditions of human origin (v. 6).

THE LESSON EXPLAINED

  1. The Pharisees Accused Jesus Matthew 15:1-2

    The story in the passage is another controversy with the religious leaders in which the behaviour of Jesus' disciples contrasted the tradition of the Jews who believed in the washing of hands before each meal for the purpose of purity. Jesus had just walked on water and had become more popular because of the healing miracles He performed (Matthew 14:34-36). Unfortunately, some Pharisees and teachers of the law who had heard of the great miracles came from Jerusalem and asked Jesus a question concerning their old tradition. They said, “Why do your disciples break the tradition of the elders? They don't wash their hands before they eat” (v. 2). The Pharisees questioned the reason Jesus would approve of such behaviour, when He knew that the law forbade it. The Pharisees were a powerful sect that took pride in their strict observance of the Law of Moses and, therefore, compelled others to do same without due consideration for justice. It is not unlikely that they were always on the lookout for Jesus and His disciples to identify the next tradition or rules they would break. They had constituted themselves an opposition party and from time to time, they monitored Jesus and His disciples looking for an opportunity to accuse Him.

    According to the passage, the Pharisees hinged their argument on the tradition of elders. The practice of the washing of hands before each meal was a prescribed religious rite, which is assumed to make a person ritually clean (v. 20) and not just a matter of hygiene. Similarly, there are some church rules and traditions that some believers take pride in because observing them makes them feel more spiritual than others. Their 'spiritual arrogance' often reflect in the way they belittle or condemn those who do not live up to their own man-made standards. These often lead to incorrect interpretations of the Scripture such that priority is placed on following rules and regulations of men without due attention to the issues of the heart.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. Why do some Christians demonstrate their knowledge of God's Word in an arrogant and critical manner?
    2. Some Christians misinterpret Gods Word purposely to suit their situation. How can this be avoided, especially in this end time? (2 Timothy 2:15; Joshua 1:8
  2. Jesus' Response to the Accusation Matthew 15:3-6

    Jesus responded to the accusation of the Pharisees and the teachers of law appropriately. He questioned their disobedience to God's command when He said, 'Honour your father and mother” and “anyone who curses his father or mother must be put to death" __ a reference to two Old Testament passages (Exodus 20:12; Deuteronomy 5:16). Surprisingly, these religious leaders taught that anything dedicated to God's service was sacred and could not be used for any other purpose, even to honour one's parents. According to Jesus, such behaviour is equated with disregard to God's command in order to follow their own teaching. In other words, the action of the disciples of not washing their hands before meal had not in any way defiled them despite what the Pharisees taught and believed.

    The commandment to honour one's father and mother is repeated by Jesus in His response to the question of the rich young ruler (Matthew 19:19). It was also emphasised in Paul's letter to the brethren in Ephesus in his effort to promote family relationship (Ephesians 6:2). Even though the Pharisees were strict in observing the law, Jesus categorically rejected the practice of using an aspect of the Bible to nullify another. Even today, there are some traditions or rules that have been adopted by some churches but are not scriptural and unfortunately, such traditions have become hindrances to true followers of Jesus. But in His explanation, Jesus endorsed care for one's parents as an important aspect of justice and mercy. The major lesson for believers in this passage is that we should not be tempted to comply with traditions that are not scriptural or helpful in any way. Instead, we should balance our obedience to religious traditions with compliance to biblical laws. Any tradition that makes us to neglect or nullify another biblical responsibility should be revisited and reviewed for holistic compliance with the Scriptures, the ultimate standard for Christian living and practice.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. To what extent should Christians keep the law and at the same time show mercy and promote justice?
    2. It seems there is a decline in the old practice of honouring one's parents. Discuss the likely causes and the various ways Christians can honour their parents, whether biological or spiritual.
  3. Jesus' Conclusion Matthew 15:7-9

    Jesus continued in His discourse with the Pharisees and the teachers of the law who came from Jerusalem to ask Him questions about the action of His disciples who did not wash their hands before their meal. Having rebuked them for disobeying God's Word for the sake of their tradition, He made them realise the implication of misinterpreting the law with regard to caring for their parents. Jesus, therefore, referred to the Pharisees as hypocrites according to Isaiah's prophecy. Their hypocrisy is seen in honouring God with their lips and not with their hearts. Consequently, their worship is in vain and made up of rules taught by men (Isaiah 29:13).

    In His conclusion about the practice of hand washing before meal, Jesus condemned the act absolutely because it was a doctrine taught by men. According to the New International Version (NIV) Study Bible, after the Babylonian captivity experience, the Jewish rabbis started to make detailed rules and regulations that constituted the interpretation of the Law of Moses that would guide the people. The laws were handed down from one generation to another but Jesus never hesitated to denounce such laws and age-long tradition whenever it undermined scriptural principles. He often explained that keeping the law without the Holy Spirit, who gives spiritual understanding, is vain. Similarly, because of our desire to be more faithful to God in our service, Christians should endeavour to maintain God's standard instead of adhering to some traditions that are constituted and taught by men. The implication is that such traditions can serve as a barrier to the spiritual growth of the individual and the church of God at large.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. Ask a church member to recall a change that the church made in the past and how it has affected the growth of the church and the entire members.
    2. Discuss what lip service means as it is used in the passage.

Prayer Points

  • Help me, O God, not to be associated with those who break Your laws.
  • Remove from me every form of hypocritical lifestyle so that I will not be a hindrance to the spread of the Gospel.
  • I receive grace to always worship you in spirit and in truth.

Fellowship and Ministry Building Activities

  • Let each class member list some inimical church traditions and brainstorm on how such traditions can be reversed for the purpose of growing the church.

Take Home

  • When we misinterpret the Bible, we misrepresent God.
  • True religion is showing God's justice and mercy at the same time.
  • Christians should endeavour to balance their compliance to church rituals with seeking justice for others.
  • Believers should seek to obey God's commandments out of a heartfelt devotion and not just mere acts of observance.

title: REAPING GOD'S JUSTICE
message:
June 24, 2018

REAPING GOD'S JUSTICE

Devotional Reading: Luke 6:20-26

Background Scripture: Luke 16:19-31; John 5:24-30

Lesson Scripture: Luke 16:19-31

Golden Text

"But Abraham replied, 'Son, remember that in your lifetime you received your good things, while Lazarus received bad things, but now he is comforted here and you are in agony. Luke 16:25

Objectives :

By the end of the lesson, class members should be able to:

  • Compare and contrast the life of Lazarus and the rich man while on earth and in eternity.
  • Discuss the implication of depending on material things at the detriment of the salvation of our souls.
  • Make a verbal/written commitment to be faithful stewards of all their possessions.

INTRODUCTION

Sister Favour Asabor is passionate about the salvation of lost souls. She goes out on personal evangelism from time to time despite her busy schedule at school. One day, she shared an experience of her encounter with a young man who questioned the reality of heaven and hell in spite of her effort to convince him using the story of Lazarus and the rich man. Funny enough, the young man asserted that heaven and hell exist here on earth. He added that the rich who live in luxury are already in heaven while the poor who live in penury are in hell. Unfortunately, this is the assumption of some people about the reality of heaven and hell. Some people presume that God will not be so wicked to allow them go to hell fire, and others depend on their cleverness to dodge hell and go to heaven.

The story of the rich man and Lazarus is a popular one that describes how our love for material things and comfort can either make or mar our relationship with God and fellow human beings. It also deals with our response to God, whether in wealth or poverty, and how this response affects our understanding about God and eternity. Today's passage focuses on the type of life that Lazarus and the rich man lived before they died and their experiences after death.

THE LESSON EXPLAINED

  1. The Rich Man and Lazarus on Earth Luke 16:19-21

    Jesus told the story of two men whose economic status dictated the way they lived while on earth. The rich man refused to use even a little of his riches to help the poor man – Lazarus. The reference to him as wearing purple clothes indicates his royal and noble background. The man was truly rich and comfortable. In contrast, Lazarus was a beggar who suffered from poor health and hunger thus he always sat at the gate of the rich man waiting for an opportunity to eat the crumbs from his table.

    Lazarus might have been abandoned by friends and family members. Consequently, he decided to stay at the gate of the rich man with the hope that he would get help. He longed to feed on the crumbs that fell from the table of the rich man who definitely had more than enough to eat and cater for others. Unfortunately for Lazarus, the crumbs became food for dogs. Instead of the rich man to use his God- given resources to bless the poor, he was indifferent.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. It is possible that Lazarus' ill-health occasioned his poverty. What does this mean for able-bodied people who have become beggars in order to make ends meet?
    2. What are the ways some individuals use their wealth today that is similar to that of the rich man in the story.
  2. Life in Paradise and in Hell Luke 16:22-26

    One thing that is common to everyone is death. A time came when both the rich man and Lazarus died but their destinations after death were different. Apparently, the rich man would have been buried amid pomp and pageantry, tributes and praises, while Lazarus' death would have gone unnoticed and uncelebrated as no reference was made to his burial except that he was carried by angels to Abraham's bosom. In other words, Lazarus was given a place of honour and exaltation next to Abraham in paradise where the righteous are kept till the final judgment. While in great torment in hell, the rich man saw Lazarus in Abraham's bosom. He was surprised and so he cried out with a loud voice, 'Father Abraham, have pity on me and send Lazarus to dip the tip of his finger in water and cool my tongue, because I am in agony in this fire.' (v. 24) Unfortunately, Abraham's reply was not favourable to the rich man; he reminded him of the contrast between the life of luxury and poverty they both lived while on earth. The passage shows the remarkable difference in destinations and experiences after death. For example:

    • The rich man was in hell where he was tormented but Lazarus was comforted in the bosom of Abraham. There will be torment in hell for sinners, and comfort in heaven for the redeemed.
    • The rich man lived in isolation but Lazarus had companion.
    • The agony of the blazing heat of hell made the rich man beg for a drop of water but Lazarus was comfortable.
    • The rich man regretted his self-indulgence and self-centredness but Lazarus had no regrets from his previous life.
    • The rich man was trapped in hell with no opportunity of escape, mercy or leniency while Lazarus was happily received by Father Abraham. Little wonder the author of the book of James emphasised the fate of the rich when they fail to treat the poor around them justly (James 5:1ff). He, thereafter, warned them to repent and weep because of the coming misery.

    The reality of hell should make saints and sinners alike fear God and live in the consciousness of judgement after death. No one can make decision about eternity after death. Life on earth determines one’s destination and there is no opportunity of crossing over the great gulf between heaven and hell.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. How can we convince those who claim that there is no life beyond this earth?
    2. Some Christians think Lazarus went to paradise because he was poor and the rich man went to hades because he was rich. How does the Bible address this impression or notion?
    3. A luxurious and materialistic lifestyle hinders Christian generosity. Discuss.
  3. The Rich Man's Request Luke 16:27-31

    The rich man who was already in great torment finally acknowledged the difficulty of crossing from hell to Abraham's bosom and so, his immediate need for water was not granted. Consequently, he shifted his attention from what could give him comfort and expressed fear about the fate of his brothers. He passionately begged Abraham to send Lazarus back to the earth to warn his five brothers that hell is real so that they can repent while they are still alive and thereby escape the torment of hell (vv. 28, 30). Of course, his request showed his ignorance of the fact that the dead cannot do anything to help those who are alive. Abraham responded that the rich man's brothers could avoid the danger of hell if they live by the Law of Moses and the Prophets (v. 29). The phrase 'Moses and the Prophets' refer to the Law of Moses and the preachers. Nevertheless, the rich man persisted and reasoned that if someone were to rise from the dead and go to them, they would turn from their sins but Abraham told him that proofs from a dead person would still not convince them if the preaching of God’s word would not bring about a change in them.

    From the passage, we can see that the rich man, when he found himself in hell, regretted his indifference to the plight of Lazarus and failure to prepare for eternity in heaven while on earth. James 5 also corroborates the unpalatable fate of the rich when they fail to treat the poor around them justly. Therefore, the challenge from this lesson is that believers should respond with compassion to the needs of the poor in their churches, families and communities and be ready to live by the truth and standard of God's Word. We should emulate the early church in which the brethren were together and had everything in common. (Acts 2:42-47). However, it should be noted that God is not interested in the death of any sinner but His desire is that all will come to repentance and be saved (2 Peter 3:9).

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. Discuss how believers can save the souls of their loved ones and others like the rich man desired in today's passage.
    2. What other lessons can we draw from the life of the rich man in today’s lesson?
    3. Discuss the importance of social ministry in the church.

    4. Prayer Points

    • Thank God for His daily provision for you and members of your family.
    • Pray that God will bless you so that you will be able to meet the needs of people around you, no matter how little your income is.
    • Pray that God will deal with the problem of selfishness, greed and poverty in our churches.

    Fellowship and Ministry Building Activities

    • Class members should compile the needs of the poor in the church/community and discuss how these needs can be met. Send the result to the social ministry department of the church through the pastor.
    • Each member should share the truths about hell and heaven and God's plan of salvation with two souls.

    Take Home

    • Christians should be able to manage their wealth in ways that demonstrate their faith.
    • It is our responsibility to care for the sick and poor, as Christians.
    • Heaven and hell are real.
    • Do not ignore God's offer of salvation now that you have the opportunity.

title: PARABLE OF THE UNFORGIVING SERVANT
message:
July 1, 2018

PARABLE OF THE UNFORGIVING SERVANT

Devotional Reading: Colossians 3:12-17

Background Scripture / Lesson Scripture: Matthew 18:21-35

Golden Text

'Shouldn't you have had mercy on your fellow servant just as I had mercy on you? Matthew 18:33

Objectives :

By the end of the lesson, class members should be able to:

  • State some reasons why they think forgiveness is important.
  • Discuss the consequences of unforgiveness.
  • Resolve to forgive someone whom they have grudges against.

INTRODUCTION

We live in a world where resentment and unforgiveness are the order of the day. People often ask questions about the possibility of actually forgiving and forgetting and sometimes, the number of times one can forgive, especially when one is seriously hurt. A story was once told of a man who, as a result of careless driving, crashed into someone else's vehicle and damaged the rear window. The owner of the vehicle who introduced himself as a Senior Advocate of Nigeria (SAN) pardoned him having begged for forgiveness. Unfortunately, the same man refused to forgive an okada rider who broke his side mirror some days later. Despite the man's plea for forgiveness, he insisted that the mirror should be replaced with the option of reporting the case to the police. The man eventually paid for the replacement of the side mirror before he released him but while he was going, a voice spoke and reminded him of his experience few days back and how he obtained mercy. How will you describe this man?

Someone rightly said, "Forgiveness is the act of failing to revenge when the opportunity comes." It also means to overlook a wrong that has been done. Therefore, it can be likened to amnesty (official pardon) for someone who has done you wrong. The summary of today\'s lesson is that forgiveness is not just a one-way action from God to a repentant sinner; it involves the whole community of God's people, their ability to forgive one another, notwithstanding the number of times. It is also a reminder that forgiveness is vital in our relationships in spite of the number of times we may have been hurt or ill-treated. Therefore, we are expected to forgive and not act like the servant who received forgiveness, yet failed to forgive his offender.

THE LESSON EXPLAINED

  1. A Servant Receives Forgiveness Matthew 18:21-27

    Jesus had just addressed the issue of the greatest in the kingdom of heaven and reminded His disciples that entrance into the kingdom is granted to those who claim no rights before God but accept His gifts gladly like little children. From verse 21, He told them a parable about the unforgiving servant in response to Peter's question on the number of times forgiveness can be offered. Jesus answered, "I tell you, not seven times, but seventy times seven .... (v. 22) To further explain the importance of forgiveness, Jesus likened the kingdom of heaven to a king who wanted to settle accounts with his servants when suddenly his debtor was brought before him. Perhaps as it was their custom then, the master ordered that he and his entire household be sold to settle the debt. However, the servant fell on his knees and passionately begged for more time to settle his debt. Interestingly, the king had pity on him, cancelled the debt and set him free from the burden. Obviously, the king in the parable represents God who always forgives our sins while the debt represents our sins.

    The issue of forgiveness is one of the hard teachings people find difficult to practice, even Christians. Some people who have been seriously hurt sometimes find it difficult to forgive. Instead, they prefer to revenge whenever they have the opportunity to do so and even wish their enemies dead. Peter knew the importance of forgiveness but possibly felt that there must be a limit, thus, he asked the number of times forgiveness could be granted. In fact, his suggestion of seven times is an indication that he is aware of the act of forgiving. However, he was stunned at Jesus' response of seventy times seven meaning that there is no limit to forgiveness. After all, God forgives whenever we sin against Him. In the same vein, God expects Christians to forgive one another because they have also received forgiveness from Him. This was Paul's understanding in his letter to the church in Colossae when he said, "Bear with each other and forgive whatever grievances you may have against one another. Forgive as the Lord forgave you." (Colossians 3:13).

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. Why do some Christians pray for the death of their enemies as a way of revenge?
    2. Jesus told Peter to forgive his offenders seventy times seven. Is it possible for someone to offend another person four hundred and ninety times?
    3. Let a member of the class share his/her experience of how God helped him/her to forgive a grievous/hurting offence
  2. A Forgiven Servant Refuses to Forgive Matthew 18:28-31

    One of the things that characterise the life of humans is the urge to revenge after an offence. According to the passage, the servant was ungrateful and had forgotten he received forgiveness as a result of his inability to pay his debt. When he found his fellow servant who owed him a hundred denarii, he dragged him and asked for his money. Like he had done to the king and received pardon, the fellow servant fell to the ground and begged him for more time to pay his debt but he refused the appeal. He had him thrown into jail pending when he would be able to settle his debt. The man who had been forgiven his huge debt could not forgive his debtor despite the plea. Afterall, the amount owed him is insignificant compared to the one he owed his master for which he was forgiven.

    The parable of the wicked servant portrays the attitude of some Christians who do not see the need to forgive their offenders even though they receive forgiveness from God from time to time. The man failed to understand that the mercy he received from his master put him under obligation to act with mercy to his fellow servant, no matter the amount he owed him. Of course, his fellow servants were witnesses to his meanness towards his debtor (v. 31). They were so grieved that they reported him to their master. Jesus knew that it was natural for humankind to retaliate every wrong done to them; hence, He concluded His teaching with the emphasis to forgive people their sins so that we too will receive forgiveness.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. Why did the servant fail to forgive his debtor after he had been forgiven his debt?
    2. Discuss some steps one can take to live amicably with someone who is unforgiving.
  3. Consequences of Unforgiveness Matthew 18:32-35

    The unforgiving servant did not know that every negative attitude or action naturally attracts consequences. He decided to throw his debtor into prison until he is able to settle his debt. The wicked act was reported to the king who had earlier shown him mercy for his inability to pay his own debt. The master was furious about his action and said to him, " Shouldn't you have had mercy on your fellow servant just as I had on you?" (v. 33) By implication, the king expected the servant to pardon his fellow servant by virtue of the fact that he had also been pardoned and his debt cancelled. In his state of disappointment and anger, the master handed the servant to the jailer to be tortured until he is able to pay back everything he owed him. Jesus concluded the parable by saying, "This is how my heavenly Father will treat each of you unless you forgive your brother from your heart." (v. 35).

    The summary of the lesson is that God expects us to forgive one another, no matter the magnitude of the offence or the number of times. In addition, when we forgive our offenders, we stand the chance of enjoying God's forgiveness. For example, Jesus was emphatic about forgiveness when He taught His disciples the Lord's Prayer. He said, "For if you forgive men when they sin against you, your heavenly Father will also forgive you." (Matthew 6:14) But unfortunately, the servant, as described in the passage, lacked the understanding despite the fact that he had enjoyed forgiveness from his master. He failed to understand that forgiveness is an expression of mercy. More so, the fact that he had received forgiveness from his master puts him under compulsion to forgive his fellow servant. It is, therefore, required of Christians to forgive one another and it must emanate from a sincere heart without any intention of vengeance whenever the opportunity arises.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. Based on today's lesson, is it necessary to be begged by our offenders before we forgive them or should we forgive whether or not we are begged?
    2. It is not possible to forgive and forget. Discuss.

Prayer Points

  • Thank God for His mercy and grace always.
  • Pray that God will give you grace to forgive those who have offended you from the depth of your heart.
  • Pray and confess all your sins to God and ask for forgiveness.

Fellowship and Ministry Building Activities

  • Encourage class members to go to persons who have offended them and assure them of their forgiveness this week.
  • They are to report to the class their experiences in the process.

Take Home

  • Christians should forgive their offenders, irrespective of the number of times they have been offended.
  • Forgiveness should not be measured or counted.
  • Believers should forgive because they have been forgiven by God.
  • Unforgiveness is an indication of an uncircumcised heart.

title: JESUS CRITICISES UNJUST LEADERS
message:
July 8, 2018

JESUS CRITICISES UNJUST LEADERS

Devotional Reading: Luke 14:7-14

Background Scripture: Matthew 23

Lesson Scripture: Matthew 23:1-4, 23-26

Golden Text

“The teachers of the law and the Pharisees sit in Moses' seat. So you must obey them and do everything they tell you. But do not do what they do, for they do not practice what they preach.” Matthew 23:2-3

Objectives :

By the end of the lesson, class members should be able to:

  • Explain why leadership should be by example and not merely by giving commands.
  • State two reasons why the scribes and Pharisees were condemned and how such condemnation can be avoided.
  • State three reasons why it is important to practice what we teach and/or preach.

INTRODUCTION

Sometime in 2015, one of the Nigerian newspapers reported what was described as Akinjide's bombshell on Nigerian governors whom he described as ''the biggest thieves''. Chief Richard Akinjide who was a former Minister of Justice accused some politicians of corruption, oppression and hypocritical lifestyles that do not match what they profess. His maxim is a reflection of the mindset of most Nigerians about our leaders at different levels of leadership. Most of them have been openly chided for unjust and irresponsible leadership, which has remained the bane of the development of Nigeria. Particularly, he reiterated that states are broke and unable to pay workers' salaries as a result of the greed of some leaders. They encourage people to be law-abiding but they disregard the law. As a result, they have forgotten that the most important things in life, especially as leaders are “leadership by example, honesty and integrity ....'' He asserted that Nigeria is beset with countless number of problems but concluded by saying that we need the right leadership, if the country must have a strong and stable economy like other developed countries of the world.

Today's lesson focuses on the activities of the Pharisees and scribes whose lifestyle was characterised by injustice and hypocrisy. Instead of providing the right leadership for God's people, they were only concerned with their outward appearances without living by what they taught according to the Law of Moses. They insisted that people must observe certain rules and standards but they dismissed such rules whenever observance becomes personally inconvenient. As a result, Jesus greatly criticised their activities but He, however, affirmed their teachings.

THE LESSON EXPLAINED

  1. Necessary Warning against Imitation Matthew 23:1-4

    The activities of the teachers of the law and the Pharisees were quite noticeable in the days of Jesus. They were the authorised interpreters of the Law of Moses to the people. They represent part of the Jewish leadership of Jesus' day and very often, they criticised Him and some of His activities. As Jesus spoke to the people and His disciples that gathered round Him, He warned them sternly against the activities of these men because of their hypocritical lifestyle. The warning is found in verse 3 where He said, "So you must obey them and do everything they tell you. But do not do what they do, for they do not practice what they preach." The statement implies that Jesus recognised the authenticity of the teachings of the Pharisees but condemned the imitation of their behaviour. Of course, the reason for the warning is clearly stated in verse 4: they put together grave demands and prohibitions that are heavy and difficult to adhere to, yet they were not willing to lift a finger to help the people follow these rules.

    Experience has shown that it is often easy for some leaders to make laws but they find it difficult to keep such laws themselves. What is most important according to the passage is that such laws should be obeyed by all. Jesus' major concern about the actions of the teachers of the law and the Pharisees was hypocrisy that characterised their lives. As those who assumed the place of Moses, they were expected to explain the law and lead God's people by example instead of merely giving commands. But rather, they placed so much emphasis on the rules and regulations that it became a burden to the people. So Jesus warned His disciples and other people who came to Him not to imitate the Pharisees who do not live by what they teach. This same warning is applicable to contemporary Christians to be ready to live by example, in words and character.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. What are some negative qualities you think Christian leaders should rid themselves of in order to avoid the type of condemnation of the Teachers of the Law and Pharisees?
    2. What ways can we show evidence of true and Christian leadership?
  2. The Sin of the Leaders Unveiled Matthew 23:5-8

    Having warned His disciples and the other people that came to Him against imitating the Pharisees and the teachers of the law, Jesus further unveiled their activities. In verses 5-8, He described their activities as mere pretentious show of their religion. According to Him, "Everything they do is done for men to see ... because:

    • They make their phylacteries wide and the tassels on their garments long as a sign of dedication to God. According to New International Version Commentary, phylacteries are boxes that contain four passages (Exodus 13:1-10, 11-16; Deuteronomy 6:4-10 and 11:13-21).
    • They love exalted seats close to the host at banquets and in the synagogues mainly for self-recognition.
    • They love to be greeted with great respect at marketplaces and to be called 'Teacher'. But Jesus warned that they (His disciples and other people who came to Him) should not assume that position or be called 'Teacher'. The reason is clearly stated: because they are all brothers and have just one Master (Jesus, Himself).

    The Pharisees and teachers of the law were condemned because they misinterpreted the command of Moses about keeping the law. Instead of them, as leaders, to live by what they believed and taught, they wrongly applied it to the extent of reducing it to a mere outward ritual, thereby drawing attention to themselves. Without doubt, the essence of the warning was to guard against seeking titles of honour to foster pride as it was with these religious leaders. Little wonder Jesus told His disciples not to be addressed as teachers because it does not attract any merit in the presence of God. Only He (Christ) has the spiritual authority of Rabbi. Christians should, therefore, note that in whatever position God has placed us, we are expected to demonstrate humility and live by example instead of using our office to oppress people and mislead them.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. Discuss what it takes to live a Christian life without drawing attention to ourselves.
    2. What is the implication of Jesus' warning to believers in verse 8?
    3. Which is more important, popularity or dignity?
  3. Jesus Condemns the Leader's Hypocrisy Matthew 23:23-26

    The passage contains seven woes as Jesus condemned the activities of religious leaders using different adjectives to qualify their ungodly behaviour (vv. 13-29). Precisely in verse 23, Jesus denounced them because they only relied on strict obedience of rules about morality and ceremony. They were scrupulous in their concern for tithe, even little garden herbs, while they ignored important matters of righteousness, justice, mercy, and faith, which are God's requirement (Micah 6:8). For that reason, Jesus described them as blind guides who strain out a gnat but swallow a camel (v. 24). They carefully observed the unimportant ritual law and broke the important moral laws of justice. Jesus, therefore, commanded them to clean the inside as a result of which the outside will automatically be made clean.

    Particularly, it should be noted that Jesus did not blame them for their honesty in tithing but for their lack of a sense of spiritual value. In verses 25-26, Jesus denounced them for paying more attention and ensuring that their cups and plates were ceremonially clean, whereas they were full of greed. Christians should know that being religious is not enough. The Scripture says that our righteousness must exceed that of the scribes and Pharisees. We must show that we understand God's demands as it pertains to justice, mercy and righteous living instead of living hypocritical lives. The summary of the lesson is that we must be ready to confront hypocrisy among Christian leaders and officers who outwardly appear to be righteous in their religious performance but are unrighteous in their personal lives. Jesus said that their interest in the outside of the cup and plates is useless because all that is in these vessels have been contaminated by the way they were acquired.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. In what ways can we deal with hypocrisy – finding faults in others and refusing to see personal faults?
    2. What are the things we consider more important in the Church that we need to pay attention to in our relationship with one another?

Prayer Points

  • Help me, O Lord, to be a good leader whose lifestyle is worthy of emulation.
  • O Lord, grant our leaders the grace to lead by example and in humility.
  • Lord Jesus, help us to understand that justice, mercy and faith are more important than total compliance with ritual obligations.

Fellowship and Ministry Building Activities

  • Discuss what Jesus meant in verse 24 and possibly some lessons Christians should learn from it.

Take Home

  • Believers should model sincerity with integrity.
  • Christian leaders should be ready to lead by example.
  • Jesus is more interested in justice and mercy than compliance with ritual obligations.
  • It is sinful to know what is right and fail to do it or pretending as if it is unimportant.

title: THE WIDOW AND THE UNJUST JUDGE
message:
July 15, 2018

THE WIDOW AND THE UNJUST JUDGE

Devotional Reading: Psalm 145:13b-20

Background Scripture / Lesson Scripture: Luke 18:1-8

Golden Text

And will not God bring about justice for his chosen ones, who cry out to him day and night? Luke 18:7a

Objectives :

By the end of the lesson, class members should be able to:

  • State three reasons why it is important to persist in prayers.
  • Explain the difference between a call for vengeance and justice in today's text.
  • Express their resolution to be persistent in prayer like the widow in today's text

INTRODUCTION

Mike Jnr is a 'miracle baby'. He was born after his parents had waited for a period of time. He is handsome and intelligent. He attends one of the best schools in his community. Every day, as his father takes him to school, he points at a well-designed bicycle and asks his father to get one for him. Every morning, he cries and points to the shop where the bicycle is being sold not minding every attempt of his father to make him realise his limited resources. Unfortunately, his father could not change the route because that was the quickest route to his school. Mike Jnr never stopped crying, praying and asking God to bless him with the gift of a bicycle like the one in the shop. One day, as he cried profusely, pointing and calling his father's attention to the direction of the shop, a passer-by stopped and made enquiry about Mike's need. Surprisingly, the man walked into the shop and purchased the bicycle of his choice for him. Out of excitement, his father said, “Your persistence has worked for you."

Persistence in prayer is one of the things Christians find difficult to do. Generally, we believe that God should meet our needs instantly through some individuals. We also forget that there are some people who are mean, they neither know God nor pay attention to the needs of their fellow humankind. They find it difficult to assist others except they are begged for what ordinarily should be handled as a responsibility and matter of importance. Such is the case of the judge in the parable in today's Bible passage. Although the judge proved to be indifferent to the widow's plea for justice, he eventually succumbed to her desire because of her persistence. The focal point of today's lesson is the need for believers to be persistent in their faith and prayers even when it seems there is delayed justice.

THE LESSON EXPLAINED

  1. The Persistent Plea of a Widow Luke 18:1-5

    Jesus had just taught about the coming of the kingdom, which He said will become visible to all humanity. Thereafter, He told them a parable of the widow and the unjust judge. The purpose of the parable was to encourage them to pray and never be discouraged. According to the parable, there was a judge in a certain town who was probably appointed and paid by either Herod or the Romans to preside in their courts. According to verse 2, the judge was described as callous because he neither feared God nor cared about his fellow humankind; perhaps one of those judges who are usually corrupt and known for demanding bribe from a claimant before justice can be served. A woman in the city came to him every day with a plea to grant her justice against her enemy. Even though the judge initially refused to listen to the widow's plea because of his insensitivity and the fact that he did not care about her or anyone else, he finally resolved to grant her request for two reasons: her persistence and probably the fear of being worn out with her constant coming to him (v. 5). Although no one is sure what her issue was about, it is believed that the mention of a single judge probably means that the widow was seeking justice in a financial matter or she may have been denied her inheritance. In other words, she simply demanded justice and not punishment for her enemies.

    There is no doubt that the widow's constant appeal to the unjust judge was already a threat to his reputation in the community; hence, he changed his mind. Nevertheless, Jesus told the parable to illustrate the fact that even when it seems God does not respond immediately to the prayers and requests of His people, He is not indifferent to their plight. This is encouragement for Christians not to give up whenever it appears our prayers are not being attended to. Persistence in prayer is also recommended by Paul in his letter to the church in Rome (Romans 12:12). When we persist in prayer and do not give up, our requests, if in accordance with the will of God, would be granted. Persistence in prayer is a function of our faith in the all-powerful God. Those who depend entirely on God will surely be vindicated and have their prayers answered. Whatever our desire may be, when we persist in prayer and continually seek the face of God, we will receive answers just like the widow in the parable and accomplish the will of God for our lives.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. Discuss other ways Christians can demand their rights e.g. position, money or landed property other than going to court.
    2. Discuss this widow\'s appeal whether it was a call for justice or vengeance.
    3. Where persistence in the demand for our right leads to misunderstanding, what should we do and how else can we handle it?
  2. God's Right Judgment Luke 18:6-8

    As He continued with the parable, Jesus contrasted the attitude and response of the unjust judge with God's. He said, "And will not God bring about justice for his chosen ones, who cry out to him day and night? Will he keep putting them off?" (v. 7) By implication, Jesus meant that if an imperfect, wicked and unjust judge could respond to repeated requests of a helpless widow, how much more will the just God hastily bring justice to His own beloved people. Jesus' explanation also indicates that God honours prayers offered consistently (day and night) and persistently. That is why He would not keep putting off His chosen ones __ as the rhetorical question portrays: will He keep putting them off? God is equally committed to ensuring that His chosen people get justice quickly; that is, in good time (vv. 7a, 8a). Jesus concluded by asking a cogent question: "When the Son of Man comes, will He find faith on the earth?" (v. 8b) This suggests that some believers may compromise their faith perhaps due to unanswered prayers with regards to life's challenges or suffering caused by injustice.

    The implication of this passage is that if a corrupt and wicked judge finally did what was right (even though for ego or personal safety sake), will God in His mercy not act swiftly on behalf of His oppressed people and give good gifts to those who ask (cf. Luke 11:9-13)? Consistency and persistence are the major keys believers should embrace and apply in order to secure answers to their requests, which they put before God in prayers. However, the fact that God will act quickly to bring justice to His people, as mentioned in this passage and the thought of Paul in Romans 16:20, does not negate the fact that God's people will endure some measure of injustice. Hence, Christians should not give-up their faith in times of temptation and tribulations because their prayers have not been answered. This is the essence of Jesus' call for persistence in prayer in verse 1 with the certainty that God will vindicate His people and answer their prayers, even more certainly than the unjust judge. As believers, we must do everything possible to maintain our spiritual vibrancy in the face of God's delay to respond to our prayers __ trusting that He will answer us in due course. More so, our timing or understanding of quickly is not the same as God's timing as He makes everything beautiful in its time.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. Ask a class member to give a practical example of how he waited for an answer to his prayer for a long time and what the experience has taught him.
    2. How can we help Christians who seem to be losing hope as a result of delayed answers to their prayers?

Prayer Points

  • Pray against all forms of injustice in our society, especially against widows who are helpless.
  • Pray that God will help our churches and individual Christians to pay attention to the needs of widows.
  • Pray that the Lord will help us not to lose faith as a result of seeming delay in answer to our prayers.

Fellowship and Ministry Building Activities

  • Briefly role-play the parable of the widow and the unjust judge. Discuss the importance of persistence in prayer.

Take Home

  • Christians should be persistent in their prayers.
  • Believers should learn to respond to injustice through persistent prayer.
  • There is hope for believers, even in the midst of injustice.
  • God is the only Righteous Judge in this corrupt world.

title: ENTERING GOD'S KINGDOM
message:
July 22, 2018

ENTERING GOD'S KINGDOM

Devotional Reading: Psalm 1

Background Scripture: Matthew 7:15-23; Luke 13:22-30

Lesson Scripture: Luke 13:22-30

Golden Text

"Make every effort to enter through the narrow door, because many, I tell you, will try to enter and will not be able to. Luke 13:24

Objectives :

By the end of the lesson, class members should be able to:

  • State clearly what is required to enter through the narrow door.
  • Identify three things that may likely happen before the first becomes the last and the last, the first.
  • Explain what it means to engage in acts that will make them enter into God's kingdom.

INTRODUCTION

Some years ago, a particular denomination organised a business summit for interested men and women who aspired to excel in the business world. According to brother Yinka, who had the opportunity to attend the summit, attendance was strictly by invitation with specific rules and regulations, which every participant must follow. The summit was scheduled to start by 6.30 a.m. with registration so, all the invited guests were expected to arrive at the venue a day before, since the programme will commence at 8a.m. the next day. The day finally came and many people rushed to the venue to be registered early so that they could sit in front. The programme started at exactly 8a.m. and the door was closed to the amazement of those who were already seated. About an hour later, a few people came demanding to be allowed in since they came with their invitation cards. They forgot that it was written on the invitation cards that late-comers will not be allowed in. As a result, they lost the opportunity of being trained as business moguls.

Jesus likened entering into the kingdom of God as through a narrow door. Though the kingdom is open to everyone, it has a time limit by which every person is expected to enter through faith in Jesus Christ. This is the summary of today's lesson.

THE LESSON EXPLAINED

  1. God's Standard for Entering the Kingdom Luke 13:22-25

    While Jesus was on His way to Jerusalem, He went through some towns and villages teaching the message of the kingdom.
