Probably having pondered on the subject of His teaching, someone asked Him a question saying, "Lord, are only a few people going to be saved?" This question can also be traced back to Jesus' teaching about the narrowness of the gate, which only a few can find (Matthew 7:14). According to verse 24, it is observed that Jesus did not answer the question directly. Instead, He made them know the standard of entering the kingdom. He said to them, "Make every effort to enter through the narrow door, because many, I tell you, will try to enter and will not be able to." The question may have emanated from the Jewish traditional belief about their position in Christ. Many of them believed that being a Jew automatically offered them salvation and, therefore, they can enter the kingdom of God. Of course, this was one of the reasons they always boasted that Abraham is their father (John 8:39). But Jesus admonished them to personally strive to enter the kingdom through the narrow door (having faith in Jesus) before it will be too late (v. 25). However, we must understand that making effort as used in the passage, does not mean that we must do some things to earn our salvation.

    Definitely, the narrow door represents faith in the Lord Jesus, His death and resurrection, which is the only way to eternal salvation (John 14:6). The most important thing is that every individual should strive to enter into the kingdom. Though we do not get saved by personal efforts (but by grace through faith - Ephesians 2:8, 9); but after we have been saved, we must work out our salvation with fear and trembling. Those who are yet to be saved should know that the grace of salvation will not be there forever. The reason for Jesus' warning is that once the owner of the house closes the door, the opportunity will be lost forever. Therefore, we must be willing to pay the price and follow Jesus __ the only door to the kingdom so that we will not be denied the opportunity of entering into God's kingdom. The decision for eternal salvation (entering through the narrow door) or repentance from the path of destruction/backsliding should not be delayed so that it will not be too late.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. Discuss why it is important to be focused as we move on the narrow path to the kingdom.
    2. Discuss the areas of our lives that require serious amendments in order to enter the kingdom.
    3. What are some of the things that may likely hinder people from entering the kingdom?
  2. A Banquet for All People Luke 13:26-30

    The question someone asked Jesus about those who will be saved motivated Him to explain the nature of the narrow door and the qualifications of those who will enter through it to the kingdom. In verse 26 Jesus said, when the door is finally closed, the people who will come knocking and pleading to be allowed entry may be a reference to the Jews. The understanding is that they should be treated as members of the family on the basis that they were familiar with Jesus __ they ate and drank with Him and He taught in their streets. But the response will be "I do not know you or where you come from. Away from me, all you evildoers! The response will definitely lead to weeping and gnashing of teeth by sinners, which symbolise mourning and torment. In fact, as it is described in the passage; the anguish will be severe, especially when they see the __ __ patriarchs Abraham, Isaac and Jacob and other prophets who were the recipients of God's covenant enter the kingdom while they are shut out. People will come from all over the world, most likely believers, the saved, the elect and those who have been __ preserved on the basis of their faith in Christ Jesus. These will include the Gentiles persons from every tribe and language and people and nations (Revelation 5:9; 7:9), and will take their places at the feast in the kingdom of God. The climax of the experience is that those who are last will be first while the first will be last (v. 30). This means that the marginalised people in the society (the last) are also loved by God and may be the first to be accepted into God's kingdom.

    The feast in this text may be the imagery of the messianic banquet, which shall be a reflection of the great joy that characterise God's kingdom. Therefore, missing this great joy will be enough reason to weep and gnash one\'s teeth. Many Jews who had counted on their privileged position as descendants of Abraham to gain entrance into God's kingdom will find themselves shut outside when the kingdom comes. But the Gentiles, whom the Jews believed would suffer eternal torment, and whom they felt were unworthy of salvation are described by Jesus as sitting at the banquet table of the kingdom, along with the prophets and the patriarchs of Israel. This implies that there is opportunity for everyone, while the door remains open, to be serious with the message of salvation and respond to it accordingly before it is too late. Otherwise, they will be shut out of the kingdom of God. Similarly, those who have believed must hold on to their faith and maintain their spiritual stability so that they will not lose the joy of the great banquet in heaven.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. What is the place of today's lesson in evangelism?
    2. Discuss the meaning and implications of verse 30 for believers.

Prayer Points

  • Pray and ask God to help you to remain faithful so as to enter His kingdom.
  • Pray for God's help to make you qualify to partake of the heavenly banquet.
  • Ask God to help His church to be committed to evangelism, especially in this end- time.

Fellowship and Ministry Building Activities

  • Ask class members to mention and discuss some possible steps Christians can take as they make effort to enter the kingdom of God. They are to pray for grace to make it.

Take Home

  • All true believers will be allowed to enter the kingdom of God.
  • The narrow door (Jesus Christ) is the only way to heaven.
  • Christians should be ready to pay the price for entering the kingdom.
  • Familiarising oneself with the Word of God alone without salvation will not take us to heaven.
  • Familiarity with Christ and involvement in religious activities without salvation will not take us to heaven.

title: PARABLE OF THE GREAT DINNER
message:
July 29, 2018

PARABLE OF THE GREAT DINNER

Devotional Reading: Luke 14:25-33

Background Scripture / Luke 14:25-33: Luke 14:25-33

Golden Text

'Go out quickly into the streets and alleys of the town and bring in the poor, the crippled, the blind and the lame.' Luke 14:21b

Objectives :

By the end of the lesson, class members should be able to:

  • Identify possible reasons why people make excuses for not coming to God.
  • Discuss the nature of the heavenly banquet and ways we can best be prepared for it.
  • Describe what will happen to those who refuse to honour God's invitation.

INTRODUCTION

The society we live in is characterised by different classes and cliques of people, even in the church. It is obvious that the normal human relationship that ought to exist between one person and another has paralised. We often see people who are affiliated either by language, gender, the level of education, profession and sometimes age group relate and do things in common. Sometimes, when there is an occasion that ought to be open for anyone interested, it will be marked ''strictly by invitation' simply to put an impediment on the way of interested individuals. A couple narrated their unpleasant experience when their distant relative gave out one of his daughters in marriage. Apart from the fact that they were not specifically invited perhaps because of their low financial status, according to them, all the invited guests were in different uniforms, beautifully dressed and seated together with enough food and drinks on their tables. Unfortunately, this couple, even though they are closely related to the father of the bride, were ignored because they did not belong to any group neither did they wear the same uniform (Aso-ebi) with the family members. This kind of discrimination has continued for long, even among Christians.

Having reprimanded the people on the importance of humility and hospitality, Jesus told the parable of the great feast simply to illustrate how people respond to the invitation God gives through Jesus Christ. Of course, He knew that many people, especially the religious leaders of His own nation would reject Him and His offer of eternal redemption, giving the most trivial excuses. However, today's topic offers a strong hope not only to the poor and those who have been despised, downtrodden, dehumanised and rejected by the society but also to others who will respond to God's gracious invitation of salvation along with its future blessing. This invitation will not be restricted to a particular class of people but to all, irrespective of one's social status, tribe and language.

THE LESSON EXPLAINED

  1. Invitation to the Great Banquet Luke 14:15-20

    Jesus had just taught a lesson on humility and kindness having noticed how some of the invited guests to a feast chose the best places for themselves. He concluded and admonished the people on the importance of inviting those who are not able to return their kindness so as to receive God's blessing (vv. 1-14). The question asked in verse 2 prompted Jesus to narrate the parable of the great banquet to illustrate the kind of people who will enter God's kingdom. It was the parable of a certain man who prepared a banquet and invited many guests who were expected to indicate their willingness to come so that food would be prepared accordingly. The reason is that it was considered very irresponsible to attend a banquet if you were not invited. Unfortunately, they all gave different excuses on the day of the banquet. The fact that they gave excuses for their failure to attend the banquet is an indication of four things:

    • It can be considered a sign of irresponsibility to have accepted an invitation and fail to attend.
    • They had been invited before they began to make lame excuses.
    • They had other things to attend to, which were more important to them.
    • Their refusal to attend was a show of disrespect for the organiser of the banquet.

    This passage paints a picture of God\'s abundant provision and invitation of salvation, which was rejected by the Jews who did not accept the Messiah. The excuses they all gave are not genuine because no one would buy a field without first inspecting it, or buy yoke of oxen without first trying them. More importantly, there is no reason why a newly married man should not take his wife along to a banquet. Therefore, these invited guests only showed their profound disrespect for their host despite the fact that they had accepted the first invitation. Even today, many people give flimsy excuses for not accepting God's offer of eternal life with the assumption that God will not be wicked enough to allow His children go to hell. Some even reject the offer with the excuse that there is still time to do so. The heavenly banquet, which Christ has prepared for His bride (the church) is beautifully represented in this passage. The best way anyone can be prepared to enter the great banquet is to accept Jesus as Saviour and Lord thus becoming a Christian. We are also to work out our salvation with fear and trembling, walk in His ways and remain steadfast until the return of the Master.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. Why is it difficult for people to accept God's invitation of salvation?
    2. Let class members discuss other worldly invitations that compete with God's.
  2. Special Invitation to Special People Luke 14:21-24

    It is natural for people to feel offended when their invitees disappoint them, especially when enough provision have been made for them. According to the passage, the report of the servant about the refusal of the people to come did not go down well with the master. He became furious because the meal would have been prepared according to the number of people who accepted the first invitation. For obvious reasons, the man ordered his servant to extend the invitation to the poor, crippled, blind and the lame who would not have ordinarily been allowed to attend the occasion so that his house would be full. The Pharisees had ignorantly placed many restrictions on who would enter God's kingdom when actually God has extended His grace to everyone. Interestingly, these people represent the Jews who were despised and unable to observe the traditional laws of ritual purity.

    The special invitation to the last set of people is significant because the Pharisees had considered them to be unclean and, therefore, not fit to inherit the kingdom. Consequently, their invitation is a clear indication that the kingdom is open and available for everyone who accepts God's offer of salvation. God has graciously __ extended this invitation of salvation to many to the Jews first and then to the Gentiles. However, the rejection of Christ by the Jews finally opened the door of salvation to the Gentiles. Those who failed to honour the invitation to the banquet obviously missed the joy of dining with the Master. Hence those who choose to reject Christ's offer of salvation will never taste the joy of salvation nor partake in the heavenly banquet.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. Discuss some common excuses people give for not accepting Jesus' offer of salvation and how such people can be helped.
    2. What are the dangers of continually giving excuses concerning Christ's invitation?
    3. What does the invitation to these classes of people in the society teach us about evangelism and salvation?

Prayer Points

  • Appreciate God who has graciously extended the invitation of salvation to all.
  • Pray that God will help you to remain steadfast until His coming, in Jesus' Name.
  • Pray for those who have not known God in your family and community.

Fellowship and Ministry Building Activities

  • Let each class member write at least five common excuses people give for not accepting God's gift of salvation.
  • They are to pray for the unsaved in their families and communities for God to open their eyes that they may know Him and be saved.

Take Home

  • Believers should not discriminate concerning the kind of people with whom to fellowship.
  • Real generosity does not look for returns.
  • It is God's desire that all are saved.
  • Those who refuse God's gift of salvation will suffer the consequences.

title: EQUITY FOR ALL
message:
August 5, 2018

EQUITY FOR ALL

Devotional Reading: Psalm 32

Background Scripture: Romans 2:1-16

Lesson Scripture: Romans 2:1-12

Golden Text

But glory, honour and peace for everyone who does good: first for the Jew, then for the Gentile. For God does not show favouritism. Romans 2:10-11

Objectives :

By the end of the lesson, class members should be able to:

  • Identify and recount that God is the only impartial Judge.
  • Contrast human judgment with God’s judgment.
  • Make decision to look beyond the faults of others and treat them with fairness through Christian behaviour.

INTRODUCTION

Mike Yohamaki is a senior officer in one of the new generation banks. By virtue of his new promotion, he was saddled with the responsibility of supervising the activities of the operation department in his branch. As it was their tradition, every morning, staff members would come together in their conference room to receive instructions from their boss (Mr Mike) before they begin the day's work. Unfortunately, Mr Mike was known to come late to work and this usually delayed the commencement of operation for the day. Eventually when he comes, he would yell at the staff members and accuse them of laziness, nonchalance and, sometimes, threaten to recommend them for dismissal. One day, a superior officer from the head office visited the branch and discovered that Mr Mike was yet to resume work for the day. Upon investigation, he was reliably informed of Mr Mike's habitual late coming to office yet, he would accuse other staff members of the same offence. The Senior Officer who was furious at his arrogance and nonchalant attitude, however, accused him of being mean because he commits the same offence with others yet, accuses and threatens them almost on daily basis. He declared that as much as possible, the bank will continue to maintain equal opportunity for all, notwithstanding who is involved.

There were some Jews in the church in Rome who were proud because they possess and know God's law. As a result, they were quick to condemn the vices of the pagan world whereas, they were as wicked as the pagans who do not know God and His laws. In other words, they were not better than the pagans because they were guilty of the same offence of the unbelievers. Paul, therefore, reminded them that God's judgment is with strict impartiality. He made them know that God will judge each individual according to his deeds. Therefore, those who reject the truth will receive the wrath of God but those who continually do good will enjoy peace, glory and honour, whether Jew or Gentile (vv. 7-11). The focus of today's lesson is a reminder that God ahbors discrimination among His people.

THE LESSON EXPLAINED

  1. God's Righteous Judgment Revealed Romans 2:1-5

    One of the attributes of God is His impartiality in dealing with people. This was Paul's strongest point when he confronted the Jewish readers about their shortcomings in judging others of the same offences they were guilty of. According to verse 2, he made it clear that the Jews have no moral justification to pass judgment on others because God is always right when He judges. Moreover, he emphasised the fact that they will not escape God's judgment, which is based on truth; otherwise, they will condemn themselves because they do the same things. In verse 4, Paul asked an important question about their show of contempt for the riches of God's kindness, tolerance and patience without realising that His kindness can lead to repentance. Invariably, the purpose of God's kindness is to give opportunity to people to repent of their wickedness. Nevertheless, because of the stubbornness of people, their punishment will be greater when God's anger and righteous judgment will be revealed (v. 5).

    The actions of human beings are sometimes influenced by partiality, favouritism and unfairness. The tone of Paul's letter has been described by some as a warning than correction. However, he cautioned the attitude of the self-righteous people who practise the sins common to humankind and yet they were quick to condemn others. This, of course, is an indication that the human judgment is always biased. He compared their judgment with that of God who gives opportunity to sinners to change through His patience and kindness to all. He, however, made it clear that they will not be able to escape the punishment of God at the end of age when God's fury will be revealed. The summary of the lesson is that Christians should be cautious of their conduct, especially in a society like ours that is characterised by wickedness and corruption. We should not be influenced or join the people of the world to do evil and thereafter criticise them. According to Paul, the punishment will be worse when God shall come to judge His people. Even though it seems everyone has a high tendency to criticise others in words or thoughts like the Jews but the awareness that we also stand to be condemned should make Christians refrain from criticising and judging others.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. Describe the different ways Christians discriminate among themselves today and how this can be corrected.
    2. What are some excuses people give for judging others, even when they are guilty of the same offence?
    3. How can God's grace of equity be displayed to all when He forgives sins?
  2. God's Impartial Judgment Revealed Romans 2:6-12

    As Paul continued with God's righteous judgment, he became categorical in verse 6. He said, "God will give to each person according to what he has done." Thereafter, he made a contrast between those who desire to do good and seek glory, honour and immortality and those who reject the truth and continue in their evil ways. According to him, while the group that judges right is rewarded with glory, honour, peace and the gift of eternity, those who are self-seeking and reject the truth, thereby despising God's patience and kindness will be punished with God's wrath and anger (vv. 7-8). Both groups shall be judged accordingly and the judgment will not be biased or hidden. Consequently, there will be great trouble and distress for the entire human race, particularly the evildoers but glory, honour and peace will reign in the hearts of those who do good, both the Jews and Gentiles. Of course, the reason is clearly stated in verse 11 that God does not show favouritism, no matter who is involved. However, Paul balanced his teaching with the conclusion that, "All who sin apart from the law will also perish apart from the law, and all who sin under the law will be judged by the law." (v. 12).

    According to the passage, Paul made it clear that God is just in all His ways unlike humankind who sometimes show partiality in their judgment. More importantly, God cannot be deceived to give reward in the place of punishment or punish those who should be rewarded as the wicked do. Little wonder the righteous got what they meted out (v. 9). Even though we live in a world where people show partiality without considering the consequence or the emotional trauma they put people through, believers should refrain from the attitude of judging others. Instead, we should be ready to correct our fellow brethren of their wrongdoing with love while we watch ourselves so that we will not be tempted (Galatians 6:1).

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. Let at least two members briefly share how they felt recently when they were partially judged.
    2. What will be your suggestion for disciplinary action against an offending congregant after today's study?

Prayer Points

  • Thank God for His righteous judgment.
  • Ask God to forgive you for previously judging others.
  • Ask the Lord to help you in carrying out any necessary disciplinary action to offenders with the aim of encouraging godly equity.

Fellowship and Ministry Building Activities

  • List the righteous judgments of God in the passage and discuss the possibility of applying them in our contemporary time.
  • Each member should make a commitment not to be a part of either tearing down the Christian body through judgmental attitudes or giving up on salvation for the unbeliever through condemnation or criticism.

Take Home

  • God's judgment is always righteous, without partiality and of absolute equity.
  • Equity is a Christian virtue, which must be encouraged by all believers.
  • Disciplinary actions with godly equity will surely restore backsliding Christians rather than turn them to rebels.
  • Everyone will surely receive the righteous and unbiased judgment he deserves from God.

title: CHARITABLE EQUITY FOR ALL
message:
August 12, 2018

CHARITABLE EQUITY FOR ALL

Devotional Reading: Proverbs 3:9-10, 13-20, 27-28

Background Scripture: 2 Corinthians 8:9

Lesson Scripture: 2 Corinthians 8:7-15

Golden Text

For you know the grace of our Lord Jesus Christ, that though he was, yet or your sakes he became poor, so that you through his poverty might become rich. 2 Corinthians 8:9

Objectives :

By the end of the lesson, class members should be able to:

  • Identify the areas believers can emulate the attitude of the Macedonians who gave their best to support their brethren.
  • Discuss the benefits of giving and receiving.
  • Make decisions as stewards to be equitable with their God-given resources.

INTRODUCTION

Word Search 9 gave a beautiful illustration on charitable giving and kindness. It used the story of a woman who transferred kindness when she visited a coffee outlet sometime ago. Because of her unusual giftedness in giving, this woman chose to pay not only for her cup of coffee but also for the person next to her on the queue. When the customer was told her cup of coffee had been paid for, she was pleased and decided to pay for the customer next to her. Interestingly, this pattern of charitable kindness was passed in relay form from one customer to another through all the twenty seven customers who were on queue for a cup of coffee. Chapters 8 and 9 of Paul's letter to the brethren in Corinth contain mostly instructions about the offering for the poor saints in Jerusalem who were suffering from financial challenges. Titus had helped the Corinthians to make a good start following Paul's instructions in his earlier letter to them (v. 6). To further encourage them to give, Paul wrote another letter to remind them of the need to support their Jewish fellow Christians and by so doing, they will learn the duty and blessing of systematic and generous giving. Today's lesson focuses on the need for believers to practise charitable equality for all, whenever the need arises.

THE LESSON EXPLAINED

  1. Encouragement to Give Generously 2 Corinthians 8:7-12

    Paul's major concern as he wrote this letter was how the Corinthians can give generously to support the saints in Jerusalem. In his attempt to encourage them, he related how the Macedonians had voluntarily and generously contributed to support the brethren in Jerusalem out of their extreme poverty (vv. 1-2). He, therefore, used them as an example to motivate the Corinthians to do likewise. Previously, Paul had praised and thanked God for the Corinthian church for the having spiritual gifts and for eagerly waiting for the revelation of Jesus Christ (1Corinthians 1:4-8). Consequently, they were encouraged to also do well in the grace of charitable giving besides their faith, speech, knowledge, complete earnestness and their love for them. Paul, however, affirmed that his instruction was not a command but a test to prove their love in enthusiastic giving. In verse 9, he made a reference to Jesus Christ who exemplified charitable giving that even though He was rich, He became poor so that the poverty of humankind will be exchanged for His riches.

    It is commonly believed that humankind was born with the inclination to be selfish and, therefore, cannot easily part with their possession. However, the giving attitude of the Christians in Macedonian has proved this statement wrong. Particularly, Paul testified that they were under severe trial which resulted to a state of poverty (v. 3). Notwithstanding, they gave beyond their ability and so, they have become a reference for urging the Corinthian Christians to do likewise. By implication, believers should emulate the Macedonians by meeting the needs of the needy either in their family, church or our community so that there will be equality for all as it was the practice of the early church (Acts 4:32-35). For instance, churches and individual families can choose to have food and clothes bank, bookstore (old and new) and other resources purposely to help the poor. After all, the gift will be acceptable and become a blessing to the poor if the willingness is there (Mark 12:41- 44). We should remember that we are stewards of God's resources in our possession; therefore, we are expected to be faithful and generously share our resources with others as the need arises.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. Describe what our churches would look like when more churches exchange charitable assistance
    2. Mention ministries and organisations you know that help people in need and take some time to find their source of motivation.
    3. Discuss a discouraging experience you had recently in an attempt to share your resources with someone in need.
  2. Encouragement to Maintain Equity in Giving Corinthians 8:13-15

    Apostle Paul was specific in his admonition to the Christians in Corinth regarding generous giving. He explained in these verses that the essence of being charitable is not to cause inconveniences in the use of their resources even though it was meant for the relief of their fellow brethren, thereby making them poor. Actually, his desire as he promoted equity among believers was to encourage the people to maintain God's standard of fairness in their giving. The reason is that the surplus of some will be useful for the deficiency of others and so they will complement one another. The idea is to practice the act of giving and receiving as it was in the tradition of the early church. By so doing, we will follow the example of Christ and ease the poverty and oppression of the needy who live among us.

    The truth of this lesson is that every Christian does not have it all; therefore, we are bound to depend on one another for our needs to be met. When this is done, there will be equity among God's people. More importantly, Christians should not only excel in faith, speech, knowledge, earnestness and love, we must also understand and maintain the practice of generous giving with the aim of bridging the gap between the rich and poor in our families, churches and communities (v. 7). This was Paul's appeal to the Corinthian church.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. Discuss how to overcome the fear of tomorrow that makes people hoard what they have.
    2. In what ways can inner motivation to practice charitable equity be inspired where outward motivation is absent?

Prayer Points

  • Thank God for the excellent generosity we have in Christ Jesus who became poor that we might be rich.
  • Ask the Lord to equip you with His Spirit and resources to become an agent of charitable equity.
  • Pray that the Church will practice giving assistance to neighbouring churches, especially in their times of need.

Fellowship and Ministry Building Activities

  • Reflect on the things you have in excess and ways to share them with others in need this week. Report to the class about the people's responses.
  • Prayerfully work with the social ministry committee in your church on how to create a “ministry of giving” in the church or community.

Take Home

  • The Macedonian's generosity should be an example for all believers.
  • Wise Stewards manage God-given resources with charitable equity.
  • Your willingness to give cheerfully matters more to God as it attracts blessings.
  • Giving to the needy is our response to Jesus Christ who gave His all for us.
  • Believers must be willing to serve God and others with a willing heart.

title: LOVING AND JUST BEHAVIOUR
message:
August 19, 2018

LOVING AND JUST BEHAVIOUR

Devotional Reading: Matthew 5:38-48

Background Scripture / Lesson Scripture: Romans 12:9-21

Golden Text

Love must be completely sincere. Hate what is evil, hold on to what is good. Romans 12:9

Objectives :

By the end of the lesson, class members should be able to:

  • List at least four of the marks of Christians described in Roman 12:9-21.
  • Compare and contrast love and discipline.
  • Write down their decision not to allow any provocation make them exhibit hate and evil in their behaviour.

INTRODUCTION

Brother Musa Hassan is a converted Muslim. He gave his life to Christ during Reinhard Bonnke's last crusade in his hometown, in one of the cities in the South West. Even though he was greatly persecuted by his family members, he did not give up. He was excited by his new faith and was very much willing to learn and know more about God. Soon, he got baptised and became a member of the choir in his church. Despite his busy schedule, he was committed to almost all the weekly programmes in the church, especially Bible study because of his desire to grow spiritually. One day, after the Bible study which was focused on Romans chapter 12 with the topic "Christian Conduct", brother Musa became a little worried about the possibility of someone possessing all the qualities mentioned in the chapter. In fact, his major concern was the command not to revenge. In his state of confusion, he walked up to the pastor and shared his worry. The pastor succeeded counselled and encouraged him to continue to pray for grace as he grows in the faith.

Paul\'s letter to the brethren in Rome, especially from chapters 12-15 consist of exhortation and instructions related to Christian service to God, obligations as a Christian community and the need to accept one another in spite of differences. The summary of today's lesson is Christian conduct and acceptable behaviour through loving and just actions toward others. Without doubt, such acts will afford us the opportunity to live as brothers and sisters, which is acceptable to God.

THE LESSON EXPLAINED

  1. Admonition to Live as Christians Romans 12:9-13

    Paul's letter to the church in Rome is quite explicit. Mainly, his concern in this chapter was to encourage the brethren to live a transformed life as Christians. Beginning from verse 9, he systematically described some Christian qualities which the Roman Christians should display in their relationship with one another and in the community. The encouragement expresses the need:

    • For Christian love: which must be sincere and complete. He means the type of love that is not mere emotion but active and genuine.
    • To hate evil: They should abhor evil and love what is good and admirable.
    • For commitment to one another: He emphasised the importance of showing brotherly love to one another.
    • To honour one another: they were expected to honour one another above themselves and be zealous in their service to God.
    • To be joyful in hope, patient in suffering and faithful in prayer.
    • To give: They were to share their resources with the needy and so demonstrate true hospitality. In other words, the people were encouraged to open their homes to strangers. This instruction became necessary because the early Christian missionaries like Paul were travellers and so, were always in need of a place to sleep.
     

    There is every possibility that Paul's admonition was necessitated by the attitude of the brethren which was contrary to God's standard. He, therefore, called their attention to life in God's service (the practicality of Christian lifestyle). Christian living can be reflected in showing sincere love and just behaviour toward one another. In doing this, we live as Christians, we will be able to influence others and live harmoniously. Unfortunately, it seems believers are not sensitive to the tricks of the Devil to cause hatred and disunity among God\'s people to the extent that we are often provoked to pay back with revenge. Therefore, today's lesson is a call to promote Christian lifestyle so that we can serve as light to the world.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. How can Christians recognise and curb those who are out to exploit the Christian ethics of sacrificial giving.
    2. Discuss ways in which Christians can package love to fellow members and also unbelievers.
  2. Admonition to Live at Peace Romans 12:14-21

    Paul's admonition to the brethren in Rome was all-inclusive. While he encouraged the Christians to relate in love and practice true hospitality, he also envisaged the possibility of some people who will act in hatred and evil hence, he prescribed how Christians are to respond to such attitude. Beginning from verse 14, he advised that maltreated believers should:

    • Ask God to bless (speak well of) those who persecute them and not curse.
    • Identify with those who rejoice and mourn with mourners.
    • Live in harmony with everyone.
    • Not be proud but be willing to associate with those of low status.
    • Not revenge but do what is right always.
    • Live in peace with one another.

    Unfortunately, as good as these instructions and commands are to believers, we live in a world that is characterised by hatred, evil practices and the urge to revenge every wrong done to us. Naturally, people want to retaliate every wrongdoing. We often forget that even Jesus said we should not revenge rather, we should love our enemies, do good to those who hate us and bless those who curse (Luke 6:27-28). In fact, the best response to these commands and instructions is to strive to overcome evil with hospitality, living at peace and doing what is right in the sight of everybody (vv. 17-19). When this is done, the Word of God will spread, His kingdom will be enlarged and everyone will live in peace.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. Discuss how practicable it is to live in harmony, especially with people of different religion who show hostility from time to time.
    2. What is the place of prayer in peaceful and harmonious living?
    3. Living in peace with others is costly. Discuss.

Prayer Points

  • Thank God for the demonstration of His love for us through the death and resurrection of Jesus Christ.
  • Pray that God will help you to always show love and not hatred.
  • Ask God to forgive you of the sin of vengeance in the past and make you an agent of peace.

Fellowship and Ministry Building Activities

  • Describe the commands in verses 14-19 and the benefits of putting them into practice.

Take Home

  • Believers should not allow provocation to make them hate other people.
  • Christians are expected to live in harmony regardless of our differences.
  • We should not revenge because God had said vengeance belongs to Him.
  • Believers should not be proud but be ready to identify with the poor in our midst.

title: PRACTISING JUSTICE
message:
August 26, 2018

PRACTISING JUSTICE

Devotional Reading: Romans 8:1-11

Background Scripture: Ephesians 4:25 5:2; Colossians 3:1-17

Lesson Scripture: Colossians 3:5-17

Golden Text

Therefore, as God's chosen people, holy and dearly loved, clothe yourselves with compassion, kindness, humility, gentleness and patience. Colossians 3:12

Objectives :

By the end of the lesson, class members should be able to:

  • Differentiate between their old way of life and the new.
  • Give examples of when it may be difficult to practice justice.
  • Make a conscious decision to live peaceably with everyone; both Christians and non-Christians.

INTRODUCTION

Apostle Paul said in his letter to the Corinthian church, "Therefore, if anyone is in Christ, he is a new creation; the old has gone and the new has come." (2 Corinthians 5:17) This was the slogan of a young lady immediately she gave her life to Christ during one of the Baptist Students' Fellowship (BSF) annual campus joint retreat. The sister who used to be known as wayward started to exhibit godly virtues so much that the difference between her past and present became evident. Although some people initially doubted her conversion but she remained unswerving and focused in her faith and services to God. She made it known to her friends that she has shifted from the old way of immorality and disobedience to faith and obedience to God. She publicly announced her decision to live the new life in Christ Jesus who died and resurrected for the sake of redeeming her soul from destruction.

Becoming a Christian means a break from the old as a result of our acknowledging Jesus Christ as our Saviour and Lord. It also means yielding to the Holy Spirit to live the new life of Christ in us, direct our way and make love and forgiveness become our model. Of course, no man is an island. We have been made to relate with one another – Christians and non-Christians – and it is through our relationship with others that we can truly test the virtues we claim we have. Today's topic focuses on Paul\'s appeal to the Christians in Colossae to refrain from their sinful behaviour and practice the new life that comes by having been raised to new life in Christ Jesus.

THE LESSON EXPLAINED

  1. Admonition to Live a New Life Colossians 3:5-11

    Paul was frank in his exhortation to the brethren in Colossae as he reminded and admonished them on rules for holy living. He distinguished between the old and new lifestyles and made them to understand that God abhors sin and will invariably make sure it is justly punished. Therefore, in order to avoid such punishment for sin, he instructed the people to: put to death all evil desires like sexual immorality, impurity, lust, evil desires and greed (v. 5). According to verses 7 and 8, he affirmed that even though they once practiced these evil things, they must do away with them because they have taken off the old self and its practices. More so, they have put on the new life in Christ Jesus, which God is constantly renewing in His own image so that they can be brought into the full knowledge of Himself. Consequently, there is no more division of any kind between Gentiles and Greeks, circumcised and uncircumcised, barbarians and, Scythian (uncultured persons), slave or free. This declaration suggests that Jesus Christ transcends all barriers and so, He is the unifying factor of all races. Similarly, Paul reminded the Galatians that all have become one through Jesus Christ and are Abraham's seed and heirs according to the promise (Galatians 3:28). Without doubt, living a new life in Christ will empower believers to seek justice both locally and globally.

    Paul was concerned about the spiritual growth of the brethren. His admonition was primarily for them to forsake their evil ways of life and begin to live a new life in Christ, which is in accordance with the will of God for them. Immediately one confesses Jesus Christ as Saviour and Lord, Jesus becomes our model in His love, relationship and character; a lifestyle that is quite different from the old. He, therefore, appealed to them to avoid evil habits like anger, passion and hateful feelings or lying which should only be seen with unbelievers. Paul also emphasised this when he talked about getting rid of lies, anger, harmful words, bitterness, insults and so on (Ephesians 4:25-32). The implication, therefore, is that believers should depend on the Holy Spirit to help them exhibit godly character as we relate with other people, notwithstanding their religion, sex or race because Christ is all, and is in all (v. 11). When we begin to display godly attribute in our relationships, we will become models and light to other people.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. Why is it difficult for some people to exhibit godly character even after their conversion?
    2. Discuss contemporary suggestions for Christian living in relation to the lesson.
    3. Discuss what Paul meant in verse 11 and how it relates with our relation to people from other religion.
  2. Admonition to Live as God's People Colossians 3:12-14

    Paul's appeal for the brethren in Colossae to begin to live a new life was necessitated by their new faith in Christ Jesus. Since they have become God's chosen people, they were encouraged to practice justice and fairness toward one another as evidence of compassion, kindness, humility, gentleness and patience. He added that tolerance and forgiveness should be their traits, especially whenever there is a misunderstanding among them. Paul also encouraged them to forgive. He said, "Forgive as the Lord forgave you" (v. 13b). They were to forgive as Christ forgave them showing the same disposition and readiness to forgive an offender, as Christ has shown to them. Besides, they should love one another because love has the ability to bind together in perfect unity.

    The fact remains that every Christian has been chosen by God; therefore, we are expected to live as people of God and exhibit godly qualities in our relationship with other believers. Paul's admonition is that we belong to one and the same God, redeemed by the same blood, and chosen by the same grace. This should lead Christians to manifest a spirit of kindness, gentleness, and love towards one another. More importantly, we must strive to live godly lives because of our election unto eternal salvation as God's people.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. Should the offended wait to be begged before he or she forgives?
    2. Can a person truly become perfect in character, especially in this evil society?
  3. Admonition to Embrace Peace Colossians 3:15-17

    Paul concludes his message, he became more resolute about his expectations from the brethren in Colossae. Particularly, he told them three important things that will help them in their relationship with other people, as God's elect. For instance, he wished that:

    • The peace that Christ gives of which they have been called will guide their daily decisions and rule their hearts. Most especially that they are members of one body and have been called to embrace peace; therefore, they should be thankful (v. 15). In essence, Paul meant the type of peace that Christ alone gives instead of their constant state of bitterness and disagreement.
    • The Word of Christ will dwell in their hearts as they teach and admonish one another with wisdom as they sing psalms, hymns, and sacred songs to God with thanksgiving (v. 15).
    • Whatever they do, whether in words or deeds should be done in the name of the Lord Jesus with thanksgiving to God the Father through Jesus (v. 17).

    In fact, one of the attributes that should characterise the life of a believer is the willingness to embrace and promote peace, principally in our relationship with our fellow Christians and non-Christians. Paul's advice is very fundamental to contemporary believers, especially with the nature of our world that almost lack peace today. When we know the importance of peace and pursue it, soon, it will spread like whirlwind. Furthermore, the act of singing psalms, hymns and spiritual songs as recorded by Paul can encourage believers to follow Christ's teachings and improve our worship attitude to God. Therefore, Christians should endeavour to develop the attitude of true worship through the singing of hymns and songs of praise to God for His immeasurable blessings from time to time.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. Describe how the Word of God can dwell in us according to Paul's admonition in verse 16.
    2. Discuss the significance of singing hymns and Psalms in our worship services.
    3. Discuss the role of Christians in promoting peace in our troubled world.

Prayer Points

  • Pray that God will help you to promote fairness and justice to all people, in Jesus' Name.
  • Help every Christian, O Lord, to live harmoniously with other people in this world of hostility, in Jesus' Name.
  • I want to live in peace and be an agent of peace every day of my life.

Fellowship and Ministry Building Activities

  • How can we prove that all Christians are actually God's elect?
  • Ask the class members to carefully examine the virtues in the passage and underline the one they not have and pray for the grace of God to continue to help them.

Take Home

  • We are called to show love to others as God's chosen people.
  • Christians are to get rid of any ungodly attitude because of the new life we now live in Christ.
  • There is no distinction in the body of Christ.
  • We have been called to forgive our offenders just as God has forgiven us our trespasses.

title: GOD CREATED THE HEAVENS AND THE EARTH
message:
September 2, 2018

GOD CREATED THE HEAVENS AND THE EARTH

Devotional Reading: Psalm 33:1-9

Background Scripture / Lesson Scripture: Genesis 1:1-13

Golden Text

In the beginning, God created the heavens and the earth. Now the earth was formless and empty, darkness was over the surface of the deep, and the Spirit of God was hovering over the waters. enesis 1:1-2

Objectives :

By the end of the lesson, class members should be able to:

  • Describe the story of creation in a sequential order.
  • Discuss how God is distinct from His creation.
  • Express appreciation of God, the Creator of the heavens and the earth.

INTRODUCTION

It was another Sunday and the topic for the children's Sunday school was 'God Created the Heavens and the Earth'. The teacher taught explicitly the story of creation with relevant Bible passages. She composed and led the children to sing a song that further confirmed that God is the Creator of the heavens and the earth. Suddenly, the teacher noticed that one of the children did not sing or respond in any way. The child looked confused and probably needed more clarification. When she asked the child why he looked confused, he demanded to know the possibility of one single person to have created the heavens and the earth and everything in it.

Sometime ago, some men made attempt to discredit God and His power to create. They decided to propound a theory that the earth came into existence as a result of evolution. According to the story, after several failed attempts, these men finally concluded that truly God is the Creator of the heavens and the earth. Their conclusion, of course, is in consonance with the Scriptures that God was at the beginning when nothing else was. Therefore, He is the Originator, Creator and Sustainer of the universe. Today's lesson focuses on the account of creation in Genesis chapter 1 when nothing existed, but God alone. Consequently, the passage teaches us three basic truths about God: He is eternal, creative, and distinct from His creation because He was not created.

THE LESSON EXPLAINED

  1. God's Good Beginning Genesis 1:1-5

    The story of the creation has always been an interesting topic for discussion. It reveals and confirms the creative power of God with which He created the heavens and the earth in the beginning. According to verse 2, three things are revealed about the earth: it was without shape, covered with darkness and the Spirit of God was hovering over the waters. God started His work of creation when He commanded light to appear and because He saw that it was good, He separated it from darkness and called it day, while He called darkness night. God's attestation that the creation was good testifies to the fact that there was no disorder or imperfection in what He had done. It could also mean the excellent state of God\'s creation. There was evening and morning of the first day He began the work of creation (v. 5). In the Old Testament, light was symbolic of life and blessings (2 Samuel 22:29; Job 3:20) but Paul used the word “Light” to illustrate God's re-creating work in sin-darkened hearts (2 Corinthians 4:6). God called the light day, and darkness He called night. The purpose of the account, therefore, was to demonstrate the power of the spoken word in confirming the fact that everything God created was good (v. 9).

    We can see from the passage that all things started with God. The author of the book of Ecclesiastes also testified to the fact that God created everything in heaven and the earth (Ecclesiastes 1:5). The passage, therefore, is a reminder of the pre-existence of God who created the heavens and the earth. Secondly, it counteracts the concept confronting the modern man, especially the scientists who have tried to fashion out their own creation story. The __ Scripture declares that in the beginning, “God created the heavens and the earth” the origin of every creature. From a formless and chaotic world, He formed everything into an orderly universe to be inhabited by all living creatures. He would bring into being (Isaiah 45:18). Thus, “the Spirit of God was moving over the face of the waters,” watching over the world that was being created. This connotes that more things were being anticipated to take place.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. What does darkness in the passage signify?
    2. Why did God choose to create light above other things?
    3. Discuss the importance of evaluation as seen in verse 4.
  2. God's Creative Words Genesis 1:6-10

    God's work of creation was in sequence. Having created the heavens, the earth and the light on the first day with an affirmation that it was good, He commanded into existence an expanse between the waters. The description of the activities in the passage comprises the formation of the land mass and the gathering of surface waters into oceans and seas. The matters were separated from the land to constitute the earth and to form the seas, probably to make possible luxuriant plants and trees to grow and bring forth fruits and food for humankind. God called the expanse "sky" and there was evening and morning of the second day. In verse 9, God also commanded the coming together of the water in the sky in one place so that the land will appear and it was so. Consequently, the land was named "earth" and the water that had come together was called "sea". Again, God was pleased with what He had created.

    One of the uniqueness of the story of creation is the demonstration of the creative power of God. Everything He created was commanded into existence by His word. Notable also is the separation of the water above and beneath (v. 7). Believers must know that God is eternal and in control of the universe He has created. He is infinitely above all creatures, gods and all of humanity in knowledge, wisdom and understanding. The most exciting aspect of the story of creation is that God is distinct from everything He created. Although He created everything He was not created and that further confirms His creative power. Therefore, He is the foundation of all creation having been in existence before the beginning of His creative act.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. One of the uniqueness of the story of creation is the demonstration of the creative power of God. Everything He created was commanded into existence byHis word. Notable also is the separation of the water above and beneath (v. 7). Believers must know that God is eternal and in control of the universe He has created. He is infinitely above all creatures, gods and all of humanity in knowledge, wisdom and understanding. The most exciting aspect of the story of creation is that God is distinct from everything He created. Although He created everything He was not created and that further confirms His creative power. Therefore, He is the foundation of all creation having been in existence before the beginning of His creative act.
    2. Why was God's creation in sequence and what lessons can we learn from it?
  3. God's Distinctive Power in Creation Genesis 1:11-13

    The fact has been established that the world and everything in it were created through God's creative power, which continued in this passage. First was the “light” (v. 3), and the waters below the expanse and waters above the expanse (v. 7). The dry land and the vegetation, yet none of the creatures was like Him (God). In verse 11, God commanded the land to produce vegetation, seed-bearing plants and trees on the land that bear fruit with seeds in it according to their kinds and it was done according to His words (v. 13). Consequently, God was pleased with everything He had created. On the third day, there was evening and there was morning (v. 13).

    The attributes of God revealed in this lesson indicate God's distinctiveness from everything He created, so, He is Eternal. Without doubt, He is the Originator of the universe, the Creator, Fashioner, the One who commanded and everything came into being. All these attributes distinguish Him from His creatures. Notable in the passage is that after the creative activities of the first three days, God observed that everything was good. This statement stresses the excellence of God, which is repeated throughout the story of creation. The work of creation was done in sequence and in an orderly manner. God was pleased with what He created each time.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. From the story of creation, mention some attributes of God that He does not share with humankind.
    2. What does God\'s orderly creation teach believers?

Prayer Points

  • Thank God for His creation and what He is still creating.
  • Help me, Lord, to always appreciate Your creative power.
  • Give me grace to maintain everything You have created.

Fellowship and Ministry Building Activities

  • Encourage class members to take a walk and observe nature then make a list of every created thing they encounter.
  • Ask them to write a prayer of praise and thanksgiving for what God has done and continues to do in creation

Take Home

  • God is the Creator of the heavens, the earth and everything in it.
  • Believers are only stewards of what God has created.
  • God's creation is a show of His creative power.
  • God's perfection can be seen in His creation.
  • God has solution to all problems.

title: GOD CREATED LIGHTS AND ANIMALS
message:
September 9, 2018

GOD CREATED LIGHTS AND ANIMALS

Devotional Reading: Psalms 130:1-9

Lesson Scripture: Genesis 1:14-25

Golden Text

And God said, “Let there be lights in the expanse of the sky to separate the day from the night, and let them serve as signs to mark seasons and days and years. Genesis 1:14

Objectives :

By the end of the lesson, class members should be able to:

  • Mention some functions of light to humankind.
  • Discuss how they can use the story of creation to witness to unbelievers.
  • Demonstrate their willingness to take care of the animals and plants in appreciation of God's creative power.

INTRODUCTION

Mr Enoch Adama is a furniture maker. He is known in the church and community to be responsible and hard working. Sometime ago, he was given a contract by the Federal Government to construct some office furniture. Because he did not want to bring disrepute to his name, he decided to engage the services of some of his colleagues. The work began in earnest and the logs were cut into various shapes and sizes for easy assembling. Tools like nails of various sizes, hammer, leather and other materials were ready for use. After some days, when the pieces of wood and the other equipment had been put together, they became beautiful office furniture to behold.

As God's creative work progressed, His word became the tool by which all heavenly bodies, plants and animals were created. This is indicative of the fact that the creation and development of the universe were the will of God. He chose to create the world and His word was the medium by which His desire was accomplished; hence, the constant expression: “And God said ....” Through those inspired words, the creative power by which God brought order out of the formlessness and emptiness of the world flowed out. This whole process of creation reveals His power in creation. From this point, the wonders in God\'s word became more potent as the heavenly bodies began to appear. This is the focal point of today's lesson.

THE LESSON EXPLAINED

  1. The Creation of Lights Genesis 1:14-19

    The story of creation was in stages and each stage was characterised by different actions. According to verses 14 and 15, God commanded light to appear in the expanse of the sky for three reasons:

    • To separate the day from the night.
    • To mark the times of days, years and seasons. These events were solely determined by the phase of the moon.
    • To shine in the sky to illuminate the earth.
    The Scripture says that it was done according to the creative words of God. Of course, it can be seen as a further development of what God started to do on the first day, when He said, 'Let there be light, and there was light' (v. 3). In verse 16, God also created two great lights. According to the New International Version Commentary, the greater light was to govern the day and the lesser was to govern the night including the stars. Some Bible commentators support the fact that the writer deliberately avoided the words “sun" and “moon” since both were used as names for the pagan gods associated with those heavenly bodies. They are light-givers to be appreciated, but not powers to be feared or worshipped (Isaiah 40:26). Notable also in the passage is that the lights are carefully positioned in the sky so that they can illuminate the earth, to rule over the day and night and to separate darkness from light (v. 17). Again, God was pleased with what He had done.

    The importance of light to humankind and animals cannot be overemphasised. Having created both the great and lesser lights, God gave different functions to them. While the sun was to govern the day, the moon was made to govern the night and the stars help the moon to rule the night (Psalm 136:9). Furthermore, these lights were created for signs of the change of weather, so that the farmer may order his affairs with discretion/wisdom. They also give light upon the earth, so that we too may walk (John11:9) and work (John 9:4) as the duty of everyday requires. However, as important as these lights are, God did not make them to be worshipped. It is folly to making them deities (objects of worship) and give them divine honour, when God has given us dominion over all He has created including the sun, moon and stars.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. Discuss why some people worship created things instead of the Creator?
    2. How should Christians respond to God's creation?
  2. The Creation of Animals Genesis 1:20-23

    As God continued in the creation exercise, He saw the need to also create animals that live both in the water and air. He said, “Let the water teem with living creatures, and let birds fly above the earth across the expanse of the sky” (v. 20). He also created the great sea monsters (probably dreaded marine monsters, which were regarded as God's enemies in the ancient world, Psalm 104:26). After creation, the fish were conditioned to live in water while the birds flew in the air. These of course were the products of the fifth day's creative activity of God. He also commanded the creatures that live in water to reproduce their kind and to populate the sea; the birds were expected to also increase in number. However, it does appear that God moved from the “small” to the “great”; nonetheless, all were important. All these happened on the fifth day of creation.

    Ultimately, the progression of the story of creation is worthy of note; on the first and second days, God created inanimate things while on the third day; He created the vegetation, which shall bear fruits according to their kinds. On the fourth day, the great lights appeared to illuminate the world and become the light of life. On the fifth day, He created animal life and commanded them saying, “Be fruitful and multiply”, the same command He gave to humankind after creation (v. 28). By this divine blessing, animals are expected to multiply both in the sea and in the air. In fact, we can see that God's blessings upon these animals brought multiplication and fruitfulness; hence, the fish of the sea and the birds have remained innumerable because of their ability to reproduce. By God's standard, everything He had created was good (v. 21). With the appearance of both the animals of the sea and air, creation proceeded progressively to prepare for God's highest earthly creature, humankind.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. Ask members to discuss their understanding of God, especially in relation to the creation
    2. Let class members mention an animal, whether in the sea or air, and discuss its importance to humankind
  3. The Creation of Land Animals Genesis 1:24-25

    God's creation story progressed without hindrance. The sixth day was the final stage of creation, in which God brought the world into its perfect form. He commanded the land to produce living creatures according to their kinds, which can be classified into domestic, wild and small (literally, creatures that crawl on the ground). These animals may include reptiles (creeping things), insects, mice etc. Consequently, God made them all and He affirmed that what He had made was good. Of course, this was with a sense of satisfaction as He had originally intended.

    Again, it should be noted that these created animals, both small and big, were endowed with the ability to reproduce, thereby participating in procreation according to God's command. However, God did not conclude His process of creation with these animals. The climax was His plan to make a creature in His image and likeness who will be endowed with authority to rule over the fish of the sea and the birds of the air and over every living creature that moves on the ground (v. 28). Unfortunately, humankind lost the opportunity as a result of disobedience in the Garden of Eden. One of the key lessons of the story of creation is that we should endeavour to follow the example of God in creating good things for others, especially as stewards who will one day give account to God.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. Discuss the likely reasons God created wild animals, especially those that are harmful?
    2. How do we know that all the animals created are fruitful according to God's command?

Prayer Points

  • Thank you Lord for Your creative power.
  • Help us to always appreciate Your creation, both great and small.
  • May I remember to always practise my obligation as a good steward of the things God has created.

Fellowship and Ministry Building Activities

  • Encourage class members to observe one of the smallest creatures in their environment in the course of the week and ponder on the complexity of God's creation.
  • They are to share their experiences with class members next week.

Take Home

  • God is the Creator of all things, plants and animals; both great and small.
  • Believers should be ready to worship God, the Creator, as we consider the complexity of the created order.
  • God is still in the process of creation.
  • God's orderliness in creation should be appreciated by all.

title: GOD CREATED PEOPLE
message:
September 16, 2018

GOD CREATED PEOPLE

Devotional Reading: Psalm 113:11-14

Background Scripture: Genesis 1:26-31; 2:4-7

Golden Text

So God created man in his image, in the image of God he created him; male and female he created them. Genesis 1:27

Objectives :

By the end of the lesson, class members should be able to:

  • Identify some ways human beings bear a resemblance of God.
  • Specify the implication of God creating humankind in His image.
  • State at least three ways humankind is superior to other creatures.
  • Make a commitment to continually be stewards of God's creation.

INTRODUCTION

There are three friends who belong to different religions. They all believe different versions of the story of creation. The atheist believes that man evolved progressively from an animal called ape. The traditional worshipper said his forefather told him that man came into existence through a mysterious and uncontrollable wind many years ago. The Christian simply made reference to the biblical account of God's creation, which includes humankind. Because of the differences in claims, the atheist and traditional worshipper both agreed to go home and pray for more insight and converge again the next day. Interestingly, they came back with the testimony of God's revelation that He is the Creator and Sustainer of the universe.

Today's lesson focuses on the Creator, God. In fact, the highest point of all His creative acts was the making of humankind, distinguished from all other creatures because of God's Spirit in them that makes them bear His image. It was entirely a new dimension of creation that concluded the creative activities of the sixth day. Humankind was created in collaboration with the Trinity. God said, “Let us make man in our image.” (v. 26) In other words, God the Father, the Son and the Holy Spirit were involved in the creation of humankind and this was the crown of all creation. God's purpose was to create humankind in His likeness and give them authority and control over all other creatures that He had made. Consequently, humans became superior to any of the other animals. Humankind is a distinct, unique and special creation by God. We were created to have pre-eminent position as the crown of all creation and given the privilege to participate in procreation according to God's plan.

THE LESSON EXPLAINED

  1. God Made Man in His Image Genesis 1:26-28

    As observed in verse 1, everything God created was called into existence according to His word. The climax of His creative activities on the sixth day was the creation of humankind. He said in verse 26, “Let us make man in our image, in our likeness, and let them rule over the fish of the sea and the birds of the air, ...” So God created humankind, male and female, in His own image. He then blessed them saying:

    • Be fruitful and increase in number: This is a command to reproduce offspring according to their resemblance.
    • Fill the earth and subdue it. This is the authority to have control over all the other animals God had created, whether the birds of the air, the fish of the sea and all the creatures that move on the ground.

    Although there are a variety of explanations about the use of “us” in the passage but it is obvious that God referred to the heavenly host/courts or angels (Genesis 3:22; 11:17; Isaiah 6:8). Other Scriptures confirm that God's Spirit took part in the creation (Job 33:4; Psalm 104:30). In like manner, Paul tells us that God\'s Son, Jesus Christ, was at work in the creation of humankind (Colossians 1:16). In addition, the phrase “in our image or likeness” is more about having God's essential nature rather than His physical likeness. Notably, of all creation, only humankind is described as being made in the likeness of God. It is something that distinguishes humans from other animals that were created on the sixth day. Although God had given other higher animals the ability to reproduce, this is the first and only time “male and female” were distinctly mentioned. It establishes the fact that there is a special relationship between humankind and God.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    2. Discuss the differences between humankind and the other animals and the implication for all humankind.
    3. How should humankind respond to God who has created them specially?
  2. Created to Rule and Have Control Genesis 1:29-31

    The climax of God's creative activity was the making of humankind and some other animals on the sixth day. He gave humans authority over everything He has created. In verse 29 He said, “I give you every seed-bearing plant on the face of the whole earth and every tree that has fruit with seed in it. They will be yours for food.” Of course, the command to exercise authority over His creature includes all the beasts of the earth and all the birds of the air and every creature that moves on the ground. Principally, every green plant was also given to humankind to serve as food (v. 30). Interestingly, God saw that what He had made was very good. This is a proof that humankind is superior to animals and other creatures because they were created in God's likeness and commanded to have dominion and subdue the earth.

    To “rule over” means to have dominion and power over something or somebody. God ultimately rules over the earth, but He has relinquished part of His authority to humankind as it can be seen in the passage. By this directive given to humankind, God has granted us some measure of dominion apparently to participate in recreation, and to take responsibility for the environment and other animals. Therefore, humankind should appreciate God's goodness and not be wasteful or careless as we carry out this noble assignment. God was careful when He created this world; we too, must be careful with the way we care for the world He has entrusted to us to have dominion over, rule and control.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. Is it true that human activities have harmed the natural world more than it has helped it?
    2. Identify some ways humankind have misused God\'s creation and how to correct it.
  3. The Creation of Humankind Genesis 2:4-7

    God completed His work of creation on the sixth day. On the seventh day, He stopped working. He rested, blessed the day and dedicated it exclusively for the service and worship of Him, our Creator (Genesis 2:1-3). Initially, when God created the world, there were no plants and no seeds germinated because there was no rain to water the soil and no one to cultivate it. This of course was as a result of the fact that humankind had not been created. However, there was water from beneath the surface of the earth to water the ground. Consequently, He took some soil from the ground and formed humans out of it. Humankind became a living being having received the breath of God through His nostrils.

    There are two exceptional facts in the creation of humankind. We were not created simply by God's command like every other creature. Rather, it involved an action in which God took some soil from the ground and breathed the breath of life into it and humankind became a living soul. This account further confirms the fact that God is the Creator of humankind. He created humans and gave us authority to rule and have dominion over all other animals. Humankind has also been made the crown of all creations and God's representative on earth. We should, therefore, respond to God through sincere worship and exhibit a high sense of wisdom to control other creatures.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. When God created humankind, He provided enough food for their sustenance. What does this portray about God as far as provision is concerned?
    2. Why was humankind created differently from other animals?
    3. Discuss the value of humans as part of God's creation.

Prayer Points

  • Appreciate God for creating you in His image and likeness.
  • Pray that God will grant you the grace to respond to Him always as a steward.
  • Help me, Lord, to be able to witness to unbelievers about Your power to create.

Fellowship and Ministry Building Activities

  • Make a list of some of the attributes humankind share with God.
  • Lead class members to pray for the grace of God to be responsible stewards.

Take Home

  • We are created in the divine image of God.
  • Every human being has value as part of God's creation.
  • We should worship God with gratitude for the privilege of being blessed by Him.
  • God is still in the process of creation.
  • Everything in the world was made by God, humankind inclusive.

title: GOD CREATED THE FAMILY
message:
September 23, 2018

GOD CREATED THE FAMILY

Devotional Reading: Leviticus 19:11-18

Background Scripture: Genesis 2:18-24; 4:1-2

Golden Text

For this reason a man will leave his father and mother and be united to his wife, and they will become one flesh. Genesis 2:24

Objectives :

By the end of the lesson, class members should be able to:

  • Define marriage and God's intention for creating the woman.
  • Discuss the implication of creating the woman with the rib from the side of the man and not from his head.
  • Demonstrate the willingness to promote love, peace and harmony in their families.

INTRODUCTION

One Sunday, a Sunday School teacher walked into the class and asked the class members to mention at least ten things God created. Surprisingly, none of them remembered marriage. It is possible they did not know that marriage was one of the things God created as we shall study today. In the previous lessons, we learnt that God created all living and non-living things including humankind, whom He created on the sixth day. In chapter 1 verse 27, God created both male and female, but there was no detailed account as to how the female was created until chapter 2. After God had created different kinds of animals, the Scripture tells us that there was no resemblance of Adam even though God had given him the opportunity to name all the animals. Invariably, God knew that having a single sex would not be good enough, especially as regards fulfilling the mandate to be fruitful and increase in number (Genesis 1:28). Then, He decided to create the woman as “a suitable help meet for Adam; particularly as the animals were not suitable companions for him. Consequently, the focus of today's lesson is how God created the first family through whom humankind came into existence.

THE LESSON EXPLAINED

  1. A Companion Made for Adam Genesis 2:18-24

    After the creation of man, God put him in the Garden of Eden to work and care for it. He also gave him freedom to eat from any tree in the garden except the tree of the knowledge of good and evil (vv. 15-16). Having formed the trees, the beast of the field and the birds of the air from the ground, He brought them to Adam to name them, thereby showing the dominion earlier given to him (Genesis 1:26). For Adam, there was no suitable companion, thus, God created the woman from his ribs and presented her to Adam. Neither the birds nor animals could provide the needed companionship for Him. Therefore, He said, “I will make a helper suitable for him.” This literally means a partner who would complement and make Adam complete. When Adam saw the woman, he expressed satisfaction and immediately composed a lyric poetry saying: "This is now bone of my bones and flesh of my very flesh; she shall be called 'Woman,' for she was taken out of man."

    It is apparent from the passage that the creative activity of God was not complete until the woman was created. He caused Adam to fall into a deep sleep, and took a rib from his side with which He made the woman and brought her to him. In fact, this is an indication that in marriage, which is the coming together of a man and a woman under God's command, the couple symbolically become one flesh and no sex is superior to the other. According to verse 14, God has established the institution of marriage as having priority over the parent/child relationship since the man is expected to leave his parents and be united to his wife in one flesh. By implication, the two of them shall be one flesh and considered as one body, having no separate or independent rights, privileges, cares and concerns.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. Discuss the significance of taking one of the ribs of the man to create the woman and not any other part of the body.
    2. Explain the meaning of the phrase “a helper suitable for him” and its implication for marriage. v. 18b.
    3. What are the implications of a man leaving his parents only to cleave to his wife?
  2. The Significance of the Creation of Woman Genesis 4:1-2

    One of the things that distinguish God from humankind is that He is faithful to His promises unlike humans who sometimes demonstrate slackness. After the creation of the man and woman, God blessed them and said, “Be fruitful and increase in number and fill the water in the seas, and let the birds increase on the earth” (Genesis 1:28). Invariably, He commanded humankind to procreate and fill the earth. Nevertheless, this promise came to pass after the fall of humankind. Verses 1 and 2 of chapter 4 describe the fulfilment of God's initial plan of multiplication for humankind. The Scripture says that Adam had sexual relationship with his wife, Eve, and she became pregnant. Eventually, she bore her first born son and gave him the name Cain, which in Hebrew language means “acquired” and the second, Abel, meaning “a breath”.

    God is the Originator of marriage. From the passage, one can see the significance of marriage and family as ordained by God. Cain and Abel, and their parents were together as a family having been brought to life by their parents. Therefore, the creation of the woman was an indication that:

    • The man needed a companion because humans are social beings and cannot afford to be alone for life, except in times of solitude.
    • The capacity to procreate and populate the earth became complete. In fact, the uniqueness of marriage is revealed in this passage because it provides the intimate relationship in which human companionship reaches its peak.
    DISCUSSION TIME
