    1. If it is the will of God that couples should be co-equals in marriage and not a master-servant relationship why then do some men treat their wives as not important in decision-making in the home?
    2. Why do some people refuse to get married having known that God is the Originator of marriage?
    3. Discuss some lessons in today's passage that can help Christian couples to strengthen their relationships.

Prayer Points

  • Help me, O God, to understand the value of marriage according to Your standard.
  • Help every married couple to see their partners as their companion and not slaves/servants.
  • Pray that God will intervene in every home that is at the verge of collapse.

Fellowship and Ministry Building Activities

  • Two class members, preferably a male and a female, should dramatise the action of Adam when he saw Eve.
  • Let each member of the class get a partner and pray for both the singles and married for God's will to be done in their lives.

Take Home

  • God is the Originator of marriage.
  • God is interested in who and how we marry, as Christians.
  • Procreation is part of God's reason for creating the woman.
  • Believers should endeavour to extend the love of God through our families in the way they care for one another.
  • Christian couples should complement each other.

title: GOD CREATES, HUMANS SIN
message:
September 30, 2018

GOD CREATES, HUMANS SIN

Devotional Reading: Psalm 51:1-12

Background Scripture: Genesis 3

Lesson Scripture: Genesis 3:8-17, 20-24

Golden Text

So, the LORD God banished him from the Garden of Eden to work the ground from which he had been taken. Genesis 3:23

Objectives :

By the end of the lesson, class members should be able to:

  • Discuss the consequences of sin in the life of humans.
  • Identify the effects of the sin of Adam on humanity.
  • · Identify the effects of the sin of Adam on humanity.

INTRODUCTION

His father left the home with a stern warning that he should neither go out nor bring his friends into the compound to play. However, not long after his father left, Paul invited his friends and they began to play football in the compound against his father's instruction. In the process, the windscreen of one of the cars broke. In fear and anticipation of the punishment that awaits him, Paul broke down in tears and hid when he heard the sound of his father's car later in the day. His father was surprised that Paul refused to open the gate as it was his usual practice. Immediately, he suspected something unusual had happened. Paul was duly punishment by his father for disobeying his order.

Genesis chapter 3 is the beginning of a new scene after the creation of everything. God brought Adam and Eve into the Garden of Eden. They both lived a mutual and fulfilled life, being in fellowship with God and in companionship with each other. After all, the environment in the garden provided a beautiful surrounding and their needs were always met until things suddenly changed. The serpent subtly deceived the woman to eat from the forbidden fruit and so distorted God's plan for them. Because they were convinced by the serpent that they would be better off as autonomous individuals than living in subordinate obedience to God, God's original plan for them was altered. Today's lesson focuses on the origin of sin (the fall of humankind) and the consequences that followed.

THE LESSON EXPLAINED

  1. Man's Alienation from God Genesis 3:8-10

    The account of how sin came into the world emphasises the fact that human beings are answerable for their actions and must suffer the consequences of their sins (Galatians 6:7-9). When God instituted the first family, Adam and Eve, He made everything available that would make life comfortable for them in the garden. Unfortunately, they forfeited the privilege when they ate the forbidden fruit. Of course, the aftermath of their disobedience was alienation from God. They hid among the trees of the garden when they heard the sound of the Lord as He was walking in the cool of the day. But because God is omnipresent, He was aware of their sin thus He called to the man saying, “Where are you?” (v. 9) According to verse 10, the man's response was not a direct answer to God's question of where are you. He simply said, “I heard you in the garden, and I was afraid because I was naked; so I hid."

    It is obvious that until the appearance of the serpent, there was no sin or evil in the world because everything God created was good. Although the serpent had promised them that they would become like God, knowing good and evil when they eat the fruit but it did not come true as expected. However, God's probing question: “Where are you?” stirred up a sense of guilt, nakedness, fear and shame in Adam and Eve. Consequently, their constant and sweet relationship with God was marred and finally they were alienated from Him, which means spiritual death. In other words, they could no longer have fellowship with God (v. 8). Apparently, separation, isolation, fear and sense of guilt are some of the consequences of sin in the life of humankind. The only antidote is confession and genuine repentance. Even today, many people no longer enjoy sweet fellowship with God because of their sinful nature but when we confess and ask for forgiveness, He will hear and restore us to Himself.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. Discuss the implication of God's question “Where are you”?
    2. What would have been the couple's best reply to God?
    3. Identify some ways Christians behave like Adam and Eve, who hid when they heard the sound of God.
  2. Declaration of Punishment Genesis 3:11-17

    This passage starts with a question to Adam and his wife, Eve. After their response to God's question of “Where are you” God asked two important questions. He said, “Who told you that you are naked? Have you eaten from the tree that I commanded you not to eat from?” Again, instead of taking responsibility for their actions, they (Adam and Eve) resorted to shifting blames; accusations and counter accusations. Adam blamed Eve for giving him the fruit while Eve blamed the serpent for tempting her. This is a true reflection of the attitude of some believers who often shift blames to others after they have sinned instead of asking for forgiveness. Invariably, both of them failed to accept responsibility for their disobedience to God's command. God, therefore, pronounced curses and punishment on them. Thus:

    • The serpent was cursed above all livestock and wild animals.
    • It will begin to crawl on its belly and feed on dust.
    • Enmity was put between the serpent and the woman, even their offspring. It was fulfilled in Christ\'s victory over Satan (Romans 16:20). To the woman:
    • Her pain during childbirth will be greatly increased.
    • Her desire will be for her husband.
    • Her husband will rule over her.

    To the man: The ground was cursed and through painful labour, he will produce what he would eat throughout his lifetime. Unfortunately, these pronouncements have greatly affected humankind. There is always hostility between man and snakes and there is no childbirth without pain. In addition, women are perpetually under the control of their husbands who struggle to live by the fruit of their labour. It is not uncommon that some people continuously live in sin without the consciousness of the punishment from God. Apostle Paul said, “For the wages of sin is death, but the gift of God is eternal life in Christ Jesus our Lord.” (Romans 6:23). Therefore, believers should endeavour to live holy lives so that we will escape the punishment that awaits sinners.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. Apart from the serpent, the architect of the sin, did Adam and Eve deserve the punishment they received?
    2. What was the mistake of Adam in verse 12 and what are some ways Christians behave like him today?
    3. Discuss the various ways Satan deceives people today.
  3. God's Plan of Redemption and Restoration Genesis 3:20-24

    One of the attributes of God is compassion. Immediately He pronounced judgment on Adam and Eve, God also made adequate plans for their redemption and restoration. He made garments of animal skins to clothe them since they were naked. He concluded that since humankind have possessed the knowledge of what is good and bad, they must not be allowed to take from the fruit that gives life (v. 22). Subsequently, they were sent out of the Garden of Eden so that the man would begin to cultivate the soil from which he has been formed according to God's pronouncement. Furthermore, God made adequate provision to secure the garden. So, living creatures and flaming sword, which rotates in all directions, were put at the east side of the garden. However, in the new creation, all God's people will have access to the tree (Revelation 2:7; 22:2).

    Nonetheless, because of God's nature to forgive, He chose to seek them again. He took the first step in His new work of redemption and restoration with Adam and Eve when He decided to clothe them. By this act, He showed that He would not punish them for their disobedience forever. This redemptive love of God came to the fullest when Jesus died for sinners. In fact, nothing could be more loving than to seek the redemption of sinners before they would “eat of the tree of life and live forever,” This loving concern of God prefigured an age of redemption that would bring humankind back to a restored fellowship with Him through His saving grace.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. What is the significance of clothing of Adam and Eve's nakedness after they had sinned?
    2. Discuss the best ways to keep our relationship with God based on today's lesson.
    3. Discuss the consequences of sin.

Prayer Points

  • Thank you Lord for this reminder that sin has its consequences in the lives of believers.
  • Forgive my sins, O God, and help me to restore my relationship with You again.
  • Teach me to obey Your words, O Lord.

Fellowship and Ministry Building Activities

  • Let class members make a list of the consequences of sin and compare them with the blessings of God according to the Scriptures.
  • Let them pray for one another for forgiveness and restoration.

Take Home

  • God does not tolerate sin, no matter who is involved.
  • We are sinful men and women by nature.
  • Sin has its consequences.
  • Believers should acknowledge their sins and seek reconciliation with God through confession and genuine repentance.
  • God's redemption and restoration are sure.

title: NOAH'S STEADFAST FAITH
message:
October 7, 2018

NOAH'S STEADFAST FAITH

Devotional Reading: Matthew 24:36-44

Background Scripture: Genesis 6:8-19

Lesson Scripture: Genesis 6:9b-22

Golden Text

Noah did everything just as God commanded him. Genesis 6:22

Objectives :

By the end of the lesson, class members should be able to:

  • Discuss how Christians can maintain holy lifestyles in this corrupt generation.
  • Differentiate between the evils in the days of Noah and the present age.
  • Discuss the reward of obedience to God.

INTRODUCTION

A story was told of Sister Grace and her outstanding performance during her university days. According to the story, she grew up with an uncle who succeeded in instilling the fear of God and hard work in her, through biblical teachings. Therefore, she grew to be responsible, dutiful and committed to her studies throughout her days in the university. She never attended parties or stayed away from classes even though that was the practice of almost everyone in her hostel. Despite the effort of the school management to curb the girls and make them know the consequences of their actions, they remained defiant. However, because of Sister Grace's disciplined lifestyle; she was always attentive in class. Regardless of being ridiculed by friends, she was focused and refused to compromise her faith. She eventually emerged the best graduating student, which qualified her for a scholarship to study in any university of her choice outside the country while others were disqualified.

The story of Noah and the ark is quite familiar and the lessons are true and ever relevant. His days were characterised by so much wickedness that God was grieved that He ever made humankind. God, therefore, swore to wipe off humanity but He was pleased with Noah because he was upright in his relationship with God. Despite the evil in his days, He was described as holy and blameless. Consequently, God commanded Noah to construct an ark for himself and his family and Noah obeyed and did everything according to the command of God. This is the focus of today's lesson.

THE LESSON EXPLAINED

  1. Noah: A Just Man Genesis 6:9-13

    The first few verses of the chapter describe the wicked activities of humankind on the surface of the earth as they began to increase (v. 1). The earth was corrupt and full of violence. A similar phenomenon is prevalent in Nigeria today like: kidnapping, ritual killing, sexual immorality, stealing, etc. Because of God\'s nature of holiness, He was grieved that He ever created humankind. Therefore, He resolved to wipe off humankind and animals that move on the ground and the birds of the air (vv. 1-8, 13). However, God found a man (Noah) to be righteous and blameless despite the corrupt practices of his days. Apostle Peter called him a preacher of righteousness (2 Peter 2:5). He also walked with God. In other words, his lifestyle was in contrast to the people of his days. Even though he may not be completely free from sin, he lived righteously (Psalm 15:2-5). His consistent faith in God made him just and blameless.

    The dictionary defines righteousness as “behaviour that is morally justifiable or right.” Such a behaviour is characterised by accepted standards of morality, justice, virtue, or uprightness. Apart from Noah, the Bible has a record of people who were described as righteous and blameless in the sight of God because of their genuine faith and obedient lifestyle. For example, Zechariah and Elizabeth, his wife (Luke 1:6); Abel (Hebrews 11:4); Daniel and Job (Ezekiel 14:14). These men did not compromise their faith because the people of their days were corrupt and violent (v. 11). This further emphasises the fact that the way of life of people in the society is not an excuse for anyone to engage in sin. Unfortunately today, some people, including Christians say, “If you cannot beat them, you join them” simply to justify their wicked practices. In fact, the lesson is a reminder that God expects His people to live holy lives without regardless of the prevailing circumstances. This can be done when we give our lives to God and allow the Holy Spirit to direct our affairs daily.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. Can we still find people like Noah in this generation?
    2. Discuss how Noah was able to abstain from the corruption of his days.
    3. How can one live blamelessly in this perverse world?
  2. The Command to Make an Ark Genesis 6:14-18

    The fact has been established that because of humankind\'s violent and corrupt deeds, God resolved to put an end to the existence of all people on earth, except Noah whom He found to be righteous and blameless (v. 13). In verse 14, God commanded Noah to construct an ark for himself with detailed specifications before He would carry out the planned destruction. The ark was to be built with cypress wood; possibly the type that will not be affected by water or termite. The shape of the ark would be box-like and from the specifications it will be 450 feet long, 75 feet wide and 45 feet high (approximately 11⁄2 standard football field length). Furthermore, Noah was commanded to make a roof on the ark of 18 inches to the top, a door on the side with lower, middle and upper decks (vv. 14-16), probably for ventilation. At least for the first time, God stated clearly how he intends to destroy the earth. He said, “I am going to bring floodwaters on the earth to destroy all life under the heavens, every creature that has the breath of life in it ....” In fact, it is emphatically stated that everything on earth will perish (v. 17). But God promised to establish a covenant relationship with Noah, which suggests that he and his family will not be destroyed by the flood.

    The story of Noah, the ark and the flood is one of the well-known Bible stories of all times. God decided to put an end to the evil on earth through flood (v. 13). The phrase, “all people of the earth” indicates that the effect of the flood was going to be universal. After all, the universal corruption of the world also demands that the punishment must be universal. Therefore, it will affect all creatures; they will be wiped off (Genesis 6:7). But God will preserve Noah\'s life and that of every member of his family. Note that when sin (corruption, killing, wickedness, etc.) become the norms in a nation like the days of Noah, such a nation is destined for ruin. However, God will always care and protect the righteous that have not compromised their faith. Peter description of Noah's experience (1 Peter 3:20; 2 Peter 2:5), suggested that the account should be seen more as God's saving humanity from sinful self-destruction than merely as punishment for sin.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. Apart from total destruction, are there other means God would have used to end the existence of all wicked people on earth? If yes, mention one of them.
    2. Noah was given detailed instructions as to how he should build the ark. Discuss how important these instructions were to him.
  3. Noah's Perfect Obedience Genesis 6:19-22

    Noah was given detailed instruction concerning the construction of the ark with the promise to establish a covenant with him. Thereafter, God began to unfold His plans. According to verses 19 and 20, Noah was given two specific instructions: To bring __ into the ark two of all living creatures male and female, which will be kept with him alive in the ark. He was also to take along every kind of food for him and his family members for the period the flood will last. Obviously, to an ordinary man, these instructions about the construction of the ark would have seemed cumbersome and so keeping to the details would be difficult. But the Scripture says that Noah did everything just as God commanded him (v. 22), which stresses his complete obedience to God.

    One of the greatest lessons in today's passage is that God decided to extend His loving concern not only to Noah but to his whole family as they were saved from the disaster. It is also noteworthy that Noah demonstrated total and not partial obedience to God in all the instructions he was given. He, therefore, displayed one of the virtues of a righteous and blameless man. This made God protect him, his sons, wife and sons' wives from the effect of the great flood. Ultimately, Noah became one of the biblical heroes whose obedience and uprightness have remained a model to all believers. By this, all Christians should know that God's commandments and instructions must be strictly followed, no matter how burdensome we think they are. This is important because God delights in complete obedience to Him and obedience is better than sacrifice.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. How easy is it to follow God's instructions, especially when they seem not to make sense to us?
    2. According to the passage, God's saving grace was extended to Noah's family as they were saved from destruction. Can children also be saved today because of the faith of their parents? If no, why?

Prayer Points

  • Pray that God will make you steadfast in the faith, no matter the circumstances that surround you.
  • Ask God to give you the grace to be obedient to Him in all things.
  • Pray that God will help you to remain a model in your family, church and community, like Noah.

Fellowship and Ministry Building Activities

  • Divide the class into two, let each group pick a character in the Bible and discuss the rewards of their obedience and disobedience.
  • Encourage them to pray for the grace to be obedient to God and their leaders.

Take Home

  • Christians should be ready to follow God's instructions even when they seem not to make sense.
  • There is reward in obedience just as there is punishment in disobedience.
  • Uprightness is a virtue that should be exhibited by all believers.
  • It is possible to maintain holiness and uprightness even in the midst of corrupt people.

title: GOD IS ALWAYS WORKING
message:
October 14, 2018

GOD IS ALWAYS WORKING

Devotional Reading: Hebrews 11:4-10

Background Scripture: Genesis 9

Lesson Scripture: Genesis 10:2, 11:10, 27, 31-32; 12:1-4

Golden Text

"I will make you into a great nation and I will bless you; I will make your name great, and you will be a blessing. I will bless those who bless you, and whoever curses you I will curse; and all peoples on earth will be blessed through you." Genesis 12:2-3

Objectives :

By the end of the lesson, class members should be able to:

  • Identify the influence of family background in building our relationship with God.
  • Explain how God sometimes uses unbelievers to make His purpose known.
  • Discuss the truth that believers in Christ are part of the covenant God made with Abraham.

INTRODUCTION

When we go through the pages of the Bible, it could be boring when we read about the genealogy of people sometimes, we even skip the pages. The issue of genealogy is a serious one in that many people have ignorantly been trapped in relationships because they knew little or nothing about their lineage. A story was told about Sister Faith and Brother Simon who grew up in the same community in the early 80’s. Accidentally, they attended the same primary and secondary school. During their university days, they belonged to the same fellowship and had their National Youth Service in the same state. They were known to be close friends even by their parents. Immediately after their Youth Service Corp, Brother Simon who said he had prayed and had the conviction to marry sister Faith made his intention known to her. In fact, sister Faith wasted no time in giving her consent. Out of excitement, they decided to inform their parents and probably pick a date for family introduction.

Unfortunately, when the two families met on the day of introduction, it was discovered that Brother Simon and Sister Faith are from the same lineage and so they cannot get married. As they both realised that it was not proper for them to get married, they blamed their parents for failing to make them know their lineage early enough. Today's lesson places emphasis on the importance of knowing our genealogy. Genealogy is indispensable as it lays the foundation for all that follows. God can be seen working through genealogies.

THE LESSON EXPLAINED

  1. Noah's Son's Descendants Genesis 10:2; 11:10, 27

    The passage has a comprehensive account of Noah and his descendants. The sons of Noah who came out of the ark after the flood disaster were Shem, Ham (the father of Canaan) and Jepheth (v. 2). Therefore, the three sons of Noah are the ancestors of all the people of the earth (Genesis 9:18). Just as it is natural for different families on earth to reproduce so it was with Noah and his three children. Noah's three sons had their own descendants after them. First, according to verse 2, Gomer, Magog, Madai, Javan, Tubal, Meshech, and Tiras were the people who bear their names as descendants of Japheth. Furthermore, two years after the flood, Shem who probably was the oldest son of Noah had a son whose name was Arphaxad. He also had other children (v. 11) at the age of 500. Terah also was the father of Abram, Nahor and Haran. Nevertheless, God chose Abram from the family of Shem as the recipient through whom He would fulfil His covenant.

    Every family on planet earth has an origin. No individual on earth exists in isolation. We all have our lineage just like Noah had several descendants through his three children. Noteworthy is the fact that the covenant God made with Noah was from one generation to another. In other words, it is continuous. However, Christians should remember that we are heirs of the covenant of God through Jesus Christ. Therefore, everyone who accepts Jesus as Saviour and Lord becomes a recipient of the new covenant and heirs with Him. This presupposes the fact that one does not necessarily need to be born a Jew in order to partake in the covenant but be saved through faith in Jesus Christ.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. Let the class members mention some significant events in their family probably from the last four decades.
    2. Discuss how family background can influence their children's life decisions.
  2. Terah and His Family Relocate Genesis 11:31-32

    Noah had a long and great family background. From verses 10 to 26 we have the record of the genealogy of Shem, the oldest son of Noah. At the age of 70, Terah became the father of Abram, Nahor and Haran. He led his family to relocate towards Canaan, the land God later promised and gave to Abraham and his descendants. Although the reason for the relocation is not stated, the Scripture says that after a while, Terah decided to relocate from the city of Ur of the Chaldeans to the land of Canaan. He left with his son Abram, grandson Lot and his daughter in-law Sarai (the wife of Abram). According to verse 31, they went as far as Haran and lived there until his death at the age of 205.

    It is evident from the passage that God entered into a covenant relationship with Noah and his family after the flood and this covenant continues throughout all generations. However, three things are paramount in the fulfilment of God's plans: His programmes, the timing and the recipients. God places great importance on His timing and ultimately decides through whom He will achieve His purpose. It could be an unbeliever, provided the aim is accomplished to the glory of God.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. Give some instances of how unbelievers were instrumental to doing what is right in your community.
    2. Discuss the effects of failing to do the will of God. Give some biblical examples.
  3. A Call into a New Covenant Genesis 12:1-4

    This passage begins with God extending His call to Abram. The call was with the command to leave his country, people and his father\'s household to an unknown destination, which He promised to show him (v. 1). The call came with different promises. For instance, from verse 2 to 4, God promised to:

    • Make him into a great nation and to bless him.
    • Make his name great among the nations so that he will be a blessing.
    • Bless those who bless him as well as curse those who curse him.
    • All people on earth will be blessed through him.

    According to verse 4, Abram left as commanded by God; with his wife, Sarai and cousin, Lot at the age of seventy-five. Although God's call to Abram to go to an unknown place looks incomprehensible from human perspective; his quick response is amazing. He promptly acted in faith and left as instructed by God. Little wonder the author of Hebrews credited him for his faith. This singular step, therefore, has made Abram the progenitor of a new community through which God has brought about salvation to humankind. It marked the beginning of God's new covenant relationship with him. By implication, God's dealing with Abram was a move towards saving humanity, culminating in the coming of the Messiah from the lineage of Abraham (Matthew 1). Of course, God is still in the business of calling His people as a way of reaching the whole world for Him through Jesus Christ.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. Discuss how the whole world has benefitted from the covenant of God with Abram.
    2. How can believers be recipients of God's blessing to Abram?
    3. What are some of the things people consider difficult to leave in order to follow Jesus?

Prayer Points

  • Thank God who has extended His covenant of salvation to you through His Son, Jesus Christ.
  • Pray that God will enable you to be part of His instruments to win souls into His covenant relationship.
  • Ask God to help you to be a good example of faith in Christ to your children and relatives.

Fellowship and Ministry Building Activities

  • Class members should write at least five reasons they would not have answered the call of God at the age of Abram when God called him to leave his family to a new place.

Take Home

  • God rewards faithfulness at all times.
  • Total obedience to God attracts divine blessings.
  • Family background can serve as a catalyst or impediment to one's relationship with God.
  • We should be ready to answer God's call at all times.
  • Christians should be good examples of the faith to the people around them.

title: ABRAHAM AND SARAH BIRTH GOD'S PEOPLE
message:
October 21, 2018

ABRAHAM AND SARAH BIRTH GOD'S PEOPLE

Devotional Reading: Luke 1:26-38

Background Scripture / Lesson Scripture: Genesis 18:9-15; 21:1-7

Golden Text

Now the LORD was gracious to Sarah as he had said, and the LORD did for Sarah what he had promised. Genesis 21:1

Objectives :

By the end of the lesson, class members should be able to:

  • Distinguish between the promises of God and that of humankind.
  • Discuss the joys as well as the responsibilities associated with parenting.
  • Learn to trust in God even when God delays to answers their prayers.

INTRODUCTION

Barrenness has always been a major challenge even among Christian couples, particularly in the African setting. Sadly, women are mostly blamed for their inability to conceive even when it defies medical explanation. Such was the story of Mr and Mrs Isaac Obodo who have been married for twenty-five years without any child. As a result of this, Mrs Ruth Obodo has been summoned to several family meetings and has been asked some questions she could not provide answers to. After much threat, she was asked to come to the village to perform some rituals and take some native herbs. But the couple refused to compromise their faith despite pressure from friends and parents. Even though they have suffered shame and reproach, they resolved to continue to trust God to bless them with children. However, during the period of waiting, God continually assured them that they will have children of their own and this made them more courageous. Some time later, the woman got pregnant and gave birth to a set of twins according to the promise of God for them. The naming ceremony attracted people from all walks of life while the news became the headline in most of the national dailies.

Today's lesson focuses on the story of Abraham and Sarah, the parents of Isaac. The study is centred on how God blessed them; having waited for a period of twenty five years, after the promise of a son to them was made. The story emphasises two important facts: (1) that God does everything at His own appointed time, especially for those who trust in Him like Abraham and Sarah. (2) With God all things are possible for those that believe. Even though Sarah doubted God's promise because of her age, God was faithful to His promise.

THE LESSON EXPLAINED

  1. The Promise of a Son to Abram and Sarah Genesis 18:9-15

    God had earlier promised to give Abraham a son through his wife Sarah so that she will be the mother of all nations; and kings of people will come from her. Precisely, the son’s would be called Isaac (Genesis 17:16, 19). The preceding verses of chapter 18 have the account of the three visitors who met Abraham by the tree of Mamre. Worthy of note is Abraham\'s warm reception and hospitality towards the men, even though he did not know they were angels sent to him (vv. 3-8). The plan of God to bless the couple with a son was again confirmed. But just as Abraham laughed in the previous encounter with God (Genesis 17:17), Sarah also laughed at the possibility of her having children at her old age. Standing quietly at the entrance of the tent, she said, “After I am worn out, and my master is old, will I now have this pleasure?” In fact, Sarah reasoned like every other woman would have reasoned because of the difficulty of bearing children at old age. Nevertheless, the response of the angel was remarkable. He said, “Is anything too hard for the Lord?” (v. 14) In other words, there is nothing God cannot do including procreation, notwithstanding the age. Similarly, the same affirmation of God\'s limitless power was made known when the angel visited Mary, the mother of Jesus (Luke 1: 37).

    God is capable of doing whatever He wants to do without any barrier. Of course, barrenness in those days was seen as a curse from God. Sarah seem to have given up on child-bearing thus she doubted the possibility of the pronouncement and laughed. It was the same attitude that compelled her to make Abraham have a child through her maid, Hagar. Even though she laughed, she was afraid to admit that she doubted God's promise and power (v. 15). However, God still showed mercy by fulfilling His promise. God's reply to her shows that with humans, many things may be impossible but with God all things are possible.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. Why do some people find it difficult to believe God's promises?
    2. What would have been your response to the promise of having a child at old age if you were Sarah?
    3. Discuss the place of hospitality in receiving God's promise.
  2. The Birth of Isaac Genesis 21:1-7

    One of the things that distinguish God from humankind is His ability to keep His promises. When the set time came, God\'s promise to Abraham and Sarah was fulfilled. God visited Sarah, she conceived and bore a son to Abraham and they named him Isaac, which in Hebrew language means 'He laughs'. In fact, the joy and excitement of his parents at his birth is reflected in this name. She said in verse 6, “God has brought me laughter, and everyone who hears about it will laugh with me.” Isaac was circumcised when he was eight days old in accordance with the covenant between God and Abraham (Genesis 17:6-14). Sarah's testimony was based on the fact that no one expected that she would ever nurse a child for her husband Abraham, yet she has borne a son in her old age (v. 7). The climax of the testimony is that Abraham was a hundred years old when Isaac was born (v. 5). Ultimately, not only was Sarah happy but those around her were also joyful at the fulfilment of God's promise to the couple.

    The birth of Isaac, unlike Ishmael, was God's doing (Galatians 4:21-28). Through this promised child and his descendants, God will keep His covenant with Abraham, which suggests the supernatural aspect of his conception and birth. Although the fulfilment of the promise took twenty-five years, what is important is its fulfilment at the appointed time. Undoubtedly, the miracle was for God's name to be glorified and to make people believe that God still works miracles in the lives of His people. Therefore, waiting couples should be encouraged to continue to trust in God for His miracles, no matter how long it will take God to fulfil His promises.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. Some people believe that the era of miracles and supernatural intervention has passed. What is your view?
    2. How will you describe God\'s timing, even when He appears to be very late?
    3. Why did God prolong the long predicted miracle of the birth of Isaac?

Prayer Points

  • Pray that God's promises concerning your life will be fulfilled.
  • Pray against every form of delay in your life, marriage and even business.
  • Ask God to break every yoke of barrenness in the life of all waiting mothers.

Fellowship and Ministry Building Activities

  • Encourage at least two class members to briefly share testimonies of how God blessed a couple with a promised child after many years of waiting.
  • Let class members agree on a day to fast and pray for waiting couples in their church and families.

Take Home

  • Christians should learn to trust God even when hope seems lost.
  • The promises of God can never go unfulfilled (Romans 9:6-13).
  • Waiting on God for a particular need can be difficult and frustrating but the end is always glorious.
  • God knows what is best for us all.
  • Delay in receiving God's blessing is not an indication that He has forgotten us.

title: ISAAC AND REBEKAH CONTINUE THE LEGACY
message:
October 28, 2018

ISAAC AND REBEKAH CONTINUE THE LEGACY

Devotional Reading: Ephesians 5:21-33

Background Scripture: Genesis 24

Lesson Scripture: Genesis 24:12-21, 61-67

Golden Text

Then Rebekah and her maids got ready and mounted their camels and went back with the man. So the servant took Rebekah and left. Genesis 24:61

Objectives :

By the end of the lesson, class members should be able to:

  • Explain the importance of prayer and faith in the Almighty, in all human endeavours.
  • Describe the imperative of willingness in fulfilling the purpose of God for one's life.
  • Identify human roles in the continuity of God's programme for the salvation of humankind.

INTRODUCTION

Mr Efosa Epen was a faithful and hard-working staff of a production company. He was known to be committed to his work and would never involve himself in any doubtful deal, even when his salary was meagre with much responsibility. Mr Efosa served the company with exceptional faithfulness, zeal and trustworthiness. At his retirement, the company organised a befitting service to honour him. It was a programme that attracted senior management staff, other members of staff and some customers of the company. Having listened to the testimonies from people about Mr Efosa's sincere contributions to the growth of the company, the chairman of the company was moved and asked Mr Efosa to get a replacement from among his children in order to continue his good legacy in the company. In our lesson today, we shall study how the legacy that begun with Abraham continued through his son, Isaac and his wife, Rebekah.

THE LESSON EXPLAINED

  1. The Prayer of a Loyal Servant Genesis 24:12-16

    Abraham was already old and well advanced in age. He was blessed in every way according to the promise of God to him. Because Isaac had grown up to a marriageable age thus Abraham, his father, compelled his chief servant to swear an oath to get a wife for Isaac among his people (24:1-10), and that he would not get a wife for his son from among the Canaanites. The servant demonstrated obedience and, thereafter, embarked on the journey to the town of Nahor. He was specific in his prayer to God for His guidance in the choice of a wife for Isaac. Although he was not given specifications about the type of woman but the servant acknowledged the importance of prayers in accomplishing the task. He, therefore, prayed and said, O LORD, God of my master Abraham, give me success today, and kindness to my master Abraham." (v. 12) Thereafter, he asked for a sign to validate his choice of a wife for his master's son, Isaac. He stood beside the spring to see the daughters of the townspeople as they came to fetch water. Verse 16 describes Rebekah as very fair looking and a virgin who came to fill her pitcher from the well.

    The place of prayer of faith cannot be underestimated. The prayer offered by the servant was to enable him know the perfect will of God in marriage for his master's son. By doing so, he exemplified loyalty and faithfulness to his master, and faith and absolute trust in God. He was committed to the assignment entrusted to him by his master and at the same time trusted God to accomplish the task on his behalf. He knew he could not succeed without God so he prayed and asked for guidance and success in the journey. The servant understood the fact that human wisdom or experience cannot guarantee success or breakthrough if God is not involved. In fact, this is an attestation that when we pray with faith concerning anything according to the will of God, He hears and gives us success (James 5:15-16).

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. What is your view about asking for signs before you take any decision?
    2. Describe Abraham's servant, according to the passage of today
  2. The Servant Receives Answer to Prayer Genesis 24:17-21

    The servant's earnest prayer for a successful journey received an immediate answer. Immediately after his prayer, he saw Rebekah, the daughter of Bethuel, who was the son of Abraham's brother Nahor and his wife Milcah. She came to fetch water from the well. Probably as directed by God, he approached her and said, “Give me to drink; I pray thee, a little water from thy pitcher.” (v. 27) Even though she was unaware of the servant's mission, Rebekah demonstrated generosity and was respectful. She hastily emptied her pitcher of water for the servant and also offered to give water to all his camels. However, the servant watched carefully to ascertain whether his prayers had been answered. God is indeed a prayer answering God. The servant's journey was made successful. Rebekah did exactly as the servant previously requested from God without any anticipation of the servant's task.

    When believers pray according to the will of God without necessarily asking for a sign, He hears and gives us answers. Christians should be mindful of asking for signs whenever we pray. The fact that Abraham's servant asked for a sign to determine God's will, which eventually came to pass should not be a precondition for prayer. The Bible categorically states that people pray without receiving answers because such prayers were not offered according to the will of God. We should know that God is always attentive to prayers offered in faith and according to His will.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. Is it biblical to always ask for signs in order to know the will of God for us?
    2. Can you share the experience of how God answered your prayer in a confusing situation?
    3. What is the place of generosity in receiving God's blessings?
  3. Rebekah Is Married to Isaac Genesis 24:61-67

    The journey embarked upon by Abraham's servant was accomplished. Rebekah gave her consent to follow the servant (v. 58). Therefore, immediately after the marriage rite had been perfected, the servant sought for permission to go with Rebekah to his master, Abraham. As it was their custom, Rebekah and two of her maids embarked on the journey to Canaan. The discourse between Rebekah and the servant in verses 64 and 65 was another confirmation that she was actually God's will for Isaac. Finally, Isaac brought Rebekah, his newly wedded wife, to the tent of his mother Sarah. He loved her and he was comforted after the death of his mother.

    Worthy of note in the passage is Rebekah's decision to go with the man in order to become Isaac's wife. The decision exemplifies two things: her faith in God who had chosen her as an heir to the covenant and her willingness to submit to the will of God and followed the servant to Canaan. Thereafter, Isaac and Rebekah became co-heirs to the covenant God had made with Abraham. Faith in God and the willingness to do His will are two major keys to relating and receiving divine favour. The example of Rebekah should be emulated by believers in their relationship with God, no matter how difficult the decision seems.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. Should Christians be involved in match-making marriages? Discuss some of its negative consequences?
    2. How can a young man/lady know God's will of a future partner for him/her? Discuss some common mistakes young people make today in their choice of partners.

Prayer Points

  1. Lord, I appreciate you for answering my prayers always.
  2. Ask for grace to always do the will of God.
  3. Lord, I need Your guidance in my life's endeavours.

Fellowship and Ministry Building Activities

  • Let at least two class members share personal testimonies of how God helped them recently in making the right decision at the point of confusion.

Take Home

  • Christians should know the importance of prayer and faith in their walk with God.
  • We should have absolute faith and trust in God.
  • Human wisdom or experience cannot guarantee success or breakthrough without God.
  • Believers do not necessarily need to demand for a sign before God hears and answers our prayers.
  • There is need to be generous and be respectful.

title: A TROUBLED BIRTH
message:
November 4, 2018

A TROUBLED BIRTH

Devotional Reading: Matthew 16:13-20

Background Scripture / Lesson Scripture: Genesis 25:19-34

Golden Text

The Lord said to her, “Two nations are in your womb, and two peoples from within you will be separated; one people will be stronger than the other, and the older will serve the younger.” Genesis 25:23

Objectives :

By the end of the lesson, class members should be able to:

  • State how waiting period could be challenging when one is trusting God concerning certain issues.
  • Explain why husbands must intercede for their wives and family members like Isaac did for his wife.
  • Mention three ways people inquire about their future these days.

INTRODUCTION

A story of a particular family was told who had a set of twin boys. According to the story, the trouble or rivalry between the boys started while they were in the womb. Their mother became so uncomfortable that she went to the hospital to inquire about the well-being of the unborn children. After series of scan, it was discovered that the male child suppressed the female in their positions. However, after birth, the rivalry became more pronounced when their father showed his preference for the male child while their mother preferred the female child over the male. Gradually they divided their home and the two children became bitter toward each other and their parents. Unfortunately, the problem extended to their lineage. Indeed, this is usually the outcome when parents deliberately show favouritism among their children.

Rivalry between siblings has always been a major problem. The prominent ones in the Bible are Cain and Abel, Isaac and Ishmael, Joseph and his brothers as well as Jacob and Esau, which is our focus today. It has been observed that rivalry among siblings can sometimes be caused by parents that show preferential treatment to one child over the others. The lesson of today will help us see clearly the harm that can be done to a family as a result of parental preferential treatment like the case of Jacob and Esau whose trouble started from the time of conception.

THE LESSON EXPLAINED

  1. Isaac and Rebekah's Waiting Period Genesis 25:19-23

    The story of Isaac is similar to that of his father Abraham. He was the promised child born when Abraham and Sarah were already old according to God's plan for them (Genesis 21:1ff). When Isaac was forty years old, he married Rebekah, the daughter of Bethuel (an Aramean from Mesopotamia) and sister of Laban. According to verse 21, Rebekah had no child for about twenty years, and to be barren in those days was a sign of God's wrath on an individual. Isaac who was more spiritually sensitive to what God can do prayed on behalf of his wife. God answered his prayer as Rebekah became pregnant. She was going to have a set of twins but before their birth, they struggled against each other in the womb. Upon their mother's inquiry, the Lord said to her, “Two nations are in your womb and two peoples from within you will be separated; one people will be stronger than the other, and the older will serve the younger” (v. 23). Some Bible scholars have concluded that the enmity between Israelites and Edomites can be traced to the birth of these twin brothers. Apostle Paul also attested to this when he stated that before they were born, God had already preferred Jacob to Esau (Romans 9:11-13). Apparently, two things are revealed in this passage:

    • Isaac's spiritual sensitivity. He identified the problem and the right solution thus he prayed and asked God for intervention. The testimony is that his prayer was answered and Rebekah became pregnant. Isaac would have opted for divorce or subjected her to public ridicule.
    • Rebekah's devotion to God. When she discovered a strange movement in her womb, she decided to inquire from the Lord. God told her that the babies in her womb are two nations, two separate peoples and one will be stronger than the other and the older will serve the younger v. 23. She did not act like some people who would resolve to consult stargazers, fortune-tellers, seers or traditionalists to solve their problems.

    There is no doubt that waiting periods can be traumatising and capable of leading one into seeking help from wrong places. The example of Isaac and Rebekah who knew their God and what He can do according to today's lesson should encourage us to learn to seek the face of God concerning our needs.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. Discuss the likely behaviour of some men whose wives are still waiting for the blessings of children. Give some practical examples.
    2. What does the action of Rebekah teach Christian mothers, especially those who are waiting on God for the blessing of children?
    3. Mention three ways people inquire about their future today. How can Christians know God's plan for their future?
  2. The Birth of Esau and Jacob Genesis 25:24-28

    God had revealed to Rebekah that she will give birth to a set of twin boys who will eventually become two nations. According to God's promise, when the time came, Rebekah gave birth to two boys with different features. The first that came out was red and his body was hairy thus, he was named Esau (a Hebrew name with the meaning “hairy”. But his brother was born with his hand holding Esau's heel, and so he was named Jacob” (v .26). They both grew up and chose their different occupations. The Scripture says that Esau was a skilful hunter and loved outdoor life. In other words, he was a man of the open country who moved from one place to another for game hunting. But his brother Jacob was quiet and prefers to stay at home. Division and disunity started in the home when their parents began to show their preferences. While Isaac preferred Esau because he enjoyed eating his game, Rebekah preferred Jacob probably because of his availability to help her do some domestic chores.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. Discuss the implications of parental favouritism among siblings. How can it be curbed in Christian homes?
    2. How can parents display maturity and equal love among their children?
  3. Esau Despised His Birthright Genesis 25:29-34

    Isaac and Rebekah had their favourites among their children which later resulted into hostility and disunity in the home. According to verse 29, one day, Jacob was preparing some stew when his brother Esau returned from hunting probably tired and, of course, hungry and could not immediately make anything for himself. Presumably, he was relieved when he saw his brother cooking. Therefore, he said to him, “Quick! Let me have some of that red stew! I am famished” Ordinarily, one would expect Jacob to empathise and willingly give him some food to quench his hunger but the reverse was the case. Instead, he requested Esau's birthright in exchange for a plate of food. He said to his brother, “First sell me your birthright” (v. 31). Despite Esau's repeated explanation that he was hungry, Jacob demanded that he should swear an oath in order to make the transaction of the sale of his birthright authentic. Unfortunately, Esau swore an oath and sold his birthright for temporary satisfaction. Suffice to say that in ancient times, birthright included the inheritances of a first born son.

    From this passage, it is possible that Jacob was preparing Esau's favourite meal because the name later used for the descendant of Esau “Edom” was from the meaning “red”. It is also probable that Esau exaggerated his hunger so much that he said, “... I am about to die, after all, what good is the birthright to me.” (v. 32) Apparently, Esau did not take his birthright seriously. So, he willingly sold his birthright to his brother Jacob even with an oath. He, however, did not realise what he had given up until it was too late (Hebrews 12:16-17). Therefore, Jacob who is known as a schemer took undue advantage of Esau’s weakness to rob him of his birthright and position. The summary of this lesson is that Christians should not be gluttons who are ready to do anything for the sake of what they will eat. We should also not despise our positions for the pleasure of a moment only to later regret our action. More importantly, we should not be careless with our God-given heritage for any reason that may cause regret and sorrow.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. Esau failed to protect his birthright. Consequently, he lost it and later regretted his action. Explain how you can guard your heritage as Christians so you will not lose it and later regret.
    2. Discuss how sibling rivalry can affect the peace of the family.

Prayer Points

  • Help me, O God, to control my physical appetite, no matter how hungry I am.
  • Give me grace not to deceive anyone or be deceived by anyone in my relationship with others.
  • Help me to keep and cherish my inheritance from deceivers.

Fellowship and Ministry Building Activities

  • Let at least two class members recall an occasion when they acted on impulse and the consequences.

Take Home

  • Christians should avoid anything that will rob them of their inheritances.
  • Every decision has consequence.
  • We should learn to help others in times of need and not take undue advantage of them.
  • Parental favouritism can destroy the unity and stability of family members. Christians should avoid it.
  • God hates cheating and the exploitation of others.

title: JACOB RECEIVES ISAAC'S BLESSING
message:
November 11, 2018

JACOB RECEIVES ISAAC'S BLESSING

Devotional Reading: Psalm 24:1-6

Background Scripture: Genesis 27:1-28:5

Lesson Scripture: Genesis 27:5-10; 18-19, 21-29

Golden Text

He did not recognise him, for his hands were hairy like those of his brother Esau; so he blessed him. Genesis 27:23

Objectives :

By the end of the lesson, class members should be able to:

  • Explain the different ways people are being deceived today.
  • Discuss the implication(s) of deceiving others.
  • Discuss the best ways Christians can respond when they are deceived.
  • Identify some ways people 'help' God to fulfil divine plan for their lives.

INTRODUCTION

Mr Thomas Akugba is a retired military officer. He resides in his hometown in one of the oil producing states. While in active service, God helped him to build a house but he became blind after retirement. However, his children employed a maid and driver for him. One day, one of his sons came home from Lagos under the pretext of coming to spend some time with him . Not long after, the young man made away with all the relevant documents of the house. Of course, he had intended to sell the house and start a business with the money. But unfortunately, he was deceived by his so-called customer who paid him in fake dollars.

Deception, according to Encarta Dictionary is “the practice of deliberately making somebody believe things that are not true”. It could be in terms of information intended to deceive or to mislead somebody in order to get something from them. Such people are crafty as they deceive their fellow human beings by making them believe things that are not true in order to achieve their intended plans. The focal point of today's lesson is how Rebekah masterminded a plan for Jacob to deceive Isaac, his father, so that he will get what belonged to his twin brother, Esau.

THE LESSON EXPLAINED

  1. Rebekah's Deceptive Plan Genesis 27:5-10

    Jacob had cunningly taken the birthright of his brother Esau and was probably waiting for the death of their father to inherit his property. When Isaac became old and his eyes were weak, he called his beloved and first born son, Esau to prepare his favourite meal for him so that he would bless him before he dies (v. 1-4). Rebekah quietly listened to Isaac's conversation with Esau about his intention to bless him before he died. Consequently, she deceitfully devised a plan for Jacob to receive the intended blessing from their father Isaac when Esau had gone hunting. In verses 9 and 10, she told Jacob to get two young goats to prepare a meal so that Isaac will eat and pronounce his last blessing on him. Undoubtedly, Rebekah's desire was to help God so that His plan for Jacob will be accomplished (Genesis 23:23). By implication, she knew the favourite food of her husband and so volunteered to prepare it.

    Meanwhile, Jacob had already bought his brother's birthright and now wants to get his father's blessing to validate the transfer and eventually become stronger than Esau, in accordance with the earlier prediction about him. It is obvious that Jacob earnestly desired the birthright of his brother as a channel through which God's promise of blessing to him will be fulfilled. He would probably, have obtained it through other means. In addition, Isaac's planned blessing to Esau was against what God revealed to Rebekah before the boys were born. On the other hand, Esau who whole-heartedly accepted the plan to receive his father's blessing acted contrary to the oath he earlier swore to his brother (Genesis 25:23, 33). Similarly, Rebekah did not make any reference to God's earlier revelation but chose to be deceptive in order to bring God's plan to fulfilment. Isaac also relied on his senses, which failed him so much that he could not distinguish between Jacob and Esau. In reality, we do not need to help God to accomplish His plans for us. We only need to cooperate with Him and His plans will be fulfilled concerning us.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. According to the lesson, what do you think Isaac did not do well?
    2. What is the general motive behind deception and how does it relate to Rebekah's plan?
    3. Can anyone help God? Mention some ways people tend to help God these days and the repercussion.
  2. Isaac Was Deceived Genesis 27:18-19

    Rebekah succeeded in convincing Jacob to carry out the deceptive plan to get Esau's blessing from their father. She prepared the tasty food as Isaac would like it, put Esau's clothes on Jacob and covered his hands and the smooth part of his neck with goatskin (vv. 14-17). According to verse 18, Jacob went to his father Isaac disguised as Esau. In his attempt to convince his father, he said, “I am Esau, your firstborn. I have done as you told me. Please sit up and eat some of my game so that you may give me your blessing.” Unfortunately, Isaac was already old and “his eyes were weak that he could no longer see (v. 1).

    The influence and negative role of Rebekah in the life of her beloved son, Jacob, in their effort to help God accomplish His purpose for him is glaring. Jacob followed his mother's instructions to the point of wearing Esau's clothes so that their father, Isaac, will not know his true identity. Although he finally recognised the voice as that of Jacob, it was not enough evidence to confirm his suspicion because his sense organs were weak except his ears. However, it should be noted that Isaac's blessing as it is used in this context is different from the birthright, which has to do with spiritual destiny. Christians should be reminded that there is no one that cannot be deceived, especially in this corrupt world in which the syndrome of get rich quick is the order of the day. The only antidote is constant prayer, spiritual alertness and discernment.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. Isaac was deceived by Rebekah and Jacob. How can Christians escape the temptation of being deceived?
    2. Does Esau's birthright, which he sold to Jacob have anything to do with Isaac's blessings?
  3. Isaac Blesses Jacob Genesis 27:21-29

    The plan of Rebekah and Jacob to deceive Isaac in order to get Esau's blessing was a perfect one. Isaac made an attempt with the use of his two sensory organs to determine if really he was Esau. His questions in verses 20, 21 and 24 show his state of constant suspicion as to whether it was truly Esau standing before him. Jacob's responses were affirmative but because of weakness in age, Isaac did not identify him, especially because of the goatskin with which he covered his hand. He was only able to recognise his voice as that of Jacob. Having eaten the food and wine, he kissed him and pronounced his blessing on Jacob and said, “Ah, the smell of my son is like the smell of a field that the __ LORD has blessed. May God give you of heaven's dew and of earth's riches an abundance of grain and new wine ... (vv. 27-29). Isaac's blessing was characterised by both prosperity and authority in relation with God's earlier revelation while they were in the womb.

    Jacob's responses were affirmative but because of weakness in age, Isaac did not identify him, especially because of the goatskin with which he covered his hand. He was only able to recognise his voice as that of Jacob. Having eaten the food and wine, he kissed him and pronounced his blessing on Jacob and said, “Ah, the smell of my son is like the smell of a field that the LORD has blessed. May God give you of heaven's dew and of earth's riches __ an abundance of grain and new wine ... (vv. 27-29). Isaac's blessing was characterised by both prosperity and authority in relation with God's earlier revelation while they were in the womb.

    Consequently, Rebekah's plan for her beloved son, Jacob, was accomplished at the expense of her oldest son, Esau. She succeeded in helping Jacob, her favourite son, achieve God\'s plan and prophecy declared concerning him before his birth (Genesis 25:23). Unfortunately, according to the Old Testament times, once a blessing is pronounced it can never be reversed. In fact, the importance of sight in judging correctly is seen in this passage as Isaac could not judge rightly as a result of his defect in sight. This is a reminder that we all need spiritual eyes to see and discover the tricks of the Devil concerning us. We must also understand that God does not depend on human help to accomplish His purpose. His plan concerning each of us is sure to come to pass according to His timing.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. Some people used deceptive means to achieve their selfish desire or get to top positions. As a believer, explain how you would achieve God's purpose for your life without being deceptive
    2. Mention some of the implications of deception.
    3. What should be a Christian's response to ungodly suggestions like the case of Rebekah?

Prayer Points

  • Pray that no one will deceive you or receive your divine blessing, in Jesus' Name.
  • Ask God to give you the spirit of discernment, especially at the point of being deceived.
  • Pray and claim all the promises of God concerning you.

Fellowship and Ministry Building Activities

  • Let class members role-play the conversation between Jacob and his father, Isaac.
  • Let them pray for grace to resist every temptation to cheat on others.

Take Home

title: JACOB FORMS A RELATIONSHIP WITH GOD
message:
November 18, 2018

JACOB FORMS A RELATIONSHIP WITH GOD

Devotional Reading: Psalm 42:1-5

Background Scripture / Lesson Scripture: Genesis 28:10-22

Golden Text

I am with you and will watch over you wherever you go, and I will bring you back to this land. I will not leave you until I have done what I have promised you. Genesis 28:15

Objectives :

By the end of the lesson, class members should be able to:

  • Mention three significant things about Jacob's dream.
  • Discuss the relevance of the ladder Jacob saw in his dream.
  • State how they will respond to God in a new relationship that reveals and affirms His promise and purpose for them.

INTRODUCTION

Recently, a young lady testified about God's divine intervention at the point of taking a risk that would have cost her life. According to her, her parents were deceived with fake documents for her to travel the United Kingdom to serve as a housemaid to a close family member. With joy and excitement, her parents agreed with the people without seeking for her consent or praying for divine direction. Although she reluctantly accepted the offer, she lost her peace for some days. One day, she dreamt and was strictly warned by God not to embark on the journey, in spite of the fact that her parents had made necessary preparations. Even though her refusal to embark on the journey caused trouble between her and her parents, she did not mind because of the warning. Some months later, news reached her parents about some of the girls who died in the desert in their attempt to cross over to Italy while others who survived were forced into prostitution without any option.

According to Oxford Advanced Learner's Dictionary, dreams are series of images, events and feelings that happen in the mind when one is asleep. But from the biblical perspective, dreams and visions are some ways through which God speaks to His people, right from the Old Testament times. They have always been means through which messages of warnings, blessings or future events are conveyed from God to specific people through His prophets and priests. However, we should know that God-given dreams are always with clear message(s). Today's lesson focuses on Jacob's dream which was the beginning of his new relationship with God despite his past impiety over his brother, Esau.

THE LESSON EXPLAINED

  1. Jacob's Dream Genesis 28:10-15

    As we studied last week, Jacob connived with his mother, Rebekah, to deceive his father, Isaac, to bless him instead of his brother Esau after taking his birthright. Of course, Esau became angry and planned to kill him. When their mother sensed danger, she quickly encouraged Jacob to leave Beersheba at once and flee to Haran (her brother's city) in Mesopotamia where he lived for about 20 years. The decision was also to prevent him from marrying from among the Canaanite women like his brother Esau. Without doubt, his life was characterised by hopelessness, fear and insecurity. So, having travelled about forty-eight miles from Beersheba, a journey too long for a day, he became tired. Therefore, when the sun had set and he could not proceed in the journey, he laid down to sleep using a stone as pillow to support his head. According to verse 12, he had a dream and saw three things:

    • A stairway resting on the earth and the top reaching to the heavens. This can be interpreted as a connection between the heaven and earth, between God and human beings. It can also be likened to Jesus as the link between humanity and heaven (John 14:6).
    • Angels of God were ascending and descending on the ladder (v. 12c); this probably represents God's presence.
    • The Lord stood above it. He spoke and reaffirmed the promises He made with Jacob's forebears (Genesis 12:3). The climax of the dream experience was God\'s promise of His ever abiding presence with him. He also promised to watch over him wherever he goes and to bring him back to the land.

    God can use any means to reveal Himself to humankind either through a dream, vision, nature, happenings, crisis and many other ways. Obviously, Jacob's dream experience was very significant. The things he saw in his dream signified the presence of God, which marked the beginning of his new relationship with Him despite his past wicked acts towards his brother, Esau. Notably, the encounter was with an assertion of blessing of prosperity, fulfilment of divine purpose and covenant which God had made to Abraham and Isaac. God also promised His presence and protection in all his ways and to bring him back safely to the land where he slept and had the vision. God always makes provision for humans to have a new relationship with Him. Ultimately, Jesus is the connecting bridge between the heaven and earth and the Mediator between God and humankind. Therefore, we should know that life cannot be meaningful without an encounter with Him.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. Describe Jacob's state of mind in the course of his journey.
    2. What is the significance of the three things Jacob saw in his dream?
    3. Jacob's decision to run was a blessing. Discuss.
  2. Jacob's Unawareness Genesis 28:16-19

    Jacob had a dream while he was asleep, therefore, we can assume that until he woke up, he was not aware of all that transpired. Consequently, when he woke up after the dream, he affirmed with certainty that he had met with the Lord. He said, “Surely the Lord is in this place, and I was not aware of it.” (v. 16b) Of course, this statement confirms his awareness of God's presence where he slept. However, he was overwhelmed with fear and declared, “How awesome is this place! This is none other than the house of God; this is the gate of heaven.” Indeed, the awesomeness of his experience motivated him to do something the next morning. He took the stone that was under his head and set it up as a commemorative plaque. He dedicated it to God by pouring oil on it and naming the place Bethel, which means “House of God” even though it was initially known as Luz.

    Jacobs encounter with God was a special and memorable one. We can see that after this experience, he became a changed man though still with flaws but with new and genuine faith in the God of his fathers. After all, he never expected such a special encounter with God, being a fugitive. How often do Christians demonstrate ignorance of God's presence and protection, especially when faced with challenges? Instead of instant judgment on Jacob for his wickedness against his brother, God chose to enter into a new relationship with him, even though he was frustrated, hopeless and dejected. He was transformed into a man of faith in God throughout his service to Laban and beyond. God always loves to use the weak and foolish people of this world to put to shame the so-called wise and strong people of the world (1 Corinthians 1:27- 29).

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. What are some things you think Christians can do as memorial to God for His faithfulness?
    2. Considering this passage, what should be our attitude towards wicked people?
  3. Jacob Made a Vow Genesis 28:20-22

    Jacob's response to God's promises to bless him and his offspring exceedingly (vv. 13- 15) on his way to Haran is remarkable. He made a vow as part of his commitment to God who has promised to fulfil His promise to him. He said, “If God will be with me and watch over me on this journey I am taking and will give me food to eat and clothes to wear so that I return safely to my father's house, then the LORD will be my God ...” (vv. 20-21). He also vowed that the stone which he has set up as a memorial of his meeting with God will be God's house and out of his possession, he will give one tenth. This declaration was a way of acknowledging the Lord as his God, King, Protector and Provider. Jacob's vow is seen by some scholars as a bargain with God: He said, If God does this, then I will do that, while others see it as more of concession. In other words, Jacob meant that because God will fulfil His promise to him then he will respond in three ways: the Lord will be his God, he will make a place of worship for God where the stone is set up and he will give a tenth of all his earnings to Him.

    The climax of today's lesson is that Jacob's singular experience changed everything about him. Therefore, there are basic lessons to learn from Jacob's commitment to the new relationship with God 1). He surrendered his life to God and vowed to serve the God of his fathers. In fact, an encounter with God is usually a life-transforming because it is not possible for one to encounter God and remain the same. 2). He made the worship of God his primary focus. 3). He vowed to give to God a tenth of all his blessings. These three things are very important if we will truly respond to God's invitation to a new relationship. Just like Jacob set up a memorial to acknowledge God, believers can buy Bibles, plant churches, buy evangelism vehicles or form prayer groups to serve as memorials as our salvation experience of God's mighty works in our lives. Supposedly, our lives as Christians should reflect the glory of God by virtue of the fact that we have encountered God through the salvation of our souls.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. In what way should we respond to God's invitation to a new relationship and fellowship?
    2. Discuss the importance of making vows to God.
    3. Discuss the relevance of tithing under the new covenant.

Prayer Points

  • May the promises of God concerning me and my family come to pass, in Jesus' Name.
  • Help me, O God, that I will always enjoy Your presence.
  • Pray that God will renew His covenant relationship with you.

Fellowship and Ministry Building Activities

  • Lead the class members to list some of the things they find very difficult to part with in order to have a new relationship with God.
  • They should render a prayer of agreement and ask for the power of the Holy Spirit to help part with such things so that they will begin to enjoy God's favour.

Take Home

  • No matter how lonely we are, God's presence is always with us.
  • Our past experiences do not debar God from using us.
  • Commit your life and resources to the service of God.
  • One tenth of your earnings belongs to God and must be dedicated to Him.
  • Whenever we make vows, we should be ready to fulfil them.

title: GOD BLESSES JACOB AND RACHEL
message:
November 25, 2018

GOD BLESSES JACOB AND RACHEL

Devotional Reading: Psalm 46

Background Scripture: Genesis 30

Lesson Scripture: Genesis 30:22-32, 43

Golden Text

Then God remembered Rachel; he listened to her and opened her womb. Genesis 30:22

Objectives :

By the end of the lesson, class members should be able to:

  • Explain God's expectations of believers during waiting period or when they are cheated by someone they trust.
  • Pray for others who are waiting and trusting God for the fruit of the womb in their church.
  • Determine to be faithful to God and their duties, even when cheated.

INTRODUCTION

An English saying goes thus: “He who laughs last, laughs best.” Mr Williams Adams is a senior lecturer in one of the federal universities in the country. He is a committed Christian who is well respected in his family, church and community. Even though he is one of the most experienced lecturers, he was denied promotion having served for about seventeen years. Interestingly, he never complained or grumbled but did his work diligently, waiting for God's intervention. Later on, he got an appointment as a senior lecturer in a private university. His joy knew no bounds when he was made an associate professor with all benefits attached because of his wealth of experience. Although he suffered delay from humans but he was not denied his blessings by God and he laughed at last.

Jacob faithfully served his father-in-law, Laban, for a period of twenty years and wanted to go back to his hometown. Indeed, he was faithful to his duty, his master and father-in-law, Laban, and became greatly prosperous. He again demonstrated his cleverness as he bargained with his father-in-law, Laban, and got the better part of the livestock thus he left Haran a rich man. Furthermore, Rachel who also suffered delay in child-bearing was remembered by God and she became a mother. Today's lesson focuses on Jacob's faithfulness and how God blessed him and his wife Rachel in the land of Haran despite the effort of Laban to cheat and deny him his benefits.

THE LESSON EXPLAINED

  1. God Remembered Rachel Genesis 30:22-24

    Jacob had worked hard and fulfilled the conditions given by Laban in order to marry his two daughters Leah and Rachel. But while Leah had four sons, Rachel did not have children of her own. Unfortunately, barrenness in their days was regarded as a curse from God and conception, a gift of God. Rachel and her husband Jacob decided to seek the face of God concerning their need. Eventually, God answered the prayer of Rachel and she became pregnant and gave birth to her first son. With excitement, she declared, “God has taken away my disgrace. She named him Joseph, and said, "May the LORD add to me another son" (vv. 23b-24).

    The promises of God will surely come to fulfilment at the appointed time. Though Rachel experienced delay in child-bearing just like Sarah and Rebekah, she had her own children at God's appointed time. Nevertheless, it is apparent that she would have suffered reproach, disgrace, and so much ridicule from her sister, Leah, Jacob\'s first wife (Genesis 30:14-15) that she requested her husband to give her children or she died (Genesis 30:1). Finally, God remembered her, opened her womb and she gave birth. Her statement, “God has taken away my disgrace” (v. 23b) is an indication of the ordeals she would have gone through during her waiting period. We can say that God is never late, we only have to be patient and committed to Him as we wait for answers to our prayers. We also need to be persistent in prayer and not lose hope because He who has promised will surely bring it to pass.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. What are some ungodly ways people adopt to help themselves out of long-standing problems and its implication?
    2. What should be the response of believers when God remembers them, having waited for God's intervention for a specific request like Rachel in today's passage?
  2. Jacob Presents His Request before Laban Genesis 30:25-32

    Jacob had faithfully served Laban, his father-in-law, for several years and according to verse 27, the Lord blessed Laban for his sake. An old proverb says that no matter how long an apprentice serves his master, he must go to serve himself after some time. As a result, after the birth of Joseph, Jacob sought permission from Laban to go back to his hometown together with his wives, children and perhaps with other belongings for three reasons:

    • He wanted to go back to his homeland, which he left some years back. After all, God had multiplied him with four wives and eleven children. So, having served Laban for some years, he needed to go back to his homeland and country to start a new life with his family.
    • Jacob had longed to see his parents whom he left at Canaan due to the fear of being killed by his brother, Esau.
    • He was determined to go and settle his family on the land God promised his ancestors. Therefore, he presented his request before Laban and said, “Give me my wives and children and send me away” (vv. 25-26). Laban, however, persuaded him to continue to work for his wages because he knew he was blessed because of Jacob and so, he would not want him to go. Although Jacob was given an opportunity to bargain his wages, he preferred to have all the speckled or spotted sheep, every dark coloured lamb and goat (v. 32). By implication, Jacob's choice of wages was in favour of Laban.

    Laban wanted Jacob to continue to work for him because he (Laban) had become rich in livestock through Jacob. This is similar to the case of Potiphar whose household was blessed because of Joseph (Genesis 39:5). But it should be noted that Jacob's desire to continue to keep Jacob as his steward was for selfish reasons. Little wonder he took undue advantage of him despite his honesty and faithful service to him. Interestingly, Jacob did not cheat on Laban. Instead, he served him faithfully and diligently. He was honest with him and for this reason God reciprocated his actions with surpassing blessings. Believers should not short-change anyone for selfish reasons because the consequences can be costly.

    DISCUSSION TIME
