    1. What kind of divination do you think Laban consulted to know that he was blessed because of Jacob? Should Christians depend on any form of divination in order to ascertain some things?
    2. What is your view about Jacob's request to Laban?
  3. God Blessed Jacob Exceedingly Genesis 30:43

    Jacob's sincere dealing with Laban in the supervision of his livestock is seen in verses 37 to 41. He got some branches of poplar, almond and plane trees and stripped off their bark so that they will become white. He placed them in front of the flocks where they drank water, so that when they bred in front of the branches they will produce young ones that are streaked, speckled and spotted. Whenever the healthy animals were mating, Jacob would put the branches before them so that they would breed among the branches. By so doing, he carefully built up his own flock and kept it separate from Laban's. Within a short while, Laban had all the weak animals, Jacob had the healthy ones. This technique of peeled stick before the flocks in the watering troughs was unknown to Laban who lived in Haran. Perhaps, Jacob learnt this system from the shepherds in Canaan where it was commonly used. Gradually, Jacob became prosperous, owned large flocks, camels, donkeys, maidservants and menservants.

    God decided to bless Jacob despite Laban's deception. From the passage, we can see that his honesty paved way for him in spite of Laban's strategy to make him leave empty-handed. The peeled branches became the instrument God used to bless Jacob and increase his flocks. God is never slack in attending to His children who are being cheated and denied of their rights and entitlement. Jacob used his skill as a professional herdsman, under God's direction, profitably without any trace of dishonesty to his master, Laban. Christians must know that they can be blessed without necessarily cheating their employers. In fact, such blessings can last and many will have the opportunity of enjoying it. Therefore, we are to continually trust God for His blessings, be diligent and faithful at work, for divine blessing and uplift.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. Describe the end of those who deceive people in order to enrich themselves. If possible, give some biblical examples.
    2. State what would have happened if Jacob had paid Laban with evil?

Prayer Points

  • Pray and cancel every form of barrenness in your life and family.
  • Pray that you will not deceive anyone or be deceived by anyone in your relationship with others.
  • Pray and ask God to release those who are in one captivity or the other.

Fellowship and Ministry Building Activities

  • Class members should discuss and decide on a mission project they will do to help those who are being cheated and denied of their rights around them.
  • The class should also pray for God's intervention.

Take Home

  • God is faithful in all His ways.
  • Children are blessings from God.
  • Let your hope be rekindled because God has not forgotten you.
  • It is only the blessing from God that brings wealth without adding sorrow.
  • Deception is a trait of an individual controlled by the flesh.

title: LOVE AND DEVOTION
message:
December 2, 2018

LOVE AND DEVOTION

Devotional Reading: Mark 12:28-34

Background Scripture / Lesson Scripture: Deuteronomy 6:1-9

Golden Text

Love the Lord your God with all your heart and with all your soul and with all your strength. Deuteronomy 6:5

Objectives :

By the end of the lesson, class members should be able to:

  • Explain the necessity of the fear of and obedience to God in keeping a relationship with Him.
  • Discuss the oneness of God.
  • Identify various ways they can show their love to God.

INTRODUCTION

Rev Dr Moses Agbebaku was the Pastor of “Heaven Bound Baptist Church”. He had served for a period of about twenty years with records of achievements as members of the church testified. During his retirement service which coincided with the induction service for the new pastor, when 'Baba Pastor', as he was fondly called by his members, was asked to give his farewell message, he simply admonished the members to remain committed to God. He encouraged them to always obey God, love Him whole-heartedly and teach their children the way of the Lord because it is the pathway to success in life. Baba's farewell message can be likened to the words of Moses to the people of Israel. Having given the Ten Commandments, which was supposed to guide them as they prepare to enter the Promised Land, he also reminded them of the importance of their love and devotion to God as well as the need to teach their children.

The word "love" is the same as to feel affection for, to worship, or to be devoted to something. Unfortunately today, its usage by some people, especially young ones depict that they lack the true understanding of the word. According to Moses, the Israelites were expected to love God, demonstrate obedience and show devotion to Him in the Promised Land so that they will not be influenced by their neighbouring nations. Today's lesson focuses on God's command through His servant Moses to the Israelites to love and obey Him so that they would enjoy His blessings in the Land which He has promised to give to their fathers.

THE LESSON EXPLAINED

  1. The Command to Fear and Obey God Deuteronomy 6:1-3

    Chapter 6 of the book of Deuteronomy is known to contain series of commandments for the children of Israel. Obviously, Moses knew that the Israelites were about to enter into the Promised Land so, he assembled the Israelites to remind them of the commands, decrees and laws which they must obey in the land they were about to possess. According to verse 2, they were expected to:

    • Fear the Lord and inculcate same to the generations that would live after them. Fear for God as it is used in this context means to reverence or worship God.
    • Carefully and diligently obey all the commands and decrees He has given them. In other words, they were supposed to comply with all the instructions. Moses made them know that the fear of and obedience to God are the requisites for which they will enjoy the blessings, prosperity and protection of God in the Promised Land (vv. 2-3). The need for obedience to the laws, decrees and commands is repeated in verse 3 when he said to them, “Hear, O Israel, and be careful to obey so that it may go well with you and that you may increase greatly in a land flowing with milk and honey, just as the Lord, the God of your fathers, promised you.” (v. 3).

    The admonition to fear and obey God became necessary because of the tendency to drift from God when they get to the Promised Land. In addition, fear and obedience are the two basic requirements needed in building a relationship with God and enjoying His blessings (Deuteronomy 28:1-14). Therefore, God repeatedly instructed the Israelites on these subjects so that they may live in the land for a long time. Similarly, all Christians who intend to relate with God and enjoy His promises of blessings, prosperity, and protection should learn to fear (reverence or worship) Him. We should obey His commands, notwithstanding how burdensome they seem because this is the pathway to enjoying His blessings.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. Why do some Christians find it difficult to obey God and how do you think we can cultivate obedience?
    2. Discuss the attitudes of contemporary Christians to obedience to God's commands.
    3. What roles are expected of parents today to see that their children fear and obey the Lord?
  2. The Oneness of God Deuteronomy 6:4

    Moses recounted the great history of God's dealings with Israel over the past forty years of their experiences in the wilderness which show the inimitability of the God of Israel. He, therefore, called them to a life of total obedience to Him as they were about to enter the Promised Land (Deuteronomy 4). As he continued in his admonition to a life of obedience and respect for God, Moses also declared the doctrine of the "the unity of God." He emphatically said in verse 4, “Hear, O Israel: the Lord our God, the Lord is one”. Without doubt, this expression of the unity of God affirms that there is only one living and true God who brought them out of Egypt and promised an inheritance for them. Apparently, his desire was to remind the Israelites the uniqueness of God and how to relate with Him when they finally enter the Promised Land. The reminder became necessary because the occupants of the land were pagans (Deuteronomy 6:14). He thus reminded them that the God that brought them out of Egypt is the only true God; He has no equal or rival. He is self-existent and self-reliant. For that reason, they should not serve other gods but give their total allegiance to God alone.

    One of the things that distinguish God from humankind is that He is one indivisible God unlike Baals and other pagan gods of Canaan which have various forms. In fact, this is not negated by the doctrine of Trinity as upheld by Christians today. God remains one God who manifests as the Father, Son and the Holy Spirit. It is the same God who reveals Himself in these forms to carry out specific assignments at specific times.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. How will you convince a non Christian that Christians do not serve three Gods as they assume based on the doctrine of the Trinity?
    2. What are those things that can be other 'gods' in the lives of believers and can compete with our loyalty to God?
  3. The Command to Teach Future Generations Deuteronomy 6:5-9

    Moses' instruction to the people of Israel to love God and be devoted to Him was comprehensive. Having spoken on the oneness of God, Moses shifted to the subject of love for God. He emphatically said, “Love the Lord your God with all your heart and with all your soul and with all your strength.” (v. 5) In other words, such love must be total since it involves one's whole being as an indication of devotion to God. The importance of this command is seen in verses 7 to 9 as the parents were admonished to:

    • Teach the commands to love and obey God to their children when they sit, walk, lie down or get up.
    • Tie them as symbols on their arms and wear them on their foreheads.
    • Write them on the doorframes of their houses and gates.

    The importance of this command for the people of Israel to love the Lord and be devoted to Him cannot be overemphasised. Even Jesus said the whole law could be summed up in the words of these verses as the greatest commandment (Matthew 22:37-40). The need to tie the commands on their arms, wear and write them on their doorframes became necessary because ordinary people had no copy of the law. It was only to be taught by words of mouth and the important parts were to be written where the people would see and probably master it. Even today, the command to teach our children to love and be devoted to God has placed an important task on parents. It is the duty of every Christian parent to see that their children love God, obey and are devoted to Him with all sincerity. Love is fundamental in any relationship. When our relationship with God is based on love, we will not find it difficult to obey Him.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. Based on today's passage, discuss the various ways Christians can show their love and devotion to God
    2. What roles should Christian parents play in teaching their children to love God?
    3. Is it still necessary to tie the laws on our doorframes and gates? If no, where do you think the laws of God can be placed?

Prayer Points

  • Lord, teach me to walk with You in love and devotion.
  • Pray that God will help our generation to love and obey Him always.
  • Pray for all Christian parents that they will not fail in their responsibility to teach their children God's love and devotion.

Fellowship and Ministry Building Activities

  • Discuss what it means to fear God.
  • List creative ways to keep God's commandments in our hearts.

Take Home

  • True love for God is expressed when we fear and reverence Him.
  • Christian parents should teach their children the Word of God.
  • To love God and obey His commandments are conditions for receiving divine blessing.
  • It is the responsibility of parents to teach their children the way of the Lord.
  • Believers should give their best to show their love and devotion for God.
  • There is only one true God who deserves our total allegiance.

title: CHOOSE TO LOVE AND SERVE GOD
message:
December 9, 2018

CHOOSE TO LOVE AND SERVE GOD

Devotional Reading: Psalm 81

Background Scripture: Exodus 20:1-11

Lesson Scripture: Joshua 24:1-3, 13-15, 21-24

Golden Text

But if serving the LORD seems undesirable to you, then choose for yourselves this day whom you will serve, whether the gods your forefather served beyond the River, or the gods of the Amorites, in whose land you are living. But as for me and my household, we will serve the LORD. Joshua 24:15

Objectives :

By the end of the lesson, class members should be able to:

  • Discuss the importance of fellowship with brethren to individual renewal of love and devotion to God.
  • State choices that can hinder human relationship with God.
  • Pray over their personal resolutions towards renew their relationship with God.

INTRODUCTION

Mr Salawu Bello is a Muslim convert. He gave his life to Christ during a joint village outreach organised by the youths of God's Will Baptist Conference to mark their twentieth anniversary. Mr Salawu did not waver despite the persecution from his friends and family members immediately he gave his life to Christ. He served God with joy, zeal and devotion to a point that he donated his inherited plot of land for the construction of a church building, in his hometown. Unfortunately, none of his children was interested in the things of God despite his effort. However, sometime later, he took ill and was hospitalised for a period of time. On his sick bed, Mr Salawu continued to preach the message of the Gospel to his children. The day he died, he prayed and encouraged them to make up their minds on whom they will serve, whether it is the gods of their forefathers or the Lord Jesus.

The story of Mr Salawu Bello is similar to the case of Joshua who successfully led the people of Israel until his old age. Today's lesson focuses on how he summoned all the tribes of Israel and called them to a renewed covenant relationship with God at Shechem. Having declared his willingness to love and serve God together with his family, Joshua charged the people to forsake other gods and serve the Lord God of Israel. According to verse 31, Israel served God throughout the lifetime of Joshua and the elders who outlived him, who had experienced everything the Lord had done for them as a nation.

THE LESSON EXPLAINED

  1. A Call to a Renewed Covenant Joshua 24:1-3

    After the death of Moses, the mantle of leadership fell on Joshua to lead God\'s people to the Promised Land. God was actually with the people according to His promise to Joshua on the conquest and division of the land. When Joshua was about to die, he called and reminded the people of God's faithfulness to them and the consequences of disobedience to Him (Joshua 23:14-16). To further encourage them to love and serve God, he gathered all the tribes of Israel including the elders, judges, the leaders and all the officials of Israel to the presence of God at Shechem. Previously, the people of Israel had renewed their covenant of obedience to God in Shechem. However, the purpose of this latter gathering was to reveal God's dealings with their forefather, Abraham. During the period, God blessed him with many descendants including Isaac, the promised child.

    Apparently, Joshua's intention of bringing the people together was to make them renew their commitment to serve the Lord. When they had assembled, he recounted how God dealt kindly with their ancestor, Abraham by calling him out of idolatry into a new relationship with Him (Genesis 12:1-3). Joshua's recount of the great acts of God in the election of Abraham and his descendants is important as it serves as (1) a reminder to the people of the goodness of God and (2) the necessity of keeping His laws and commands. In the New Testament dispensation, God elected people into His family through the sacrificial death of Jesus Christ. The good acts of God to humankind which is already completed through Christ and His sacrifice can only be appreciated and appropriated as we constantly renew our allegiance to serve God. Just as Joshua summoned the people, we are daily reminded by the Holy Spirit to renew our commitment to God through Christ Jesus who has saved us.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    2. What is the place of group or personal retreat in renewing our commitment to God?
    3. What does it mean to present oneself before God? v.1b
  2. A Call to Choose Whom to Serve Joshua 24:13-15

    Joshua's effort in calling the people into a renewed covenant relationship with God was all-encompassing. From verse 5, he carefully gave detailed account of the good deeds of God among them beginning from the time He delivered and brought their fathers out of the land of Egypt. God’s deeds to them include:

    • The destruction of their oppressors (v. 7).
    • Victories over their attackers in the wilderness (8-10, 11-12).
    • The miraculous crossing of the Red Sea and Jordan River (vv. 6-7, 11)
    • Their settlement in the Promised Land (v. 13).
    He, however, acknowledged the fact that these acts were done by God without their help (v. 12) even though they have been promised by God (Deuteronomy 6:10- 11). Based on these facts, he admonished them to fear the Lord and serve Him faithfully. Furthermore, they were encouraged to get rid of their forefather\'s idols, which they worshipped in Mesopotamia and in Egypt. He finally challenged them to choose between serving God or the idols of their forefathers and the Amorites. Nevertheless, in verse 15, he made a public affirmation of his willingness to serve the Lord with his family (v. 25).

    As a true leader, Joshua’s heart desire was to see his generation continue to serve God and not idols. Today, many things compete for our attention to the detriment of our total allegiance to God. It could be our career, material possessions, fashions, academics, fame, power and so on. As it was in the days of Joshua so it is today. Christians will need to make a choice whether to allow any of these to replace God in their hearts or hold on to God. After all, Jesus said it is not possible to serve God and mammon (Matthew 6:24). It is instructive to note that the place of accountability partner(s) is important in the renewal of Christians' walk with God. This is the same role Joshua played among God's people. The challenge, therefore, is our resolution to renew our covenant relationship with God, fear Him and chose to serve Him with all sincerity because of His wonderful deeds among us.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. List some other things in this contemporary time that compete with the place of God in the hearts of people.
    2. What steps can we take to overcome these things and be resolute in serving God?
    3. What does the fear of God entail? v.14.
  3. Re-affirmation to Serve God Joshua 24:21-24

    Joshua was firm in his admonition to the people to make a choice between serving God and the idols of their forefathers (vv. 19-20). In verse 21, the people responded affirmatively. They publicly declared their willingness to serve God. They said to him, “No! We will serve the LORD”. Joshua's response to their declaration is also noteworthy. “You are witnesses against yourselves that you have chosen to serve the LORD”, he said to them (v. 22). This, of course, was a normal and authentic part of a treaty or covenant- making in the Old Testament time. Based on their confession and readiness to serve the Lord, he further encouraged them to throw away the inherited gods of their forefathers and pledge their total allegiance to the Lord, the God of Israel. Their prompt response was an indication that they were passionate about the continuity of their relationship with the God of their ancestors who had renewed His covenant with them.

    The role of a true and godly leader is seen in Joshua who worked hard and led the people to make the right decision to serve God and do away with the gods of their forefathers. The people on their part recognised and honoured the words of Joshua and jointly resolved to serve the Lord. This implies that God's people should regularly renew their allegiance to serve and obey God. In addition, we should make a passionate resolution to follow Christ and not allow the perils of the present age to turn us against God. We should also consciously and openly remind ourselves of such a decision like the people of Israel did because other life's choices are affected by the decision we make to serve God.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. Discuss some other things you think Christians should discard in order to serve God faithfully and obey Him < /li>
    2. What role does our confession play in renewing our devotion to God?

Prayer Points

  • Every contending force against my attention for God's service is paralysed, in Jesus' Name.
  • Every ungodly choice that causes obstruction in my relationship with God is removed today, in the Name of Jesus Christ.
  • I refuse to serve mammon henceforth in the name of Jesus.

Fellowship and Ministry Building Activities

  • List some of the programmes organised in your church in recent times that gave members the opportunity to renew their relationship with God
  • Class members should renew their commitment to serve God.

Take Home

  • Believers should occasionally attend retreats in order to examine their relationship with God
  • Christians should regularly renew their commitment to God.
  • We should not allow mundane things to affect our sincere love for God.
  • Each believer should have accountability partner in his/her spiritual journey.
  • We should daily resist the temptation to serve other gods.

title: LOVE AND WORSHIP GOD
message:
December 16, 2018

LOVE AND WORSHIP GOD

Devotional Reading: Psalm 86:1-7

Background Scripture / Lesson Scripture: Psalm 103:1-17, 21-22

Golden Text

As far as the east is from the west, so far has he removed our transgressions from us. Psalm 103:12

Objectives :

By the end of the lesson, class members should be able to:

  • Differentiate between thanking God and praising Him.
  • State the reasons why children of God should praise God.
  • Express their commitment to God always.

INTRODUCTION

Mr Jacobson Arubebe is a well- known philanthropist whose impact has been felt in his church, family and hometown. Many people have benefitted from his generosity, especially the youths. Through his influence, a multi-national company was established in his hometown, which made it possible for many indigenes to be gainfully employed. He single-handedly built a health centre, a town hall and renovated the only primary school in the village, which is his alma-mater. The community leaders, who recognised the roles Mr Jacobson had played in the development of the town decided to honour and appreciate him without his knowledge. He and his family members were invited to attend a meeting with the elders of the town. Some of his friends and associates were also invited to witness the occasion. The essence of the programme was to appreciate Mr Jacobson for his wonderful contributions to the well-being of the people. The youths, men and women came out in their traditional attires and different musical instruments with songs of praises in his honour.

The focal point of today's lesson is praising God for His mighty deeds among His people as declared by David. Just like the community praised and honoured Mr Jacobson for his good deeds, so it is expected of the people of God to always acknowledge God's wonderful deeds and praise Him.

THE LESSON EXPLAINED

  1. Singing the Praises of God Psalm 103:1-10

    This psalm is one of the seventy-three psalms associated with King David. It is a call to God\'s people to praise God. According to verses 1 and 2, the psalmist calls on his soul and inmost being to praise God's holy name. In verses 3 to 5, he classifies God’s deeds into personal and collective portions. Personal benefits are in terms of forgiveness, healing, redemption, love and compassion, satisfaction and strength. But verses 6 to 10 contain the collective benefits the children of God have received that call for praising Him. They include works of righteousness and vindication of the oppressed. He reveals His ways and deeds, He is slow to anger and looks compassionately on sinners. However, His love and compassion are for those who fear Him.

    This psalm is an individual's expression of thanksgiving to God for all His benefits. It should be noted that thanksgiving is different from praise. While praise is offered to God simply because of whom He is, thanksgiving is offered in response to specific things that God has done. Therefore, every part of the human body should be involved in praising God for the wonders of His love and blessings. In other words, praising God should be both internal and external and we should not be coerced to do it. Instead, we should be willing to offer our thanksgiving to God, irrespective of our situation. Though it seemed the psalmist was only talking to himself, the challenge to always praise God whole-heartedly is for all Christians because of His numerous benefits toward us.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. How will you encourage someone who has just lost his/her job to praise God?
    2. Why do people easily forget God's benefits for them?
    3. How does God crown us with love and compassion? v. 4.
  2. Praising God Thankfully Psalm 103:11-17

    The psalmist, in this passage, expressed God's love and compassion on His people, especially those who fear Him. His uses three different analogies:

    • As high as the heavens are above the earth.
    • As far as the east is from the west.
    • As a father has compassion on his children. God knows how we are formed and He remembers that we are nothing but dust. The Psalmist likens the days of man to grass and a flower that flourishes on the field whose lifespan is short. In conclusion, he attests to the fact that God's love is with those who fear Him and his righteousness is for their children's children (v. 17).

    The summary of the lesson is that while we praise and worship God for who He is, we should also thank Him for what He has done. We should give thanks for His gracious acts. This can be done in different ways like singing, clapping, giving, praying, playing of instruments, and so on. The blessings of praising God can be transferred to the next generation (v. 17).

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. Discuss other ways believers can praise God.
  3. The Call to Praise God Is Encompassing Psalm 103:21-22

    As the psalmist ends this chapter with his invitation for all to praise God, he became specific in verses 21 and 22. He calls on angels, heavenly hosts and all His works to join in praising God for His marvellous deeds. He said, “Praise the LORD, you his angels .... Praise the LORD, all his heavenly hosts, you his servants who do his will ....” Although he had earlier called on people to praise God, now his invitation covers the entire creation of God to offer praises to Him __ both heavenly and earthly beings.

    Every creature of God is required to praise Him. No creature, earthly or heavenly is exempted from this divine call to praise God. Undoubtedly, the call for all works of God to praise Him is necessitated by the acts mentioned in vv. 6-18. Every child of God should make it a duty to worship Him individually and collectively. We are expected to come together in corporate worship of God in response for His love for us.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. State the importance of corporate praise in worship
    2. How often should churches organise praise concert?

Prayer Points

  • Sing songs of praise to appreciate God.
  • Pray that your praises will be acceptable to Him always.
  • Enumerate the blessings of God in your life and praise Him.

Fellowship and Ministry Building Activities

  • Class members should write a note in form of appreciation letter addressed to God and read it in class.

Take Home

  • Believers should cultivate the habit of praising God always.
  • God is pleased when His children praise Him.
  • Praising God should not be limited to times when we enjoy His blessings.
  • We should learn to praise God whole-heartedly.
  • Christians should respond to God's miraculous acts through praise.

title: JESUS: GOD'S LOVING PROMISE
message:
December 23, 2018

JESUS: GOD'S LOVING PROMISE

Devotional Reading: Isaiah 49:1-7

Background Scripture: Luke 1:26-31; 2:21-35

Lesson Scripture: Luke 1:26-31; 2:22, 25-35

Golden Text

For my eyes have seen your salvation, which you have prepared in the sight of all people. Luke 2:30-31

Objectives :

By the end of the lesson, class members should be able to:

  • Describe Jesus as the expression of God's love to humankind.
  • Mention the purpose for which Jesus was born.
  • State the roles of believers in spreading the gospel message.

INTRODUCTION

The making and receiving of promises is part of human life. As we live and relate with one another, we make promises directly or indirectly. From experience, while some people work hard to fulfil their promise, others do not bother about fulfilling theirs. The promise of sending the Messiah to the Israelites had taken so long. They had waited and perhaps concluded that the Messiah was no longer coming. They probably forgot that one of the characteristics of God is that He keeps His promises unlike humankind who are slack in keeping theirs. However, at the appointed time, God fulfilled His promise and sent His only begotten Son, Jesus Christ through a virgin whose name was Mary.

Today's lesson centres on Jesus, God\'s loving promise. His birth was promised and foretold about 730 years before its fulfilment. The fulfilment of the promise was a manifestation of God’s unfailing love which ushered us into a new relationship with Him.

THE LESSON EXPLAINED

  1. The Birth of Jesus Predicted Luke 1:26-31

    The promise of salvation which God made to the Israelites finally came to pass. According to verses 26 and 27, in the sixth month, God sent the angel Gabriel to Nazareth, a town in Galilee to a virgin already engaged to be married to Joseph. Her name was Mary. The phrase “in the sixth month” indicates that six months had passed since the angel earlier visited Zechariah to announce the birth of their son, John the Baptist. This time, the same angel was sent to Mary to announce to her that she will conceive and give birth to a son whose name will be called Jesus (v. 32). Noteworthy in the passage is the unusual way the angel greeted Mary. He said to her, “Greetings, you who are highly favoured! The Lord is with you.” (v. 28) The greeting was strange to Mary, she was terribly afraid at the appearance of the angel and the greetings. However, the angel calmed her fear. He said to her, “Do not be afraid, Mary, you have found favour with God." The child Mary would bear shall be called Jesus (v. 31) because He will save His people from their sins." (Matthew 1:21).

    The birth of Jesus marks the fulfilment of God's loving promise to His people. In essence, Jesus was sent to save sinners from their sins. His coming, therefore, marks the fulfilment of God's promised salvation to humankind. In other words, He came to reveal and manifest the love of God for humankind. His life and death are, therefore, the expressions of His love for the world (John 3:16). Every sinner can benefit in the salvation plan of God through Jesus Christ as they identify with His work of salvation by believing in Him.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. What is the importance of the virgin birth to our understanding of who Jesus is?
    2. What does it mean to say Jesus is the Son of God?
    3. Why was Mary chosen as the mother of the Saviour of the world?
  2. Jesus' Presentation in the Temple Luke 2:22, 25-32

    Jesus was born in the city of Bethlehem as predicted by the angel in fulfilment of God's promise to His people (Luke 1:31). He was named Jesus and circumcised on the eight day according to the Law of Moses. Forty days after, Mary and Joseph came to the temple in Jerusalem for the ceremony of purification and dedication. It was the custom for every first born male child to be dedicated to the Lord (v. 23). There was a man in Jerusalem named Simeon, a righteous and devout Jew (v. 25) who had patiently waited for the consolation of Israel because the Holy Spirit had revealed to him that he would not die until he had seen the promised Messiah (v. 26). \'The consolation of Israel' means the coming of Christ. After all, God promised to send the Messiah whose emergence would bring the Israelites comfort. Simon took the child in his arms and gave thanks to God for fulfilling His promise. He said, “Sovereign Lord, as you have promised, you now dismiss your servant in peace. For my eyes have seen your salvation, which you have prepared in the sight of all people...” (vv. 29-31).

    God is faithful to fulfil His promises to His faithful followers. By divine revelation, Simeon acknowledged that Jesus is the expected Saviour whose work of salvation extends to both the Israelites and the Gentiles. His light will be to the Gentiles and glory to the Israelites (v. 32; Isaiah 49:3). There is no other name under the heavens through which the salvation of humankind will be made possible except through Jesus Christ. He is the promised Saviour whose coming fulfilled the promise. He is the expression of God's love to sinful humankind (John 3:16). As we celebrate His birth again this season, we will do well to reach out and proclaim salvation through the Name of Jesus to the entire world.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. What is the reason behind the dedication of firstborn sons? Ex 5:2; 13:13b, 15b
    2. How can a Christian develop an attitude of hope?
  3. Jesus' Ministry Revealed Luke 2:33-35

    The preceding verses reveal the excitement of Simeon when eventually he saw the fulfilment of the promised Messiah during Jesus' purification in the temple. His affirmation in verse 32 was a vivid revelation of the nature of Jesus\' ministry as light to the Gentiles and glory to the people of Israel, and this he revealed to Joseph and Mary. This means that God did not exclude anyone from His plan of salvation. According to verse 33, Jesus' parents were amazed at the pronouncement by Simeon about their Son. Simeon blessed them and said to Mary, “This child is destined to cause the falling and rising of many in Israel, and to be a sign that will be spoken against, so that the thoughts of many hearts will be revealed. And a sword will pierce your own soul to.” (vv. 34b-35).

    It is clear from the passage that Simeon's declaration was the actual nature of Jesus' ministry. It was revealed to His parents probably to prepare them for His sacrificial death. His coming truly was characterised by the rising and falling of many and a stumbling block to those who did not believe. He was often spoken against by the Pharisees, the teachers of the law and scribes, even though many were saved through Him. More importantly, His suffering and death would cause sorrow and pain to Him and His parents.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. Describe how Jesus caused the falling and rising of many in Israel.
    2. What did Simeon mean when he said to the parents of Jesus, “And a sword will pierce your own soul too”?
    3. Explain Jesus as the “Consolation of Israel.” v. 25.

Prayer Points

  • Thank God for fulfilling His promise of salvation through Jesus Christ.
  • Pray that the lost will know and embrace the salvation offered through Jesus Christ.
  • Pray that the Lord will make you a witness of the salvation through Jesus Christ to the world.

Fellowship and Ministry Building Activities

  • Let some members of the class dramatise how Simeon held baby Jesus in his arms and began to prophesy.
  • They should sing carol songs to mark the birth of the Messiah.

Take Home

  • The birth of Jesus is the fulfilment of God's promise of a Messiah.
  • There is no salvation in any other man except Christ Jesus.
  • We should learn to appreciate God for His gift of salvation.
  • Believers should be ready to share the good news of God's salvation to all.
  • God's plan of salvation includes all, irrespective of our tribe and language.

title: MODELLING GOD'S LOVE
message:
December 30, 2018

MODELLING GOD'S LOVE

Devotional Reading: James 2:14-26

Background Scripture / Lesson Scripture: Matthew 25:31-46

Golden Text

he king will reply, “I tell you the truth, whatever you did for one of the least of these brothers of mine, you did for me.” Matthew 25:40

Objectives :

By the end of the lesson, class members should be able to:

  • Describe how they can showcase the love of God to others.
  • Explain the effect of generosity in their relationship with God.
  • Express determination to be more helpful to others.

INTRODUCTION

A man once had an encounter with Jesus in which He (Jesus) promised to visit him on a particular date. In fact, the man made adequate arrangement as he led his family to prepare varieties of food and drinks. Out of excitement, he informed some of his friends about Jesu\' planned visit to his home. That same day, thrice, Jesus came under the guise of a wretched-looking man, a sick man and a blind man but He was turned down on each occasion by the man who was highly expecting Jesus. He waited until night but was disappointed when he did not see his 'perceived' Jesus. The following day, Jesus came knocking on his door. When the man saw Him, he angrily accused Jesus of disappointing him but Jesus smiled and said to him, “Thrice, I came to your house yesterday but I was denied entry." The man broke down in tears as a result of his refusal to attend to the three men who came in disguise.

Throughout Jesus' earthly ministry, He associated with and ministered to the lowly, the poor and the sick and even those in captivity (Matthew 9:10-11). Today, many people claim to love God but this does not reflect in their relationship with their fellow humans, especially the lowly like the case of the man in the introduction. Nevertheless, Jesus teaches that love for Him should be evident among the members of His kingdom. To be Christlike, therefore, means to imitate Him, especially in our relationship with the weak and helpless around us. Unfortunately, we sometimes feel indifferent toward people who are calling for our help and attention because of the evil that has pervaded our society. As much as we may be justified in the way we feel towards such people, God still expects us to minister to the least among them. This is the focus of today's lesson.

THE LESSON EXPLAINED

  1. The Day of Separation Predicted Matthew 25:31-33

    Jesus did not leave His disciples in the dark concerning His second coming. From time to time, He taught and reminded them of His departure and second coming purposely to judge the world (Matthew 24:29-31). He had just told the parable of the three servants in which the unprofitable one was cast into outer darkness for being unfaithful with the gift of God. This passage, therefore, is a description of exactly what the final judgment will look like. It presents a time when Jesus will gather nations unto Himself and separate the righteous (sheep) from the unrighteous (goats). The godly will be positioned at His right-hand side while the ungodly will be at His left-hand side. Thereafter, He will judge them according to their deeds. However, this statement highlights some important facts:

    • The certainty of the coming of the Son of Man.
    • All nations or people will be judged according to their deeds.
    • There shall be a separation of the righteous from the unrighteous.
    • While the righteous will enjoy the gift of eternity with God, the wicked will be condemned and made to suffer in hell.

    The fact that the passage refers to Jesus as the Son of Man points to the nature He took when He was on earth. He will definitely be the judge when He shall come to judge the deeds of humankind. He will come in His glory and all the nations (including the Gentiles) will be gathered unto Him to be judged. It is, therefore, essential to note that God has the records of all human activities on earth. The record will be accurate and there will be no room for manipulation or escape from the punishment as the case may be.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. What can we do to prepare all nations for the judgment day?
    2. Discuss the effects of manipulation in earthly justice. Can God favour some people above others in His judgment on the last day?
  2. Generosity Commended Matthew 25:34-40

    Whatever we do on earth, whether good or bad, has its consequences both here and in the life hereafter. According to the passage, the coming of the Son of Man to judge the world will be accompanied with commendation. The first part of His judgment will be for the godly who are on the right-hand side. He will say to them, “Come, you who are blessed by my Father; take your inheritance, the kingdom prepared for you since the creation of the world” (v. 34). Of course, the basis of the commendation is their care and hospitality to the needy, strangers, prisoners, and outcasts. Then the righteous will wonder when they ever offered such help to the Master but Jesus will reply, “I tell you the truth, whatever you did for one of the least of these brothers of mine, you did for me” (v 40).

    Jesus recognises every act of kindness we do to others. He considers what they did to the poor and the downtrodden as being done to Him. Consequently, they will receive the commendation and the gift of eternal life. Nevertheless, this is not to suggest that the basis of salvation is good works after all, no man receives salvation through good works. It is only by the grace of God through Jesus Christ; appropriated through faith (Romans 10:10-13). Rather, it means that salvation through Jesus Christ spurs the saved into displaying these godly virtues, especially toward the poor. When one is saved, it is expected that such a person will show kindness, care, and hospitality to the poor, strangers, hungry, naked and prisoners in our midst. By so doing, we would have exemplified the love of God to others.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. Faith without works is dead. What type of work does Matthew 25:34-40 recommend for believers?
    2. What is the relationship between faith and good works?
    3. How can Christians balance their faith and good works and be perfect example in showing God's love to the world?
  3. Condemnation and Punishment for the Wicked Matthew 25:41-46

    The last few verses of the passage are quite the opposite of the previous verses where the righteous were commended. Having commended the righteous and pronounced blessing on them for their good deeds, Jesus also condemned and pronounced punishment on the wicked for their insensitivity to the needs of the poor. He said to them, “Depart from me, you who are cursed, into the eternal fire prepared for the devil and his angel.” (v. 41) The reason for the curse and condemnation is stated in verses 42 and 43. Jesus said I was:

    • Hungry, you did not feed me.
    • Thirsty, you did not give me a drink.
    • A stranger but you did not welcome me into your homes.
    • Naked but you did not clothe me.
    • Sick and in prison but you did not take care of me.

    No doubt, the people were surprised to hear the words of condemnation. Even though they tried to justify themselves by claiming not to have seen Jesus physically in need and refused to help, they were cursed and condemned for refusing to serve the least among them. The final judgment was the pronouncement of eternal punishment without any opportunity to make amends. The passage is a reminder that we owe our fellow humankind some responsibilities, especially those who need our help in any form. In order to avoid the same punishment and curses which was pronounced on the wicked for failing to help others, we should regularly pay attention to the needs of people particularly the underprivileged in our midst. This is important because whatever we do for them is done for Jesus Christ who will reward us according to our deeds.

    DISCUSSION TIME
    1. To what extent do you think selfishness can affect one's faith in Jesus Christ?
    2. How do we identify those who are actually in need, especially these days when lazy people go about pretending that they are in need?

Prayer Points

  • Thank God for the love He has bestowed on you through Jesus Christ.
  • Pray that you will be a channel of His love to the needy/poor.
  • Pray that you will not live selfishly but bless the needy around you.

Fellowship and Ministry Building Activities

  • Role-play a scene in which a believer helps an unbeliever and then shares the Gospel.
  • Discuss the likely results.

Take Home

  • God will surely judge the works of men.
  • God frowns at selfishness because it is an invitation to everlasting punishment.
  • Jesus recognises the kindness done to people.
  • Believers should demonstrate their love to God through care and hospitality.
  • Faith and works are inseparable.
